headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for D.R. Horton, America’s Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to in
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for D.R. Horton, America’s Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Jessica Hansen, Vice President, Investor Relations for D.R. Horton. Please go ahead, Jessica.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our results for the first quarter of fiscal 2016. Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities L
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our results for the first quarter of fiscal 2016. Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there is no assurance that actual outcomes will not be materially different.
All forward-looking statements are based upon information available to D.R. Horton on the date of this conference call, and D.R. Horton does not undertake any obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. Additional information about issues that could lead to material changes in performance is contained in D.R. Horton's annual report on Form 10-K, which are filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
For your convenience, this morning's earnings release can be found on our website at investor.drhorton.com, and we plan to file our 10-Q in the next few days. After the conclusion of the call, we will post updated supplementary historical data through our investor relations site on the Presentations section under news and events for your reference.
The supplementary information includes historical data on gross margins, changes in active selling communities, product mix and our mortgage operation. Now I will turn the call over to David Auld, our President and CEO.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jessica, and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I am pleased to be joined of this call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat,our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.The ye
componenttext:
Thank you, Jessica, and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I am pleased to be joined of this call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat,our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
The year holding started the year with a strong first quarter, setting us for a great 2016. Our consolidated pretax income increased to $241 million from $2.4 billion of revenue and our pretax operating margin improved 40 basis points to 10%.
Our home selling increased 9% compared to the first quarter of last year due to improved absorptions. These results reflect the solid performance of our core communities and our Emerald Homes and Express Homes brands. We are striving to be the leading builder in each of our markets and to expand our industry-leading market share. We plan to maintain consistent, broad product diversity with our 3 brands over the long term. Our continued strategic focus is to produce double-digit annual growth in both our revenue and pretax profits, while generating positive cash flows and increasing our returns. 
With the sales backlog of 10,665 homes at the end of December, positive sales trends in January and a well-stocked supply of land, lots and homes, we are well positioned for the spring selling season and for 2016. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Net income for the first quarter increased 11% to $158 million or $0.42 per diluted share compared to $143 million or $0.39 per diluted share in the year-ago quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 9% to $241 million in the first quarter compare
componenttext:
Net income for the first quarter increased 11% to $158 million or $0.42 per diluted share compared to $143 million or $0.39 per diluted share in the year-ago quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 9% to $241 million in the first quarter compared to $221 million in the year-ago quarter. And homebuilding pretax income increased 11% to $229 million compared to $206 million in the prior year quarter. 
Our first quarter home sales revenues increased 4% to 2.3% $2.3 billion on 8,061 homes closed, up of from $2.2 billion on 7,973 homes closed in the year-ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was $290,400, up 3% compared to the prior year due to an increase in our average sales price, which were. 
This quarter, entry level homes market under our Express Homes brand accounted for 22% of homes closed and 15% of home sales revenue. Our homes for hire-in move up and luxury buyers priced greater than $500,000 accounted for 7% of our homes closed and 16% of our home sales revenue. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The value of our net sales orders in the first quarter increased 12% from the year-ago quarter to $2.4 billion and homes sold increased 9% to 8,064  homes on a relatively flat active selling community cap. Our average sales price of net sales orders in th
componenttext:
The value of our net sales orders in the first quarter increased 12% from the year-ago quarter to $2.4 billion and homes sold increased 9% to 8,064  homes on a relatively flat active selling community cap. Our average sales price of net sales orders in the first quarter increased 3% to $293,700. The cancellation rate for the first quarter was 23%, down from 24% from the year-ago quarter. 
The value of our backlog increased 16% from the year ago to $3.2 billion with an average sales price per home of $297,600 and homes in backlog increased 15% to 10,665 homes. 
Our backlog conversion rate for the first quarter was 76%, within the range we guided to in our fourth quarter call. We expect our second quarter backlog conversion rate to be in the range of 82% to 85%. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the first quarter was 19.9%, consistent with the fourth quarter and up 10 basis points from the first quarter of last year. The consistency in our gross margin reflects the stability of most of most of ou
componenttext:
Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the first quarter was 19.9%, consistent with the fourth quarter and up 10 basis points from the first quarter of last year. 
The consistency in our gross margin reflects the stability of most of most of our markets today. We are raising prices or reducing intensive when possible in communities where we are achieving our target absorptions, and we are also working to control cost increases. 
Our general gross margin expectations remained unchanged. In the current housing market, we continue to expect our average home sales gross margin to generally be around 20% with quarterly fluctuations that may range from 19% to 21% due to product and geographic mix and the relative impact of warranty and interest cost. 
As a reminder, our reported gross margin include all of our interest costs. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the first quarter, homebuilding SG&A expense was $243 million compared to $238 million in the prior year quarter. As a percentage of homebuilding revenues, SG&A improved 30 basis points to 10.3% compared to 10.6% in the prior-year quarter. Thus, our re
componenttext: In the first quarter, homebuilding SG&A expense was $243 million compared to $238 million in the prior year quarter. As a percentage of homebuilding revenues, SG&A improved 30 basis points to 10.3% compared to 10.6% in the prior-year quarter. Thus, our revenue increased and improved our leverage of fixed overhead cost. We remain focused on controlling our SG&A, while ensuring that our infrastructure adequately supports our current and expected growth. Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Financial services pretax income in the first quarter was $12.3 million compared to $14.6 million in the year-ago quarter. 90% of our mortgage company's loan originations during the quarter related to home closed by our homebuilding operation and our mort
componenttext:
Financial services pretax income in the first quarter was $12.3 million compared to $14.6 million in the year-ago quarter. 90% of our mortgage company's loan originations during the quarter related to home closed by our homebuilding operation and our mortgage company handled the financing for 51% of our home buyers. 
As we the accounted for 50% of the mortgage company's volume compared to 42% in the year-ago quarter. Borrowers originating loans with our mortgage company this quarter had an average FICA score of 714 and an average loan-to-value ratio of 89%. First time homebuyers represented 43% of the closings handled by our mortgage company compared to 40% in the first quarter last year. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: At the end of December, we had 21,500 homes in inventory, of which, 1,600 were models, 11,300 of our total loans homes were spec homes, with 7,700 in various stages of construction and 3,600 completed. Our construction in progress in finished homes inve
componenttext:
At the end of December, we had 21,500 homes in inventory, of which, 1,600 were models, 11,300 of our total loans homes were spec homes, with 7,700 in various stages of construction and 3,600 completed. 
Our construction in progress in finished homes inventory increased by $291 million during the quarter as we prepared for seasonally higher demand in the spring. Our first quarter investments in lots, land and development totaled $627 million, an increase of 11% from the first quarter last year. $365 million was to replenish finished lots and land and $262 million was for land development. We expect that our investments in and development for the full year of 2016 will be at least 20% greater than fiscal 2015. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: At December 31, 2015, our portfolio consisted of 178,000 lots, of which, 117,000 are owned and 61,000 are controlled through option contracts, which represents a 10% increase in our option position since year end. 69,000 of our total lots were finished,
componenttext:
At December 31, 2015, our portfolio consisted of 178,000 lots, of which, 117,000 are owned and 61,000 are controlled through option contracts, which represents a 10% increase in our option position since year end. 
69,000 of our total lots were finished, of which, 33,000 are owned and 36,000 our auctioned. Our 178,000 total lots owned and controlled provide us a strong competitive advantage in the housing market, with a sufficient lots with solid growth in sales and closings in future periods. 
Although our housing inventories will fluctuate as we manage each of communities throughout the, we expect our land and lot inventory to remain relatively stable to slightly higher in 2016, which will result in positive cash flows. 
In the first quarter, we've used $1.5 million of operating cash and improvement of $128 million compared to the first 3 months of last year. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: During the first quarter, the company reported $1.5 million in land options charges for of deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded $500,000 of inventory impairment charges. We will continue to evalua
componenttext:
During the first quarter, the company reported $1.5 million in land options charges for of deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded $500,000 of inventory impairment charges. We will continue to evaluate our inventories for potential impairments, which may result in future charges but the timing and magnitude of these charges will fluctuate as they had in the past. 
Our inactive landholder development of $185 million at the end of the quarter represents 10,500 lots, down 24% from 1 year ago. We continue to work through each of our remaining and active land parcels to improve cash flows and returns, and we expect that our landfill development will continue to decline. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: At December 31, our homebuilding liquidity included $1.2 billion of unrestricted homebuilding cash and $871 million available on our revolving credit facility. We had no cash borrowings and $104 million of letters of credit outstanding on the revolver.
componenttext:
At December 31, our homebuilding liquidity included $1.2 billion of unrestricted homebuilding cash and $871 million available on our revolving credit facility. We had no cash borrowings and $104 million of letters of credit outstanding on the revolver. 
Our gross homebuilding leverage ratio was 35.5% and our homebuilding leverage ratio net of cash was 25.7%. The balance of our public loans outstanding at December 31 was $3.3 billion. 
On January 15, we repaid $170 million of senior notes at the maturity and now, we have $373 million of maturities remaining in fiscal 2016. At December 31, our shareholders' equity was $6.1 billion and book value per share was $16.39, up 14% from a year ago. Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our expectations for fiscal 2016 remained unchanged from a what we shared on our November call and are based on current housing market conditions. We continue to expect to generate consolidated pretax operating margin of 10.5% to 11% for fiscal 2016. We a
componenttext:
Our expectations for fiscal 2016 remained unchanged from a what we shared on our November call and are based on current housing market conditions. We continue to expect to generate consolidated pretax operating margin of 10.5% to 11% for fiscal 2016. We also still expect to generate consolidated revenues between $12 billion and $12.5 billion and to close between 39,500 and 41,500 homes. 
We anticipate our home sales growth margin for the full year of 2016 will be in the high 19% to 20%, with potential quarterly fluctuations that may range from 19% to 21%. 
We estimate that our annual homebuilding SG&A expense will be in the range of 9.2% to 9.4% of homebuilding revenues, with the second quarter of the year higher than the range and the third and fourth quarters below the range. 
We expect our annual financial services operating margins to range from 30% to 33%. We are forecasting our fiscal 2016 income tax rate to be between 35% and 36% and our diluted share count to be approximately 375 million shares. 
We also continue to expect to generate $300 million to $500 million of positive cash flow from operation. Our fiscal 2016 results will be significantly impacted by the spring selling season, and we will update our expectations each quarter in visibility to the spring and full year becomes clear. 
For the second fiscal quarter of 2016, we expect our number of homes closed will approximate at the backlog conversion range in the range of 82% to 85%. We anticipate our second quarter home sales gross margin will be in the high 19% to 20% consistent with the first quarter, and we expect our homebuilding SG&A in the second quarter to be in the range of 10.3% to 10.6% of homebuilding revenues. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In closing, our first quarter growth in sales and profits and the improvement in our pretax margin was a result of the strength of our people and operating platform. We are excited and prepared for the spring selling season and opportunities ahead. We rem
componenttext:
In closing, our first quarter growth in sales and profits and the improvement in our pretax margin was a result of the strength of our people and operating platform. We are excited and prepared for the spring selling season and opportunities ahead. We remain focused on growing both our revenue and pretax profit at a double-digit annual pace, while continuing to generate positive cash flows and improve returns. We are well positioned to do so with our solid balance sheet, industry-leading market share, broad geographic footprint, diversified product offerings across our D.R. Horton, Emerald and Express brands, attractive finished lot and land positions, and most importantly, our tremendous team across the country. 
We'd like to thank all of our employees for their continued hard work, and we look forward to working together to continue growing and improving our operations during 2016. 
Let's keep the momentum from January billing week by week into the spring. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. We will now host questions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I wanted to ask, the tone that you're describing to begin the year is pretty positive. You mentioned January orders being positive. That's -- could imply a pretty broad range, so it's you could be more specific. And more broadly, the tone t
componenttext: First question I wanted to ask, the tone that you're describing to begin the year is pretty positive. You mentioned January orders being positive. That's -- could imply a pretty broad range, so it's you could be more specific. And more broadly, the tone that you're describing, it sounds like it is sufficient  to -- the absorption momentum d is sufficient to meet your revenue and closing expectations for the year so I wonder if you could just comment on that as well, please.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a positive because we see positive things out in the market. And the absorption's improvement on the relatively flat account, less pressure on margins. It was a good first quarter. And what we're seeing going to January, yes, was a lot of co
componenttext: Well, we have a positive because we see positive things out in the market. And the absorption's improvement on the relatively flat account, less pressure on margins. It was a good first quarter. And what we're seeing going to January, yes, was a lot of confidence.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to share just a little bit more about January. We're seeing week by week accelerating sales pace as we would expect to see in January and it's certainly consistent with typical seasonality and certainly in line with our expectations and our budge
componenttext: And just to share just a little bit more about January. We're seeing week by week accelerating sales pace as we would expect to see in January and it's certainly consistent with typical seasonality and certainly in line with our expectations and our budget. So we're feeling good about what we're seeing so far, what we produced in the first quarter. Sales we're seeing so far in January are right in line with our plans. in total is sufficient to generate the volume that we're guiding through for the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And second question. You folks have had a strategy of being more capital efficient, focusing on return on inventory the path 12 or 18 months or so. You've clearly been successful with that, judging from the amount of cash and liquidity that you have at th
componenttext: And second question. You folks have had a strategy of being more capital efficient, focusing on return on inventory the path 12 or 18 months or so. You've clearly been successful with that, judging from the amount of cash and liquidity that you have at the moment. So normally, a buildup of cash like this is the way like you would behave if you're expecting a downturn in the market or if you're trying to back down the hatches. So without an increase from the dividend per share buyback, what are your thoughts here? And if that characterization is correct, I mean, how can you be drawing the inventory when we still have 50% or 60% upside potential in single-family volumes going forward?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think we're going back inventory. As a matter of fact, we're guiding, I think, this year to be up 15%, 20% from what we're pushing out spending. So although focus on efficiency gains and returns, I think are -- have little to do with what we
componenttext: Well, I don't think we're going back inventory. As a matter of fact, we're guiding, I think, this year to be up 15%, 20% from what we're pushing out spending. So although focus on efficiency gains and returns, I think are -- have little to do with what we're thinking about when the market is going to be good or bad. It has a lot to do with, I think, driving to become the best company in the industry. And the liquidity and a strong balance sheet gives us a lot of flexibility and we'll see what we do with cash and.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This year, we didn't see the opportunities to invest in the business. We still do expect our land spend to be up -- land and development spend to be up 20% this year. We're continuing to add lots under option contracts and control for future growth in tha
componenttext: This year, we didn't see the opportunities to invest in the business. We still do expect our land spend to be up -- land and development spend to be up 20% this year. We're continuing to add lots under option contracts and control for future growth in that direction. But as David said, continuing to drive to more efficient business model for ourselves helps us improve our operational disciplines across the board. And that's been a consistent focus we've had in this company for a long time, and we're seeing a lot of this results bearing fruit right now. And we will be looking to pay our debt with existing cash that we just paid of, I think, $170 million in January. And we have enough maturity in April of $370 million. Bill? [indiscernible]

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question today is coming from Stephen East from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our last question today is coming from Stephen East from Evercore ISI.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016

componenttext: David, could you just talk a little bit, obviously, we'll get a lot of questions about taxes and what's happening with Royal. Could you talk a little bit sort of rank order your cities as far as the percentage of your business? And maybe talk a little bit about the demand trends that you're seeing and where you are in investing within the state, either -- well I'm looking at not only investing in communities, but also are you targeting either express, or Emerald, or is it pretty much across the board?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, it's pretty much across the board on what we're targeting pushing out. The Express has been the driver, I think, with market share gains, but Texas is in good shape. I spent the last few weeks driving Dallas/Fort Worth areas and I can tell you, y
componenttext: Stephen, it's pretty much across the board on what we're targeting pushing out. The Express has been the driver, I think, with market share gains, but Texas is in good shape. I spent the last few weeks driving Dallas/Fort Worth areas and I can tell you, you can put a house in Texas and pretty much any market and sell it in like a margin of 2 50. You're going to sell houses. So we're focused on improving the value encashment. We're focused on driving absorption levels up on a community by community basis and that has been a successful strategy for us in Texas. As far as revenues by city, Dallas/Fort Worth, well, 58% of the market share today. And I believe we can expand that, so we love Texas. We really love our operators in Texas.

componenttext: 25. Okay. David, if I can just follow on the capital allocation. You just talked about your land development being up about 20%. Did I understand you right, Mike, that you're 3 70, the spring, you'll actually pay that off? And then as you look at M&A, one, what are you seeing out there? And what's your appetite for it?

componenttextpreview: So we will, with the 3 70 mature and we have adequate cash to pay that off today and to be opportunistic. If we look at any  portion somewhere all that in a refinancing the thing what the market look like and timing to hit that. With M&A, we continue to b
componenttext: So we will, with the 3 70 mature and we have adequate cash to pay that off today and to be opportunistic. If we look at any  portion somewhere all that in a refinancing the thing what the market look like and timing to hit that. With M&A, we continue to be very inquisitive, if you will, and look at a lot of opportunities. As far as bar high for us, and looking an acquisition that makes sense, we have a great footprint today. We have good operations and having adding on to that, the high bar. So we would be very disciplined on the M&A front.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question today is coming from Stephen Kim from Barclays.
componenttext: Our last question today is coming from Stephen Kim from Barclays.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question that I had relates to what you're seeing with respect to the first-time buyer activity. And I know that at least from the entry-level side, as long as you agree those things go hand-in-hand, you've all been kind of leading the m
componenttext: I guess the first question that I had relates to what you're seeing with respect to the first-time buyer activity. And I know that at least from the entry-level side, as long as you agree those things go hand-in-hand, you've all been kind of leading the market with your Express. But the data we look at shows that beginning of April less in the first-time buyer activities markedly improved. It's now up nearly 20% year-on-year. And yet we're still not seeing your competitors indicating that there's see insufficient activity out there to work with them going out there. So it's quite an unusual situation where you really seem to have that end of the market kind of to yourselves. And so I guess to say  can you shed a little light on, a, are you in fact feeling a pickup in the market at the first-time buyer area or segment in the market since the summer of last year? Have you seen that? And B, do you have any more current thinking as to how the competitive dynamics addressing that market may change or not in '16?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the market picking up, in -- as we continue to push out the Express brand, we continue to see consistent absorption and brand. So we are -- we're in the process of pushing that brand out across the country and. Everywhere we've gone, we've seen
componenttext: As far as the market picking up, in -- as we continue to push out the Express brand, we continue to see consistent absorption and brand. So we are -- we're in the process of pushing that brand out across the country and. Everywhere we've gone, we've seen good absorption and margins at or above what we are having. So.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the competitive landscape, certainly, the entry-level, the lower end of the market is certainly the strongest right now. And anything that we see that market, we expect further competition. You're right, we haven't a whole lot in a lot of our marks. W
componenttext: And the competitive landscape, certainly, the entry-level, the lower end of the market is certainly the strongest right now. And anything that we see that market, we expect further competition. You're right, we haven't a whole lot in a lot of our marks. We probably haven't probably seen as much as we expected, but we do expect more to come to the line.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then touching back on this interesting position of strong cash flow generation next year, which is an unusual thing and usually doesn't happen early in the cycle. With your fairly optimistic commentary about the market and our position within i
componenttext: Great. And then touching back on this interesting position of strong cash flow generation next year, which is an unusual thing and usually doesn't happen early in the cycle. With your fairly optimistic commentary about the market and our position within it, I would just point out that your comment about a 20% increase in land spend next year would still imply a very low ratio relative to revenues, which is essentially you're basically barely replenishing what you're burning off in terms of dollars invested in land, which isn't a bad thing. It's just that I were disappointed. But that does still, it sound to me even though you're calculating in terms to make it sound like you're leaning forward on land investment, it actually isn't. It sounds to me like on balance, you are being relatively judicious, very judicious, actually, historically in your land spend next year. And so, I guess, I'm curious as to touching on what you said in the past. What you intend to do with the cash that you are going to be building here over the course of the next year. Do you, for instance, envision using that more for debt paydown, share repurchases, M&A up, over the course of the next 2 to 3 years?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve. First, to your comment about replenish our land supply. We feel very good about the level of our land supply in terms of what we own. And we are, the 20% or greater spend that we are essentially expecting, does replenish our land supply. We th
componenttext: Yes, Steve. First, to your comment about replenish our land supply. We feel very good about the level of our land supply in terms of what we own. And we are, the 20% or greater spend that we are essentially expecting, does replenish our land supply. We thought that it's sufficient level to support the growth expectations and guidance that we have provided, but we're definitely taking a balanced approach and keeping the investment levels within a disciplined range, and with that, generating a lot of cash flow. As far as how we look at our cash position today, we talked a bit about our debt maturities. To the extent that market is favorable, we would still issue new debts or refinance rates are still certainly very attractive and we continue to look for investments in our business. If we see great investment that will push our land spending up to 25% or 30%, we feel like we generate a good return, we will do that. And as Mike has already talked about, M&A, there are a lot of opportunities. And hopefully, there will be some come along that will meet our threshold and this cash position puts us in a great, flexible opportunistic position to be able to take advantage of that. And so today, in terms of priorities, we would just investing our business, which would include potential M&A taking care of our debt maturities along the way  as our top priorities. And beyond that, we're going to remain in a flexible and opportunistic position in the next year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: our next question today is coming from Adam Rudiger from Wells Fargo and Associates.
componenttext: our next question today is coming from Adam Rudiger from Wells Fargo and Associates.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on spec count. I think looking at operating number here, it looks like year-over-year, you're down roughly 20% on completed specs, 10% on total. And yes, I can figure expecting relatively lower growth this year than last year. But is the
componenttext: First question is on spec count. I think looking at operating number here, it looks like year-over-year, you're down roughly 20% on completed specs, 10% on total. And yes, I can figure expecting relatively lower growth this year than last year. But is there any conservative and bake them? Or just given some of the macro uncertainties, we're seeing. Maybe just talk about your thought process and where you see your in selling season?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. I would say, no [indiscernible] optimism. We are attempting to continue to do what we've been doing, which is consolidate our market share in a market by market program. We are measuring and trying to control finished inventory and keep it
componenttext: This is David. I would say, no [indiscernible] optimism. We are attempting to continue to do what we've been doing, which is consolidate our market share in a market by market program. We are measuring and trying to control finished inventory and keep it turning because of that drives SG&A leverage and it also drives significant efficiencies in the operations, so.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We feel like we're in very good position for the spring. We started a lot of houses in the first quarter. We're going to start a lot of houses in the second quarter to feed the sales that we expect. But with that, just like we are at the land, we are rema
componenttext: We feel like we're in very good position for the spring. We started a lot of houses in the first quarter. We're going to start a lot of houses in the second quarter to feed the sales that we expect. But with that, just like we are at the land, we are remaining disciplined community-by-community, and. So I think we have gotten a bit more efficient with turning our specs over the last year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And second follow-up, if I could. It sounds like you guys are pretty bullish on the January activity. I think the big concern that investors had is that the stock market volatility here is going to be maybe more at the higher end. It's causing some
componenttext: Great. And second follow-up, if I could. It sounds like you guys are pretty bullish on the January activity. I think the big concern that investors had is that the stock market volatility here is going to be maybe more at the higher end. It's causing some skittishness among the buyers there. So given your diversification of the product side, have you seen any differences in buyer activity between Emerald division and maybe down to the Express division? Or are the comments you had company-wide is pretty consistent by price point?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, pretty consistent. There is a slower movement on the MRO and higher price points are not seeing the same levels of activity that we're seeing in the wholly Express brands.
componenttext: Actually, pretty consistent. There is a slower movement on the MRO and higher price points are not seeing the same levels of activity that we're seeing in the wholly Express brands.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that a rated change comment? Meaning, it slowed over the last month or 2? Or is that just generally speaking, you get lower absorption, which, I think, would be expected?
componenttext: Is that a rated change comment? Meaning, it slowed over the last month or 2? Or is that just generally speaking, you get lower absorption, which, I think, would be expected?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say of change over the last couple of quarters. I can tell you, right now, January is starting off very good, so.
componenttext: I would say of change over the last couple of quarters. I can tell you, right now, January is starting off very good, so.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today's coming from Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Our next question today's coming from Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of Express, just curious what you're seeing in the market and how you're managing that in terms of price points? And also, the mix of the product that's obviously been successful, but I'm curious how you're managing that and how you're seeing the
componenttext: In terms of Express, just curious what you're seeing in the market and how you're managing that in terms of price points? And also, the mix of the product that's obviously been successful, but I'm curious how you're managing that and how you're seeing the behavior of first time or the homebuyer evolving in those market?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, as David mentioned, we've been very pleased with the rollout of Express. We talked to you for several course that the majority of that business has been in Texas, the Carolinas and Florida. That's still the case in the of our sales and closings are
componenttext: Sure, as David mentioned, we've been very pleased with the rollout of Express. We talked to you for several course that the majority of that business has been in Texas, the Carolinas and Florida. That's still the case in the of our sales and closings are coming out of those markets, but we're starting to see more meaningful share from some other parts of the country. The next largest state for us actually right now is California. The majority of that is in our Southern California market and that is bringing our average price point for Express up. A good quarter. It was $199,000. So in the next quarter, more than likely, we'll be over the $200,000-dollar mark with our Express Homes product offering, but really just due to geographic mix. And we've been very pleased with the rollout of Express in those other markets in addition to Texas, Carolinas and Florida where the reception still remains very strong.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of how the product is moving in existing markets, and I appreciate the California expansion, but is there anything that's different either from a price or cost or efficiency standpoint that's materially different than in terms of where it's  been
componenttext: In terms of how the product is moving in existing markets, and I appreciate the California expansion, but is there anything that's different either from a price or cost or efficiency standpoint that's materially different than in terms of where it's  been or in terms of where it's going?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say pretty consistent with where it's been. And we're going to drive where it's going. So the Express program is price point-driven. So we set works and targets and drive to that price point. So it's -- we'll -- I just -- the overall express progr
componenttext: I would say pretty consistent with where it's been. And we're going to drive where it's going. So the Express program is price point-driven. So we set works and targets and drive to that price point. So it's -- we'll -- I just -- the overall express program has been well received and continues to exceed what we thought it would be when it came out.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then secondly in terms of your expectations for price or incentives, and, obviously, you're going to wait how to spring season develops. But can you speak a little bit what Plan A looks like in regards to that relative to 1 year ago?
componenttext: Okay. And then secondly in terms of your expectations for price or incentives, and, obviously, you're going to wait how to spring season develops. But can you speak a little bit what Plan A looks like in regards to that relative to 1 year ago?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what we're seeing with good absorption in the communities, it's taken pressure off the margin and it's giving us in terms of communities of pricing power to reduce incentives and that's been showing up positing in margins. We plan to continue that
componenttext: I think what we're seeing with good absorption in the communities, it's taken pressure off the margin and it's giving us in terms of communities of pricing power to reduce incentives and that's been showing up positing in margins. We plan to continue that. The Plan A is to maintain the and that we budgeted for the year and we're seeing the market being great for of that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today's coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question today's coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I had was just trying to drill down a little bit across the regions from the order growth perspective during the quarter. Well you had, for example, some deceleration in the year-over-year order growth. I guess across the board but more not
componenttext: First question I had was just trying to drill down a little bit across the regions from the order growth perspective during the quarter. Well you had, for example, some deceleration in the year-over-year order growth. I guess across the board but more notably in the Southeast, still very strong at 22% growth versus -- but that was versus a stronger rate in '15. A couple of smaller regions fell off as well. So I was hoping to get any kind of color across the regions in terms of perhaps, highlighting, which markets right now that you might see has been stronger than others. And if there's any particular changes in community count growth that might have driven some of those regional changes quarter-to-quarter in terms of the year-over-year trend.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we saw an increase in our absorption in every region, Mike, outside of the Midwest. The Midwest a very small region for us and it does include Chicago, which we pointed to for a while now as being a weaker market. A large but, otherwise, every region
componenttext: Yes, we saw an increase in our absorption in every region, Mike, outside of the Midwest. The Midwest a very small region for us and it does include Chicago, which we pointed to for a while now as being a weaker market. A large but, otherwise, every region in terms of sales on a year-over-year basis was up as we did see a decline in our community count in half of our regions. And as we noted already, our count -- community count was relatively flat with up just almost slightly at about 1% on a year-over-year basis. So we're seeing a good pickup in absorption in a majority of our markets today, I would say.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. The -- I guess, secondly, just from the growth side, there's been a couple of questions previously around growth expectations and your land spend up, but kind of keeping your lot count flat and basically replacing what you're working
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. The -- I guess, secondly, just from the growth side, there's been a couple of questions previously around growth expectations and your land spend up, but kind of keeping your lot count flat and basically replacing what you're working through. Just thinking at the same time, you're expecting, I believe you said double-digit growth. Correct me if I'm wrong, that's your goal over the next 2 or 3 years. So how are you -- at least from a revenue or order growth standpoint, now with community count flattish for 3 quarters, maybe for another couple of quarters here, is growth something that would be reinfused into the strategy as we think about fiscal '17 and '18? Obviously, you're also creating a lot of dry powder here, building up the cash or paying down some debt incrementally. And it seems like there's a little bit of a 1 foot on the pedal or halfway on the gas pedal, whereas again, you're still well below midcycle levels as an industry. So any thoughts around, perhaps, a re-acceleration of that community count growth as we look into '17 or '18?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're looking for to continue to aggregate market share market-by-market. And we're looking at double-digit growth year-over-year and profit sales and closings. So it's -- yes, we get what we believe is a sustainable program. And the fact that we'
componenttext: I think we're looking for to continue to aggregate market share market-by-market. And we're looking at double-digit growth year-over-year and profit sales and closings. So it's -- yes, we get what we believe is a sustainable program. And the fact that we're generating cash and improving our balance sheet while gaining efficiency, it just kind of opened a lot of opportunity for us than January. And growth as a core strategy, growth at a double-digit pace is a core part of that strategy, but it is a balanced strategy. Our guidance for this year, in terms of top line revenue, equates to an 11% to 15% annual increase. Our closings guidance for the year equates to an 8% to 13% increase. And so our expectation this year are to be in the low double-digit range, which, from our perspective, is solid growth and in line with our expectations in this quarter with our sales pace in the range of our expectations for the year and certainly puts us in position to continue consistent growth. Our investment levels, we think we've done a lot growth on a couple of years from absorption improvements with the Express roll out, while our average community count has moderated. Our expectation this year , while we still see absorption improves, it will be quite at the pace that it wasn't in the prior years, but we still expect solid absorption improvements. And then certainty, going forward, when we achieve a much better level of efficiencies and perhaps in future growth at a double-digit pace may come from some further community count growth. But today and for this year, we expect low -- flat to low single-digit community count growth with improved absorptions to drive a double-digit revenue growth.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Bill. And I think just maybe to press that further, that concept in terms of the shift between community count and absorption that's occurred in the last 6, 8 quarters. This year, again, it looks like perhaps a high single-digit or so. Per
componenttext: That's helpful, Bill. And I think just maybe to press that further, that concept in terms of the shift between community count and absorption that's occurred in the last 6, 8 quarters. This year, again, it looks like perhaps a high single-digit or so. Perhaps, low double-digit absorption growth with more flattish community count. To the extent that you're coming that, that growth would continue to moderate perhaps due to the mixed shift more fully playing out from the Express standpoint, to the extent that you're expecting double-digit growth in '17, it would imply, to the extent that the absorption continues to moderate, some re-acceleration in community count. Is that fair?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe that's fair. Yes.
componenttext: I believe that's fair. Yes.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question today is coming from Ken Zener from KeyBanc.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk about the 60% of your buyers that are not first time. Obviously, it appears that there's a volatility on the existing home sales numbers and some of that mortgage related, but it does seem that things are decelerating a little b
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk about the 60% of your buyers that are not first time. Obviously, it appears that there's a volatility on the existing home sales numbers and some of that mortgage related, but it does seem that things are decelerating a little bit on the existing side. Is there anything that would cause you concern? Or David, Bill, could you kind of talk about what the income being up of that existing side might look like? And how that might concern you? I know, obviously, it used to starting to see rising inventory of existing and slowly existing sales. Have you started seeing the market where people not be able to sell their houses or anything? So that was a big part of the market last time when it started to slow down.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll tell you, Ken, we're not seeing the markets were up. When we resale market, is still relatively strong. We're continuing to see positive signs. So I mean, are inventory turns are improving. Our absorption are improving. We're stable. And in some case
componenttext: I'll tell you, Ken, we're not seeing the markets were up. When we resale market, is still relatively strong. We're continuing to see positive signs. So I mean, are inventory turns are improving. Our absorption are improving. We're stable. And in some cases, improving margins. So we feel very good about the market right now. And I'm not saying -- obviously, slow [indiscernible], but the balance of our market is doing very, very well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then if I could ask about California where you did highlight your -- some Express product. You talked about lifting your ASP. And then also as it relates to some of your other product, what percent of those homes do you believe are going to or towards
componenttext: And then if I could ask about California where you did highlight your -- some Express product. You talked about lifting your ASP. And then also as it relates to some of your other product, what percent of those homes do you believe are going to or towards investors, be it, if you can split it domestic and/or international?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have exact breakdown of the investors. And I would tell you, it's very low. What you're hearing about investors sales. A lot of people that are moving rental situation into a home that they can afford.
componenttext: We don't have exact breakdown of the investors. And I would tell you, it's very low. What you're hearing about investors sales. A lot of people that are moving rental situation into a home that they can afford.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016

componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall from RBC.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016

componenttext: Did you guys get any help with the December weather? To that extent, the construction season? And for deliveries in 4Q?

componenttext: Well, we had real weather in the fourth quarter in a couple of our major markets. But also, Carolinas in the Dallas/Fort Worth. As Mike said, we have weather [indiscernible]. What our numbers better with typical weather,  I'll say it again. [indiscernible] But we're very happy with our numbers we posted and I think were going to have a great year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It sounds like it's a past due with a start. ASP was up 3.3% and average price growth of 2.7% on the new side. And you're talking about maintaining a 19.5% to a 20% gross margin. I'm just trying to get a better picture of how to think about price is being
componenttext: It sounds like it's a past due with a start. ASP was up 3.3% and average price growth of 2.7% on the new side. And you're talking about maintaining a 19.5% to a 20% gross margin. I'm just trying to get a better picture of how to think about price is being low single-digit, what you're seeing on the labor cost side and if you're experiencing any delays due to labor bottlenecks and if that's been resolved? What's really giving you the confidence to reiterate your guidance for a very solid margin performance this year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the confidence is coming from being [indiscernible] of the operators out in [indiscernible]. And what they sense and what they feel is taking place in the markets. And across the board, our people feel very good about what's happening out there. T
componenttext: I think the confidence is coming from being [indiscernible] of the operators out in [indiscernible]. And what they sense and what they feel is taking place in the markets. And across the board, our people feel very good about what's happening out there. The labor side, I would say, it's still stressed, but seems to be improving. And the trade basis are starting to add people. I think a big part of the improvement that we're seeing is consistency in production in community by community is allowing the [indiscernible] to our work for us to hit those numbers. And it's taken awhile to get there, but they are adding people. I think our great is becoming more and more confident as well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bob, in terms of what we saw in price changes, our revenues per square foot outpaced our stick and brick per square foot on a year-over-year basis for a second time, so we've gotten to check. Sequentially, that was essentially net neutral. So if our m
componenttext: And Bob, in terms of what we saw in price changes, our revenues per square foot outpaced our stick and brick per square foot on a year-over-year basis for a second time, so we've gotten to check. Sequentially, that was essentially net neutral. So if our margin ticked up by 10 basis points year-over-year and stayed flat from Q4 to Q1, we are continuing to experience higher costs, but in about the same range in year-over-year as we were last quarter so flat gross margin.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me ask you, Jessica, just on that  point, are you really getting priced or is the driver really a reflection of the stronger mix with a bias towards the West Coast?
componenttext: And let me ask you, Jessica, just on that  point, are you really getting priced or is the driver really a reflection of the stronger mix with a bias towards the West Coast?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're actually gaining priced. If you look at our price per square foot, which is the best way we can try to look at our business apples-to-apples, we did see a low single-digit increase.
componenttext: We're actually gaining priced. If you look at our price per square foot, which is the best way we can try to look at our business apples-to-apples, we did see a low single-digit increase.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. If I can sneak one final in. Can you just like a way to think about Houston versus Dallas in the sense that it sounds like Dallas is very strong. You said Houston was soft. How do we think about that? Is there any more of a book end you can give u
componenttext: Got it. If I can sneak one final in. Can you just like a way to think about Houston versus Dallas in the sense that it sounds like Dallas is very strong. You said Houston was soft. How do we think about that? Is there any more of a book end you can give us?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All of [indiscernible] I spent a week driving Dallas and drive in Fort Worth in January. And when I got back, I told I had to get out of the field because if I stayed in Dallas and Fort Worth, I would become way too aggressive buying land. It's good in ma
componenttext: All of [indiscernible] I spent a week driving Dallas and drive in Fort Worth in January. And when I got back, I told I had to get out of the field because if I stayed in Dallas and Fort Worth, I would become way too aggressive buying land. It's good in market and closing. And as for Houston, I think there's a lot of conversation, a lot of uncertainty, a lot of volatility within the oil and gas business, which I think is making people more concerned when they out buying homes. I think there's still pent-up demand in Houston. I think the pent-up demand is growing, but it is just not the frenzy what we've seen in the past or is someplace in Texas markets.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from the line of James McCanless from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from the line of James McCanless from Sterne Agee.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could give on the labor issue. I think some people are concerned about would there be enough labor to make the number closing in the back half of the year that your guidance suggests.  Could you u talk -- I mean, when you talk about labor getting bet
componenttext: If I could give on the labor issue. I think some people are concerned about would there be enough labor to make the number closing in the back half of the year that your guidance suggests.  Could you u talk -- I mean, when you talk about labor getting better and the adding more people, is it across-the-board? Or is it just in specific market versus specific areas like frame, et cetera?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's pretty much across the board. I mean, we're seeing the construction labor force increase. And I think our strive to create more efficiency in the process and selling homes and trying to actually take some labor out of the per square foot cost of home
componenttext: It's pretty much across the board. I mean, we're seeing the construction labor force increase. And I think our strive to create more efficiency in the process and selling homes and trying to actually take some labor out of the per square foot cost of home has paid off. And our trades are money and we're seeing less pressure on good cost side. And I think we're both value for customer. So we feel like we are positioned for the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then the second question I had on Express, could you just update us on how many markets you ultimately want to with that product? And how far along you think you are in that process?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then the second question I had on Express, could you just update us on how many markets you ultimately want to with that product? And how far along you think you are in that process?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, I think there are probably we're in 78 [ph] markets. We probably will end up mid-60s, primarily because some markets just don't. We don't know why market product and we're not going to give up the brand to sell Express. We have a lot of opportunities
componenttext: Oh, I think there are probably we're in 78 [ph] markets. We probably will end up mid-60s, primarily because some markets just don't. We don't know why market product and we're not going to give up the brand to sell Express. We have a lot of opportunities still to increase our position with the most of the markets and are actively out there looking every day to do it.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And how far along you think you're in that process?
componenttext: Okay. And how far along you think you're in that process?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe halfway.
componenttext: Maybe halfway.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're in 48 markets in 15 states today. But after David's comments, we haven't fully saturated the market that we're currently in with Express. So there's more runway within that 40-plus expanding to the mid-60s.
componenttext: We're in 48 markets in 15 states today. But after David's comments, we haven't fully saturated the market that we're currently in with Express. So there's more runway within that 40-plus expanding to the mid-60s.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're on saving capital for the programs that are driving the best returns. And right now, Express is driving very good returns.
componenttext: We're on saving capital for the programs that are driving the best returns. And right now, Express is driving very good returns.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse's.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse's.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, if we could go back and put a finer point on the Texas discussion, it sounds like Dallas is clearly very strong. And if I look at your South Central trends overall, up 7% in orders, Dallas presumably outpacing that by a decent degree. So Houston, c
componenttext: David, if we could go back and put a finer point on the Texas discussion, it sounds like Dallas is clearly very strong. And if I look at your South Central trends overall, up 7% in orders, Dallas presumably outpacing that by a decent degree. So Houston, can you give us a ballpark around year-over-year what Houston's doing? And we've heard some other builders talk about the weakness extending down to the 250 take price point. I know you said earlier you put up -- if you can put up a home at $250,000, you can sell. But is there any additional color on trends that across the price segmentation within your Houston business that you can [indiscernible]?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Houston has been relatively stable for us on a year-over-year basis. So we didn't see a further slowdown in Houston, but we're also not seeing any meaningful pickup. We continue to see our lower price Express homes, very steady demands, steady sales pace.
componenttext: Houston has been relatively stable for us on a year-over-year basis. So we didn't see a further slowdown in Houston, but we're also not seeing any meaningful pickup. We continue to see our lower price Express homes, very steady demands, steady sales pace. But as has been mentioned a couple of times on the call, definitely softer at the higher end. But we continue to see good steady demand for the entry-level and people moving out of apartments. We were providing an attractive rent versus buy equation and driving to those sales offices each week. So we continue to have a close eye on Houston. We're not heavily reinvesting in Houston right now. We are replenishing where it makes sense and where we continue to add those entry-level product offerings.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, just to add a little more cover. We've had some what I would call A-plus project location positions in Houston that are maybe at the price point that we're seeing less demand for. We are going to accelerate or liquidate those positions. So we will s
componenttext: Mike, just to add a little more cover. We've had some what I would call A-plus project location positions in Houston that are maybe at the price point that we're seeing less demand for. We are going to accelerate or liquidate those positions. So we will see lower absorptions in those communities and these are -- they're communities we can't totally place and don't want to. So it's -- we're going to protect the value in our core projects absorption at the $250,000 to $300,000 range. And if you're looking at what I look at, almost 0 margin deterioration on the projects that are at the price point that are turning right now. And we don't need more than we want to force a sales or project for we have been selling $350,000 to $450,000 and are just seeing our absorptions we boost. So that's my call on Houston. I think it's going to be a tremendous market for us for a long time.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just a follow up on that last point. As you take a step back and say, look, there's too much value in some of these A+ locations to give them away, we have heard increased chatter in terms of competitors are starting to cut prices or pickup incent
componenttext: I guess just a follow up on that last point. As you take a step back and say, look, there's too much value in some of these A+ locations to give them away, we have heard increased chatter in terms of competitors are starting to cut prices or pickup incentives. So how much of it is related to the market is trading away from you? And didn't -- you're not chasing it, but the market has moved on price.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are very strong in the 2 -- I mean, we dominate the $250,000 to $300,000, -- $200,000 to $300,000 price point at Houston and we're going to continue to dominate that. And if you look at our -- the benefit -- one of the many benefits of D.R. Horton is t
componenttext: We are very strong in the 2 -- I mean, we dominate the $250,000 to $300,000, -- $200,000 to $300,000 price point at Houston and we're going to continue to dominate that. So -- I mean, it's -- we have a lot of levers to pull, but consistent comment to the people inside the company is its good to be us because we can hit our plan. And without being forced to sell a project we don't want to sell at the pace that it's been lagging.

And we'll know a whole lot more when we talk to you next quarter.

componenttext: Yes, no doubt. The 2 be prepared for the new regulations. Our mortgage family financial services operation had to make significant investments primarily in personnel. The effort to comply is a big one. And in order to meet those regulations and provide the experience to the homebuyers, they've had to increase cost there. Typically, those seems that on a seasonal basis. We see our lower operating margins in our first and second quarters and in our lower volume quarters. And then we typically see higher-than-average operating margins in financial services in Q3 and Q4. And so the margin here this quarter in the low 20s certainly does not preclude achieving the 30% to 33% guidance for the year.
