componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question today is coming from Ken Zener from KeyBanc.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk about this 60% of your buyers that are not first time. Obviously, it appears that there was volatility on the existing home sales number in December some of that mortgage related, but it does seem that things are decelerating a
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk about this 60% of your buyers that are not first time. Obviously, it appears that there was volatility on the existing home sales number in December some of that mortgage related, but it does seem that things are decelerating a little bit on the existing side. Is there anything that would cause you concern? Or David, Bill, could you kind of talk about what a gumming up of that existing side might look like? And how that might concern you? I know, obviously, Houston is starting to see rising inventory of existing and slowly existing sales. Have you started seeing in any of the market issues with people not being able to sell their houses or anything? So that was a big part of the market last time when it started to slow down.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll tell you, Ken, we're not seeing that in the markets we're operating. The resale market, is still relatively strong with continuing positive signs. So I mean, our inventory turns are improving. Our absorption per flag are improving. We're stable. And
componenttext: I'll tell you, Ken, we're not seeing that in the markets we're operating. The resale market, is still relatively strong with continuing positive signs. So I mean, our inventory turns are improving. Our absorption per flag are improving. We're stable. And in some cases, improving margins. So we feel very good about the market right now and are not seeing other than -- obviously, Houston is slow, but the balance of our markets are doing very, very well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then if I could ask about California where you did highlight your -- some Express product. Jessica, you talked about lifting your ASP. And then also as it relates to any of your other product, what percent of those homes do you believe are going to or
componenttext: And then if I could ask about California where you did highlight your -- some Express product. Jessica, you talked about lifting your ASP. And then also as it relates to any of your other product, what percent of those homes do you believe are going to or towards investors, be it, if you can split it out domestic and/or international?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have exact breakdown of the investors. Anecdotally I would tell you, it's very low. What we're hearing about any investors sales. A lot of it is just people that are moving out of a rental situation into a home that they can afford.
componenttext: We don't have exact breakdown of the investors. Anecdotally I would tell you, it's very low. What we're hearing about any investors sales. A lot of it is just people that are moving out of a rental situation into a home that they can afford.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall from RBC.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall from RBC.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Did you guys get any help with the December weather? To that extent, the construction season and assist for deliveries in 4Q?
componenttext: Did you guys get any help with the December weather? To that extent, the construction season and assist for deliveries in 4Q?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had real weather in the fourth quarter in a couple of our bigger markets. Across the Carolinas and [indiscernible] Dallas/Fort Worth. But as Mike points out, we have weather every quarter. So would our numbers have better with typical weather? Yes, the
componenttext: We had real weather in the fourth quarter in a couple of our bigger markets. Across the Carolinas and [indiscernible] Dallas/Fort Worth. But as Mike points out, we have weather every quarter. So would our numbers have better with typical weather? Yes, they would have been. But we're very happy with the numbers we've posted and think we're going to have a great year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sounds like it's fast year to start. ASP was up 3.3% and average price growth of 2.7% on the new order side. And you're talking about maintaining a 19.5% to a 20% gross margin. I'm just trying to get a better picture of how to think about price is being l
componenttext: Sounds like it's fast year to start. ASP was up 3.3% and average price growth of 2.7% on the new order side. And you're talking about maintaining a 19.5% to a 20% gross margin. I'm just trying to get a better picture of how to think about price is being low single-digit, what you're seeing on the labor cost side and if you're experiencing any delays due to labor bottlenecks and if that's been resolved? How -- what's really giving you the confidence to reiterate your guidance for a very solid margin performance this year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the confidence is coming from being in touch with the operators out in the divisions. And what they sense and what they feel is taking place in their markets. And across the board, our people feel very good about what's happening out there. The la
componenttext: I think the confidence is coming from being in touch with the operators out in the divisions. And what they sense and what they feel is taking place in their markets. And across the board, our people feel very good about what's happening out there. The labor side, I would say, it's still stressed, but seems to be improving. And the trade bases are starting to add people. I think a big part of the improvement we're seeing is consistency in production in the community-by-community is allowing these rates to stay up and maintain a workforce to hit those numbers. And it's taken a while to get there, but they are adding people. I think our credit base is seeing -- is becoming more and more confident as well. So.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bob, in terms of what we saw in price changes, our revenues per square foot outpaced our stick and brick per square foot on a year-over-year basis for the second time, so we've gotten to where that's in check. Sequentially, that was essentially net ne
componenttext: And Bob, in terms of what we saw in price changes, our revenues per square foot outpaced our stick and brick per square foot on a year-over-year basis for the second time, so we've gotten to where that's in check. Sequentially, that was essentially net neutral. So you saw our margin tick up by 10 basis points year-over-year and stayed flat from Q4 to Q1, we are continuing to experience higher land costs, but in about the same range year-over-year as we were last quarter, so flat gross margin.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me ask you, Jessica, just on that point, are you really getting priced or is the driver really a reflection of the stronger mix with a bias towards the West Coast?
componenttext: And let me ask you, Jessica, just on that point, are you really getting priced or is the driver really a reflection of the stronger mix with a bias towards the West Coast?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're actually getting priced. If we look at our price per square foot, which is the best way we can try to look at our business apples-to-apples, we did see a low single-digit increase.
componenttext: We're actually getting priced. If we look at our price per square foot, which is the best way we can try to look at our business apples-to-apples, we did see a low single-digit increase.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And if I can sneak one final in. Can you just like a way to think about Houston versus Dallas in the sense that it sounds like Dallas is very strong. You said Houston is soft. How do we think about that? Is there any more of a book end you can giv
componenttext: Got it. And if I can sneak one final in. Can you just like a way to think about Houston versus Dallas in the sense that it sounds like Dallas is very strong. You said Houston is soft. How do we think about that? Is there any more of a book end you can give us?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will tell you, Bob. I spent a week driving in Dallas and a week driving in Fort Worth in January. And when I got back, I told Horton I had to get out of the field because if I stayed in Dallas and Fort Worth, I would become way too aggressive buying lan
componenttext: I will tell you, Bob. I spent a week driving in Dallas and a week driving in Fort Worth in January. And when I got back, I told Horton I had to get out of the field because if I stayed in Dallas and Fort Worth, I would become way too aggressive buying land. It is as good a market we have seen. And as for Houston, I think there's a lot of conversation, a lot of uncertainty, a lot of volatility within the oil and gas business, which I think is making people more conservative about buying homes. I think there's still pent-up demand in Houston. I think that pent-up demand is growing, but it is just not the frenzy what we've seen in the past or is really taking place in some of the Texas markets.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from the line of James McCanless from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from the line of James McCanless from Sterne Agee.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could, maybe I can touch on the labor issue. I think some people are concerned about would there be enough labor to make the number of closings in the back half of the year that your guidance suggests.  Could you talk -- I mean, when you talk about l
componenttext: If I could, maybe I can touch on the labor issue. I think some people are concerned about would there be enough labor to make the number of closings in the back half of the year that your guidance suggests.  Could you talk -- I mean, when you talk about labor getting better and the subs adding more people, is it across-the-board? Or is it just in specific market versus specific areas like framing, et cetera?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's pretty much across the board. And I mean, we're seeing the construction labor force increase. And I think our strive to create more efficiency in the process of building selling homes and trying to actually take some labor out of a per square foot co
componenttext: It's pretty much across the board. And I mean, we're seeing the construction labor force increase. And I think our strive to create more efficiency in the process of building selling homes and trying to actually take some labor out of a per square foot cost of a home has paid off. And our trades are making money and we're seeing less pressure on the cost side. And I think providing more value for the customer. So we feel like we are positioned to deliver our year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then the second question I had on Express, could you just update us on how many markets you ultimately want to go to with that product? And how far along you think you are in that process?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then the second question I had on Express, could you just update us on how many markets you ultimately want to go to with that product? And how far along you think you are in that process?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, I think there are -- probably we're in 78 markets. We probably will end up mid-60s, primarily because some markets just don't. We don't allow you to dual market your product and we're not going to give up the Horton brand to sell Express. We have a lo
componenttext: Oh, I think there are -- probably we're in 78 markets. We probably will end up mid-60s, primarily because some markets just don't. We don't allow you to dual market your product and we're not going to give up the Horton brand to sell Express. We have a lot of opportunities still to increase our position within most of the markets and are actively out there looking every day to do that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And how far along you think you're in that process?
componenttext: Okay. And how far along you think you're in that process?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe halfway.
componenttext: Maybe halfway.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're in 48 markets in 15 states today. But to echo David's comments, we haven't fully saturated the markets that we're currently in with Express. So there's more runway within those 48 plus expanding to the mid-60s.
componenttext: We're in 48 markets in 15 states today. But to echo David's comments, we haven't fully saturated the markets that we're currently in with Express. So there's more runway within those 48 plus expanding to the mid-60s.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean we're allocating capital to the programs that are driving the best returns. And right now, Express is driving great returns.
componenttext: I mean we're allocating capital to the programs that are driving the best returns. And right now, Express is driving great returns.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, if we could go back and put a finer point on the Texas discussion, it sounds like Dallas is clearly very strong. And if I look at your South Central trends overall, up 7% in orders, Dallas presumably outpacing that by a decent degree. So Houston, c
componenttext: David, if we could go back and put a finer point on the Texas discussion, it sounds like Dallas is clearly very strong. And if I look at your South Central trends overall, up 7% in orders, Dallas presumably outpacing that by a decent degree. So Houston, can you give us a ballpark around year-over-year what Houston's doing? And we've heard some other builders talk about the weakness extending down to the 250k take price point. I know you said earlier you put up -- if you can put up a home at $250,000, you can sell it. But is there just any additional color on trends that across the price segmentation within your Houston business that you can provide?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Houston has been relatively stable for us on a year-over-year basis. So we didn't see a further slowdown in Houston, but we're also not seeing any meaningful pickup. We continue to see our lower priced Express homes, very steady demands, steady sales pace
componenttext: Houston has been relatively stable for us on a year-over-year basis. So we didn't see a further slowdown in Houston, but we're also not seeing any meaningful pickup. We continue to see our lower priced Express homes, very steady demands, steady sales pace. But as has been mentioned a couple of times on the call, definitely softer at the higher end. But we continue to see good steady demand for the entry-level and people moving out of apartments where we're providing an attractive rent versus buy equation and driving people into the sales offices each week. So we continue to have a close eye on Houston. We're not heavily reinvesting in Houston right now. We are replenishing where it makes sense and where we can continue to add those entry-level product offerings.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, just to add a little more color. We have some, what I would call, A+ project location positions in Houston that are maybe at the price point that we're seeing less demand for. And we are not going to accelerate or liquidate those positions. So we wi
componenttext: Mike, just to add a little more color. We have some, what I would call, A+ project location positions in Houston that are maybe at the price point that we're seeing less demand for. And we are not going to accelerate or liquidate those positions. So we will see lower absorptions in those communities and these are -- they're communities we can't -- don't replace and don't want to. So it's -- we're going to protect the value in our core projects, take absorption at the $250,000 to $300,000 range. And if you're looking at what I look at, almost 0 margin deterioration on the projects that are at the price point that are turning right now. And we don't need nor do we want to force a sales and a core project where we have been selling $350,000 to $450,000 and are just seeing our absorptions reduced. So that's my color on Houston. I think it's going to be a tremendous market for us for a long time.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just a follow-up on that last point. As you take a step back and say, look, there's too much value in some of these A+ locations to give them away, we have heard increased chatter in terms of that competitors are starting to cut prices or pickup i
componenttext: I guess just a follow-up on that last point. As you take a step back and say, look, there's too much value in some of these A+ locations to give them away, we have heard increased chatter in terms of that competitors are starting to cut prices or pickup incentives. So how much of it is related to the market is trading away from you and you're not chasing it, but the market has moved on price.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are very strong in the 2 -- I mean, we dominate the $250,000 to $300,000 -- $200,000 to $300,000 price point at Houston and we're going to continue to dominate that. And if you look at our -- the benefit -- one of the many benefits of being D.R. Horton
componenttext: We are very strong in the 2 -- I mean, we dominate the $250,000 to $300,000 -- $200,000 to $300,000 price point at Houston and we're going to continue to dominate that. And if you look at our -- the benefit -- one of the many benefits of being D.R. Horton is the broad geographic footprint. When the upper end in Houston slows down, the entry-level in Denver accelerates. So -- I mean, it's -- we have a lot of levers to pull, my consistent comment to the people inside the company is it's good to be us because we can hit our plan. And without being forced to sell a project we don't want to sell at the pace that it's been running at.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful and yes, a good position to be in. If I could shift gears to another earlier discussion around community count and absorptions and just as it relates to the guide, I think you mentioned unit delivery is up 8% to 13%. If we look at d
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful and yes, a good position to be in. If I could shift gears to another earlier discussion around community count and absorptions and just as it relates to the guide, I think you mentioned unit delivery is up 8% to 13%. If we look at deal orders, it seems like absorption is up about 8%. How much of the delta between hitting the low end versus the high end of the units will come from increasing your absorption beyond that 8% on a year-over-year basis versus getting more community -- communities open and getting that community count up into a low- to mid-single digit range by the end of the year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're pretty much running on our absorption targets. So I think we will, as we continue to push out the Express brand and follow-up replacing the Horton positions, I think we will see some community count grow. We don't have visibility in that today. We d
componenttext: We're pretty much running on our absorption targets. So I think we will, as we continue to push out the Express brand and follow-up replacing the Horton positions, I think we will see some community count grow. We don't have visibility in that today. We do have visibility in what we know we can deliver, so.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to know exactly where the contributions are sitting here in January not knowing what the spring is doing the whole. We're certainly seeing good early signs, but clearly, the strength of the spring selling season will help determine our year, it
componenttext: It's hard to know exactly where the contributions are sitting here in January not knowing what the spring is doing the whole. We're certainly seeing good early signs, but clearly, the strength of the spring selling season will help determine our year, it will determine where we land in our range or whether we could perhaps exceed our range. And so it's January, feeling good and feel good about our position, our preparations for the spring, and then we'll go try to execute as best we can over the next few months. And we'll know a whole lot more when we talk to you next quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Will Randow from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Will Randow from Citigroup.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was curious on the implementation of the know-before-you-owe or credit, if you will, for you guys. How that look like? How do you feel about, I guess for lack of a better term, the complexity as well as days out at the closings. And if you can just shar
componenttext: I was curious on the implementation of the know-before-you-owe or credit, if you will, for you guys. How that look like? How do you feel about, I guess for lack of a better term, the complexity as well as days out at the closings. And if you can just share some color there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really haven't seen an appreciable impact in the delay in closings. Our team have worked very hard to prepare for the changing roles and worked with our captive mortgage company. DHI Mortgages' folks have done a yeoman's job preparing for this change a
componenttext: We really haven't seen an appreciable impact in the delay in closings. Our team have worked very hard to prepare for the changing roles and worked with our captive mortgage company. DHI Mortgages' folks have done a yeoman's job preparing for this change as well as working with our preferred lenders. So really didn't see a material impact on our closings for the quarter. We'll continue to improve our processes and try to become more efficient and make it a good experience for the buyers.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up, as talked about a few times during Q&A, but on labor inflation, I think you guys are running at 2% or 3% in the prior reported quarter, well some of your competitors out there running closer to 10%. Have you seen more inflati
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up, as talked about a few times during Q&A, but on labor inflation, I think you guys are running at 2% or 3% in the prior reported quarter, well some of your competitors out there running closer to 10%. Have you seen more inflation? And has that been different for specs versus the total company?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the labor side has been minimized for us because we set absorption targets per community and drive to that, so we have consistency within the communities. And our trades are not out there looking for work one week and then add twice what they can
componenttext: I think the labor side has been minimized for us because we set absorption targets per community and drive to that, so we have consistency within the communities. And our trades are not out there looking for work one week and then add twice what they can do the next.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we are still just running a low single-digit percentage increase on cost per square foot. Stick and brick.
componenttext: And we are still just running a low single-digit percentage increase on cost per square foot. Stick and brick.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from John Lovallo from Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from John Lovallo from Merrill Lynch.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on the financial services margin. We have it about 16%, I think, in the quarter versus a guide of 30% to 33%. Now, was there any trade-related expenses kind of lumped in there in the quarter?
componenttext: First question is on the financial services margin. We have it about 16%, I think, in the quarter versus a guide of 30% to 33%. Now, was there any trade-related expenses kind of lumped in there in the quarter?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no doubt. The 2 be prepared for the new regulations. Our mortgage company financial services operation had to make significant investments primarily in personnel. The effort to comply is a big one. And in order to meet those regulations and providing
componenttext: Yes, no doubt. The 2 be prepared for the new regulations. Our mortgage company financial services operation had to make significant investments primarily in personnel. The effort to comply is a big one. And in order to meet those regulations and providing that experience to the homebuyers, they've had to increase cost there. Typically, those season on a -- from a seasonal basis. We see our lower operating margins in our first and second quarters and our lower volume quarters. And then we typically see higher-than-average operating margins in financial services in Q3 and Q4. And so the margin here this quarter in the low 20s certainly does not preclude achieving the 30% to 33% guidance for the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then the one follow-up would be realizing that weather is an issue every quarter somewhere, the recent weather we've had on the East Coast is -- has been pretty serious, particularly in areas like Carolina that are used to having
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then the one follow-up would be realizing that weather is an issue every quarter somewhere, the recent weather we've had on the East Coast is -- has been pretty serious, particularly in areas like Carolina that are used to having that kind of impact. So, I mean, are you guys anticipating any trouble in the coming quarter due to the storm?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly do appreciated it hasn't been a serious storm that's impacted a lot of people, but we feel -- it's fortunate early in our quarter and our operating teams will be able to take care of our existing homeowners in the communities and deal with the h
componenttext: Certainly do appreciated it hasn't been a serious storm that's impacted a lot of people, but we feel -- it's fortunate early in our quarter and our operating teams will be able to take care of our existing homeowners in the communities and deal with the homes that are in backlog and the specs that are out there today, and be ready for sale next week end.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd also like to add, it's a beautiful day in Texas today. So the sun is shining on somebody somewhere everyday.
componenttext: I'd also like to add, it's a beautiful day in Texas today. So the sun is shining on somebody somewhere everyday.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Buy a house in Texas.
componenttext: Buy a house in Texas.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our final question today is coming from the line of Susan Maklari from UBS.
componenttext: Our final question today is coming from the line of Susan Maklari from UBS.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You have talked frequently about how you've just not seeing a lot of competition coming in to the sort of first-time Express kind of price point. What do you think is the biggest factor that would have to change, either from an operating kind of industry
componenttext: You have talked frequently about how you've just not seeing a lot of competition coming in to the sort of first-time Express kind of price point. What do you think is the biggest factor that would have to change, either from an operating kind of industry perspective or from a macro perspective that would finally push some of the peers maybe perhaps come in and kind of create a bit more competition for you there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a hard enough time managing our people. I don't want to get in to trying to help them help themselves. So I don't know. All we do is get up everyday and operate and pursue to be the best we can be. We're tough competition. Maybe they just --
componenttext: Well, we have a hard enough time managing our people. I don't want to get in to trying to help them help themselves. So I don't know. All we do is get up everyday and operate and pursue to be the best we can be. We're tough competition. Maybe they just -- yes, I don't know.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But entry-level housing is something we've done for a very long time. It's a core competency of our business. And with our footprint and with that competency among our operating teams across the country, it's something that we've -- we got a lot to practi
componenttext: But entry-level housing is something we've done for a very long time. It's a core competency of our business. And with our footprint and with that competency among our operating teams across the country, it's something that we've -- we got a lot to practice at. So it's something we're focused on. Like we said earlier, it's a good market and there's a lot of demand there, we do expect some more competition down the line. And I think that'll be a natural next step in the cycle.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will say, we were first movers and we were aggressive first movers. And I would believe that the other companies that are also good at driving value will be following us in it. But then we've bought the lion's share of the finished lots. And when we saw
componenttext: I will say, we were first movers and we were aggressive first movers. And I would believe that the other companies that are also good at driving value will be following us in it. But then we've bought the lion's share of the finished lots. And when we saw the success, we started the investment. We have taken a development developing lots. So we just have a head start. I'm sure they're coming.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just follow up on trade. Obviously, you guys has done great job in rolling that out. But as we do get into the spring and start to just see overall activity levels increase, do you see anything out there that starts to trip things up at all
componenttext: Okay. And then just follow up on trade. Obviously, you guys has done great job in rolling that out. But as we do get into the spring and start to just see overall activity levels increase, do you see anything out there that starts to trip things up at all?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The area that we've watched the most closely, that we have less visibility to are the closings with outside lenders. Obviously, our internal mortgage company are captive closing, so we have more visibility in that process, I feel confident about that. But
componenttext: The area that we've watched the most closely, that we have less visibility to are the closings with outside lenders. Obviously, our internal mortgage company are captive closing, so we have more visibility in that process, I feel confident about that. But with outside lenders, it's something we watch closely division by division, where they have relationships with outside lenders they're working with them to make sure that we have the visibility to hit things on time, but I think that's where the greater risk is. But I honestly think month-by-month as everyone in the process gets more used to and I think it will get smoother. And any disruption that may have occurred thus far I think will be alleviated over the coming months.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for D.R. Horton, America’s Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to in
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for D.R. Horton, America’s Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Jessica Hansen, Vice President of Investor Relations for D.R. Horton. Please go ahead, Jessica.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our results for the first quarter of fiscal 2016. Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities L
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our results for the first quarter of fiscal 2016. Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumption, there is no assurance that actual outcomes will not be materially different.
All forward-looking statements are based upon information available to D.R. Horton on the date of this conference call, and D.R. Horton does not undertake any obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. Additional information about issues that could lead to material changes in performance is contained in D.R. Horton's annual report on Form 10-K, which is filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
For your convenience, this morning's earnings release can be found on our website at investor.drhorton.com, and we plan to file our 10-Q in the next few days. After the conclusion of the call, we will post updated supplementary historical data through our investor relations site on the Presentations section under News and Events for your reference.
The supplementary information includes historical data on gross margins, changes in active selling communities, product mix and our mortgage operations. Now I will turn the call over to David Auld, our President and CEO.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jessica, and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I am pleased to be joined on this call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.Our D
componenttext:
Thank you, Jessica, and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I am pleased to be joined on this call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Our D.R. Horton team started the year with a strong first quarter, setting us up for a great 2016. Our consolidated pretax income increased to $241 million from $2.4 billion of revenue, and our pretax operating margin improved 40 basis points to 10%.
Our homes sold increased 9% compared to the first quarter of last year due to improved absorptions. These results reflect the solid performance of our core D.R. Horton communities and our Emerald Homes and Express Homes brands. We are striving to be the leading builder in each of our markets and to expand our industry-leading market share. We plan to maintain consistent, broad product diversity with our 3 brands over the long term. Our continued strategic focus is to produce double-digit annual growth in both our revenue and pretax profits, while generating positive cash flows and increasing our returns. 
With a sales backlog of 10,665 homes at the end of December, positive sales trends in January and a well-stocked supply of land, plots homes, we are well-positioned for the spring selling season and for 2016. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Net income for the first quarter increased 11% to $158 million or $0.42 per diluted share compared to $143 million or $0.39 per diluted share in the year-ago quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 9% to $241 million in the first quarter compare
componenttext:
Net income for the first quarter increased 11% to $158 million or $0.42 per diluted share compared to $143 million or $0.39 per diluted share in the year-ago quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 9% to $241 million in the first quarter compared to $221 million in the year-ago quarter. And homebuilding pretax income increased 11% to $229 million compared to $206 million in the prior year quarter. 
Our first quarter home sales revenues increased 4% to 2.3% -- $2.3 billion on 8,061 homes closed, up from $2.2 billion on 7,973 homes closed in the year-ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was $290,400, up 3% compared to the prior year due to an increase in our average sales price per square foot.  
This quarter, entry-level homes market under our Express Homes brand accounted for 22% of homes closed and 15% of home sales revenue. Our homes for higher-end, move-up and luxury buyers priced greater than $500,000 accounted for 7% of our homes closed and 16% of our home sales revenue. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The value of our net sales orders in the first quarter increased 12% from the year-ago quarter to $2.4 billion and homes sold increased 9% to 8,064  homes on a relatively flat active selling community cap. Our average sales price on net sales orders in th
componenttext:
The value of our net sales orders in the first quarter increased 12% from the year-ago quarter to $2.4 billion and homes sold increased 9% to 8,064  homes on a relatively flat active selling community cap. Our average sales price on net sales orders in the first quarter increased 3% to $293,700. The cancellation rate for the first quarter was 23%, down from 24% in the year-ago quarter. 
The value of our backlog increased 16% from a year ago to $3.2 billion, with an average sales price per home of $297,600. And homes in backlog increased 15% to 10,665 homes. 
Our backlog conversion rate for the first quarter was 76%, within the range we guided to on our fourth quarter call. We expect our second quarter backlog conversion rate to be in the range of 82% to 85%. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the first quarter was 19.9%, consistent with the fourth quarter, and up 10 basis points from the first quarter of last year. The consistency in our gross margin reflects the stability of most of our marke
componenttext:
Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the first quarter was 19.9%, consistent with the fourth quarter, and up 10 basis points from the first quarter of last year. 
The consistency in our gross margin reflects the stability of most of our markets today. We are raising prices or reducing incentives when possible in communities where we are achieving our target absorptions, and we are also working to control cost increases. 
Our general gross margin expectations remain unchanged. In the current housing market, we continue to expect our average home sales gross margin to generally be around 20%, with quarterly fluctuations that may range from 19% to 21% due to product and geographic mix and the relative impact of warranty and interest costs. 
As a reminder, our reported gross margins include all of our interest costs. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the first quarter, homebuilding SG&A expense was $243 million compared to $238 million in the prior year quarter. As a percentage of homebuilding revenues, SG&A improved 30 basis points to 10.3% compared to 10.6% in the prior-year quarter as our revenu
componenttext: In the first quarter, homebuilding SG&A expense was $243 million compared to $238 million in the prior year quarter. As a percentage of homebuilding revenues, SG&A improved 30 basis points to 10.3% compared to 10.6% in the prior-year quarter as our revenue increase improved our leverage of fixed overhead costs. We remain focused on controlling our SG&A, while ensuring that our infrastructure adequately supports our current and expected growth. Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Financial services pretax income in the first quarter was $12.3 million compared to $14.6 million in the year-ago quarter. 90% of our mortgage company's loan originations during the quarter related to homes closed by our homebuilding operation, and our mo
componenttext:
Financial services pretax income in the first quarter was $12.3 million compared to $14.6 million in the year-ago quarter. 90% of our mortgage company's loan originations during the quarter related to homes closed by our homebuilding operation, and our mortgage company handled the financing for 51% of our home buyers. 
FHA and VA loans accounted for 50% of the mortgage company's volume compared to 42% in the year-ago quarter. Borrowers originating loans with our mortgage company this quarter had an average FICA score of 714 and an average loan-to-value ratio of 89%. First time homebuyers represented 43% of the closings handled by our mortgage company compared to 40% in the first quarter last year. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: At the end of December, we had 21,500 homes in inventory, of which 1,600 were models, 11,300 of our total homes were spec homes, with 7,700 in various stages of construction and 3,600 completed. Our construction-in-progress and finished homes inventory
componenttext:
At the end of December, we had 21,500 homes in inventory, of which 1,600 were models, 11,300 of our total homes were spec homes, with 7,700 in various stages of construction and 3,600 completed. 
Our construction-in-progress and finished homes inventory increased by $291 million during the quarter as we prepared for seasonally higher demand in the spring. Our first quarter investments in lots, land and development totaled $627 million, an increase of 11% from the first quarter last year. $365 million was to replenish finished lots and land, and $262 million was for land development. We expect that our investments in land and development for the full year of 2016 will be at least 20% greater than fiscal 2015. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: At December 31, 2015, our portfolio consisted of 178,000 lots, of which, 117,000 are owned and 61,000 are controlled through option contracts, which represents a 10% increase in our option position since year end. 69,000 of our total lots were finished,
componenttext:
At December 31, 2015, our portfolio consisted of 178,000 lots, of which, 117,000 are owned and 61,000 are controlled through option contracts, which represents a 10% increase in our option position since year end. 
69,000 of our total lots were finished, of which, 33,000 are owned and 36,000 are optioned. Our 178,000 total lots owned and controlled provide us a strong competitive advantage in the current housing market, with a sufficient lot supply to support solid growth in sales and closings in future periods. 
Although our housing inventories will fluctuate as we manage each of our communities throughout to optimize returns, we expect our land and lot inventory to remain relatively stable to slightly higher in 2016, which will result in positive cash flows. 
In the first quarter, we used $1.5 million of operating cash, an improvement of $128 million compared to the first 3 months of last year. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: During the first quarter, we reported $1.5 million in land option charges for write-offs of earnest money deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded $500,000 of inventory impairment charges. We will con
componenttext:
During the first quarter, we reported $1.5 million in land option charges for write-offs of earnest money deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded $500,000 of inventory impairment charges. We will continue to evaluate our inventories for potential impairment, which may result in future charges, but the timing and magnitude of these charges will fluctuate as they have in the past. 
Our inactive land held for development of $185 million at the end of the quarter represents 10,500 lots, down 24% from 1 year ago. We continue to work through each of our remaining and active land parcels to improve cash flows and returns, and we expect that our land held for development will continue to decline. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: At December 31, our homebuilding liquidity included $1.2 billion of unrestricted homebuilding cash and $871 million available capacity on our revolving credit facility. We had no cash borrowings and $104 million of letters of credit outstanding on the rev
componenttext:
At December 31, our homebuilding liquidity included $1.2 billion of unrestricted homebuilding cash and $871 million available capacity on our revolving credit facility. We had no cash borrowings and $104 million of letters of credit outstanding on the revolver. 
Our gross homebuilding leverage ratio was 35.5% and our homebuilding leverage ratio net of cash was 25.7%. The balance of our public loans outstanding at December 31 was $3.3 billion. 
On January 15, we repaid $170 million of senior notes at their maturity, and now we have $373 million of maturities remaining in fiscal 2016. At December 31, our shareholders' equity was $6.1 billion and book value per share was $16.39, up 14% from a year ago. Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our expectations for fiscal 2016 remained unchanged from what we shared on our November call and are based on current housing market conditions. We continue to expect to generate a consolidated pretax operating margin of 10.5% to 11% for fiscal 2016. We a
componenttext:
Our expectations for fiscal 2016 remained unchanged from what we shared on our November call and are based on current housing market conditions. We continue to expect to generate a consolidated pretax operating margin of 10.5% to 11% for fiscal 2016. We also still expect to generate consolidated revenues of between $12 billion and $12.5 billion, and to close between 39,500 and 41,500 homes. 
We anticipate our home sales gross margin for the full year of 2016 will be in the high-19s to 20%, with potential quarterly fluctuations that may range from 19% to 21%. 
We estimate that our annual homebuilding SG&A expense will be in the range of 9.2% to 9.4% of homebuilding revenues, with the second quarter of the year higher than this range and the third and fourth quarters below the range. 
We expect our annual financial services operating margins to range from 30% to 33%. We are forecasting our fiscal 2016 income tax rate to be between 35% and 36% and our diluted share count to be approximately 375 million shares. 
We also continue to expect to generate $300 million to $500 million of positive cash flow from operations. Our fiscal 2016 results will be significantly impacted by the spring selling season, and we will update our expectations each quarter as visibility to the spring and full year becomes clearer. 
For the second fiscal quarter of 2016, we expect our number of homes closed will approximate a beginning backlog conversion rate in a range of 82% to 85%. We anticipate our second quarter home sales gross margin will be in the high-19s to 20%, consistent with the first quarter, and we expect our homebuilding SG&A in the second quarter to be in the range of 10.3% to 10.6% of homebuilding revenues. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In closing, our first quarter growth in sales and profits and the improvement in our pretax margin was a result of the strength of our people and operating platform. We are excited and prepared for the spring selling season and opportunities ahead. We rem
componenttext:
In closing, our first quarter growth in sales and profits and the improvement in our pretax margin was a result of the strength of our people and operating platform. We are excited and prepared for the spring selling season and opportunities ahead. We remain focused on growing both our revenue and pretax profit at a double-digit annual pace while continuing to generate positive cash flows and improved returns. We are well positioned to do so with our solid balance sheet; industry-leading market share; broad geographic footprint; diversified product offerings across our D.R. Horton, Emerald and Express brands; attractive finished lot and land positions; and most importantly, our tremendous team across the country. 
We'd like to thank all of our employees for their continued hard work, and we look forward to working together to continue growing and improving our operations during 2016. 
Let's keep the momentum from January going week by week into the spring. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. We will now host questions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I wanted to ask, the tone that you're describing to begin the year is pretty positive. You mentioned January orders being positive. That's -- could imply a pretty broad range, so I was wondering if you could be more specific. And more broad
componenttext: First question I wanted to ask, the tone that you're describing to begin the year is pretty positive. You mentioned January orders being positive. That's -- could imply a pretty broad range, so I was wondering if you could be more specific. And more broadly, the tone that you're describing, it sounds like it is sufficient  to -- the absorption momentum is sufficient to meet your revenue and close with the expectations for the year. So I was just wondering if you could just comment on that as well, please.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a positive tone because we're seeing positive things happen out in the market. And the absorption's improvement on the relatively flat community account, less pressure on margins. It was a good first quarter. And what we're seeing going into
componenttext: Well, we have a positive tone because we're seeing positive things happen out in the market. And the absorption's improvement on the relatively flat community account, less pressure on margins. It was a good first quarter. And what we're seeing going into January gives us a lot of confidence.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Nishu, just to share just a little bit more about January. We're seeing week by week accelerating sales pace, as we would expect to see in January and it's certainly consistent with typical seasonality, and certainly in line with our expectations and
componenttext: And, Nishu, just to share just a little bit more about January. We're seeing week by week accelerating sales pace, as we would expect to see in January and it's certainly consistent with typical seasonality, and certainly in line with our expectations and our budget. So we're feeling good about what we're seeing so far, what we produced in the first quarter. Sales we're seeing so far in January are right in line with our plans. And certainly are sufficient to generate the volume that we're guiding to for the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the second question. You folks have had a strategy of being more capital efficient, focusing on return on inventory across the past 12 or 18 months or so. You've clearly been successful with that, judging from the amount of cash and liquidity that you
componenttext: And the second question. You folks have had a strategy of being more capital efficient, focusing on return on inventory across the past 12 or 18 months or so. You've clearly been successful with that, judging from the amount of cash and liquidity that you have at the moment. So normally, a buildup of cash like this is the way that you would behave if you were expecting a downturn in the market or if you're trying to batten down the hatches. So without an increase from the dividend or a share buyback, what are your thoughts here? And if that characterization is correct, I mean, how can you be drawing back inventory when we still have 50% or 60% upside potential in single-family volumes going forward?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think we're drawing back inventory. As a matter of fact, we're guiding, I think, this year to be up 15%, 20% in what we're pushing out spending. So the focus on efficiency gains and returns, I think are -- have little to do with what we're t
componenttext: Well, I don't think we're drawing back inventory. As a matter of fact, we're guiding, I think, this year to be up 15%, 20% in what we're pushing out spending. So the focus on efficiency gains and returns, I think are -- have little to do with what we're thinking about whether the market's going to be good or bad. It has a lot to do with, I think, driving to become the best company in the industry. And the liquidity and strong balance sheet gives us a lot of flexibility and we'll see what we do with the cash. I mean, it's...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nishu, we still see opportunities to invest in the business. We still do expect our land spend to be up -- land and development spend to be up 20% this year. We're continuing to add lots under option contracts and control for future growth, that direction
componenttext: Nishu, we still see opportunities to invest in the business. We still do expect our land spend to be up -- land and development spend to be up 20% this year. We're continuing to add lots under option contracts and control for future growth, that direction. But as David said, continuing to drive up the more efficient business model for ourselves helps us improve our operational disciplines across the board. And that's been a consistent focus. We've had in this company for a long time, and we're seeing a lot of this results bearing fruit right now. And we will be looking to pay off debt with existing cash. We just paid of, I think, $170 million in January. And we have another maturity in April of $370 million. So, these are really good [indiscernible]

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Stephen East from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Stephen East from Evercore ISI.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, could you just talk a little bit -- obviously, we're get a lot of questions about Texas and what's happening with oil. Could you talk a little bit, sort of rank order your cities as far as the percentage of your business? And maybe talk a little bi
componenttext: David, could you just talk a little bit -- obviously, we're get a lot of questions about Texas and what's happening with oil. Could you talk a little bit, sort of rank order your cities as far as the percentage of your business? And maybe talk a little bit about the demand trends that you're seeing and where you all are in investing within the state, either -- well, I'm looking at not only investing in communities, but also are you targeting either Express or Emerald, or is it pretty much across the board?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, it's pretty much across the board on what we're targeting pushing out. The Express has been the driver, I think, of market share gains, but Texas is in good shape. I've spent the last 2 weeks driving the Dallas/Fort Worth areas and I can tell you
componenttext: Stephen, it's pretty much across the board on what we're targeting pushing out. The Express has been the driver, I think, of market share gains, but Texas is in good shape. I've spent the last 2 weeks driving the Dallas/Fort Worth areas and I can tell you, you can put a house in Texas in pretty much any market and sell it to make a margin. At $250,000, you're going to sell houses. So we're focused on improving the value encashment. We're focused on driving absorption levels up on a community-by-community basis and that has been a successful strategy for us in Texas. As far as revenues and by cities...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dallas/Fort Worth.
componenttext: Dallas/Fort Worth.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: #1 Dallas/Fort Worth, well, like we're 15% of the market share today. And to be honest, we do believe we can expand that. So we love Texas. We really love our operators in Texas.
componenttext: #1 Dallas/Fort Worth, well, like we're 15% of the market share today. And to be honest, we do believe we can expand that. So we love Texas. We really love our operators in Texas.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I can just follow on the capital allocation that you talked about, your land development being up about 20%. Did I understand you right, Mike, that your $370 million, this spring, you'll actually pay that off? And then as you look at M&A, one
componenttext: Okay. And if I can just follow on the capital allocation that you talked about, your land development being up about 20%. Did I understand you right, Mike, that your $370 million, this spring, you'll actually pay that off? And then as you look at M&A, one, what are you seeing out there? And what's your appetite for it?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we will, with the $370 million maturing, we have adequate cash to pay that off today and to be opportunistic, if we look at any portion, some or all of that, in a refinancing depending upon what the market look like and timing to hit that. With M&A, we
componenttext: So we will, with the $370 million maturing, we have adequate cash to pay that off today and to be opportunistic, if we look at any portion, some or all of that, in a refinancing depending upon what the market look like and timing to hit that. With M&A, we continue to be very inquisitive, if you will, and look at a lot of opportunities. The bar is pretty high for us in looking at all acquisitions that make sense. We have a great footprint today, we have good operations, and adding on to that it's a high bar. So we would be very disciplined on the M&A front.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is the activity picked up?
componenttext: Okay. Is the activity picked up?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's been running at a very high pace in terms of lots of activity for a while. I wouldn't say it's picked up in the past quarter.  It's been running at a good clip.
componenttext: It's been running at a very high pace in terms of lots of activity for a while. I wouldn't say it's picked up in the past quarter.  It's been running at a good clip.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question today is coming from Stephen Kim from Barclays.
componenttext: Our last question today is coming from Stephen Kim from Barclays.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lots of interesting things going on. I guess, the first question that I had relates to what you're seeing with respect to the first-time buyer activity. And I know that, at least on the entry-level side, as long as you to a degree those things kind of go
componenttext: Lots of interesting things going on. I guess, the first question that I had relates to what you're seeing with respect to the first-time buyer activity. And I know that, at least on the entry-level side, as long as you to a degree those things kind of go hand-in-hand. You'll have been kind of leading the market with your Express. But the data we look at shows that beginning in April of last year the first-time buyer activity is markedly improved. It's now up nearly 20% year-on-year. And yet, we are still not seeing your competitors indicating that they're seeing insufficient activity out there to want to bear them going out there. So it's quite an unusual situation where you really seem to have that end of the market to yourselves. And so I guess I would just say, can you shed a little light on, A, are you in fact feeling a pickup in the market at the first-time buyer area or segment of the market since the summer of last year? Have you seen that? And B, do you have any more -- current thinking as to how the competitive dynamics addressing that market may change or not in '16?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the market picking up, in -- as we continue to push out the Express brand, we're continuing to see consistent absorption and demand. So we are -- we're in the process of pushing that brand out across the country and everywhere we've gone, we've
componenttext: As far as the market picking up, in -- as we continue to push out the Express brand, we're continuing to see consistent absorption and demand. So we are -- we're in the process of pushing that brand out across the country and everywhere we've gone, we've seen good absorption and margins at or above what we [indiscernible] on that. So.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: As to the competitive landscape, certainly, the entry-level, the lower end of the market is certainly the strongest right now. And any time we see that in the market, we expect further competition. You're right, we haven't seen a whole lot in a lot of our
componenttext: As to the competitive landscape, certainly, the entry-level, the lower end of the market is certainly the strongest right now. And any time we see that in the market, we expect further competition. You're right, we haven't seen a whole lot in a lot of our markets. We probably haven't probably seen as much as we expected, but we do expect more as time goes on.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then touching back on this interesting juxtaposition of strong cash flow generation next year, which is an unusual thing and usually doesn't happen early in a cycle. With your fairly optimistic commentary about the market and your position with
componenttext: Great. And then touching back on this interesting juxtaposition of strong cash flow generation next year, which is an unusual thing and usually doesn't happen early in a cycle. With your fairly optimistic commentary about the market and your position within it, I would just point out that your comment about a 20% increase in land spend next year would still imply a very low ratio relative to revenues, which is just essentially you're basically barely replenishing what you're burning off in terms of dollars invested in land, which isn't a bad thing. It's just that I was disappointed. But that does still, it sounds to me even though you're couching that in terms to make it sounds like you're sort of leaning forward on land investment, it actually isn't. It sounds to me like on balance, you are being relatively judicious, very judicious, actually, historically in your land spend next year. And so, I guess, I'm curious as to touching on what you've said in the past. What you intend to do with the cash that you are going to be building here over the course of the next year. Do you, for instance, envision using that more for debt paydown, share repurchases, M&A over the course of the next 2 to 3 years?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve. First, to your comment about us replenishing our land supply, we feel very good about the level of our land supply in terms of what we own. And we are -- the 20% or greater spend that we are essentially expecting, does replenish our land suppl
componenttext: Yes, Steve. First, to your comment about us replenishing our land supply, we feel very good about the level of our land supply in terms of what we own. And we are -- the 20% or greater spend that we are essentially expecting, does replenish our land supply. And we felt like it's at a sufficient level to support the growth expectations and guidance that we have provided. But we're definitely taking a balanced approach and keeping the investment levels within a disciplined range, and with that, that's definitely generating a lot of cash flow. As far as how we look at our cash position today, we've talked a bit about our debt maturities. To the extent the market is favorable, we would still issue new debt. The refinance rates are still certainly very attractive and we continue to look for investments in our business. If we see great investments that would push our land spending up to 25% or 30%, we feel like it generates a great return, we will do that. And as Mike has already talked about, M&A, there are a lot of opportunities. And hopefully, there will be some coming along that meet our threshold and this cash position puts us in a great, flexible opportunistic position to be able to take advantage of that. And so today, in terms of priorities, we would list investing in our business, which would include potential M&A, taking care of our debt maturities along the way as our top priorities. And beyond that, we're going to remain in a flexible and opportunistic position for the next year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Alan Ratner from Zelman & Associates.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Alan Ratner from Zelman & Associates.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on the spec count. If am -- I think I'm looking for a number here, it looks like year-over-year, you're down roughly 20% on completed specs, 10% on total. And yes, I think that you're expecting relatively lower growth this year than last
componenttext: First question is on the spec count. If am -- I think I'm looking for a number here, it looks like year-over-year, you're down roughly 20% on completed specs, 10% on total. And yes, I think that you're expecting relatively lower growth this year than last year. But is there any conservatism baked in there, just given some of the macro uncertainties we're seeing now? Or maybe just talk a little bit about the thought process and where you see your spec count heading into the selling season?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. I would say, no baked-in optimism. I mean, we are attempting to continue to do what we've been doing, which is consolidate our market share in a market-by-market program. We are measuring and trying to control the finished inventory and kee
componenttext: This is David. I would say, no baked-in optimism. I mean, we are attempting to continue to do what we've been doing, which is consolidate our market share in a market-by-market program. We are measuring and trying to control the finished inventory and keep it turning because that drives SG&A leverage and it also drives significant efficiencies in the operations, so.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But we feel like we're in a good position for the spring. We started a lot of houses in the first quarter. We're going to start a lot of houses in the second quarter too, to feed the sales that we expect. But with that, just like we are with the land, we
componenttext: But we feel like we're in a good position for the spring. We started a lot of houses in the first quarter. We're going to start a lot of houses in the second quarter too, to feed the sales that we expect. But with that, just like we are with the land, we are remaining disciplined community-by-community, and so I think we have gotten a bit more efficient with turning our specs over the last year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And second follow-up, if I could. It sounds like you guys are pretty bullish on the January activity. I think the big concern that investors have is that the stock market volatility here is going to, maybe more at the higher end, cause some skittis
componenttext: Great. And second follow-up, if I could. It sounds like you guys are pretty bullish on the January activity. I think the big concern that investors have is that the stock market volatility here is going to, maybe more at the higher end, cause some skittishness among the buyers there. So given your diversification on the product side, have you seen any differences in buyer activity between your Emerald division and maybe down to the Express division? Or are the comments you had company-wide pretty consistent from price point?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, pretty consistent. There is a slower movement on the Emerald and higher price points are not seeing the same levels of activity that we're seeing in the Horton or the Express brands.
componenttext: Actually, pretty consistent. There is a slower movement on the Emerald and higher price points are not seeing the same levels of activity that we're seeing in the Horton or the Express brands.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that a rate of change comment, meaning it slowed over the last month or 2? Or is that just, generally speaking, you get lower absorptions, which, I think, would be expected?
componenttext: Is that a rate of change comment, meaning it slowed over the last month or 2? Or is that just, generally speaking, you get lower absorptions, which, I think, would be expected?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say rate of change over the last couple of quarters. I can tell you, right now, January has started off very good, so.
componenttext: I would say rate of change over the last couple of quarters. I can tell you, right now, January has started off very good, so.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of Express, just curious what you're seeing in the market and how you're managing that in terms of price points? And also, the mix of that product, it's obviously been successful, but I'm curious how you're managing that and how you're seeing the
componenttext: In terms of Express, just curious what you're seeing in the market and how you're managing that in terms of price points? And also, the mix of that product, it's obviously been successful, but I'm curious how you're managing that and how you're seeing the behavior of the first time or that homebuyer evolving in this market?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Eric, as David mentioned that we've been very pleased with the rollout of Express. We've talked to you for several quarters that the majority of that business had been in Texas, the Carolinas and Florida. That's still the case, the majority of our s
componenttext: Sure, Eric, as David mentioned that we've been very pleased with the rollout of Express. We've talked to you for several quarters that the majority of that business had been in Texas, the Carolinas and Florida. That's still the case, the majority of our sales and closings are coming out of those markets, but we're starting to see a more meaningful share from some other parts of the country. The next largest state for us actually right now is California. The majority of that's in our Southern California markets, and that is bringing our average price point for Express up. This quarter it was $199,000. So in the next quarter, more than likely, we'll be over the $200,000 mark with our Express Homes product offering that's really just due to geographic mix. And we've been very pleased with the rollout of Express in those other markets, in addition to Texas, Carolinas and Florida, where the reception still remains very strong.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of how intentionality of how the product is moving in existing markets, and I appreciate the California expansion, but is there anything that is different, either from a price or cost or efficiency standpoint that's materially different than wher
componenttext: In terms of how intentionality of how the product is moving in existing markets, and I appreciate the California expansion, but is there anything that is different, either from a price or cost or efficiency standpoint that's materially different than where it's bad or in terms of where it's going?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say pretty consistent with where it's been. And we're going to drive where it's going. So the Express program is price point-driven. So we set absorption targets and drive to that price point. So it's -- we're -- I guess the overall express progra
componenttext: I would say pretty consistent with where it's been. And we're going to drive where it's going. So the Express program is price point-driven. So we set absorption targets and drive to that price point. So it's -- we're -- I guess the overall express program has been well received and continues to exceed what we'd thought it would be when it came out.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, in terms of your expectations for price or incentives, and, obviously, you're going to wait how to see how the spring selling season develops. But can you speak a little bit to what plan A looks like in regards to that relative to 1 yea
componenttext: And then secondly, in terms of your expectations for price or incentives, and, obviously, you're going to wait how to see how the spring selling season develops. But can you speak a little bit to what plan A looks like in regards to that relative to 1 year ago?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what we're seeing with good absorption in the communities, it's taking pressure off of margins and it's giving us, in certain communities, a little bit of pricing power to reduce incentives, and that's been showing up positively in margins. We pla
componenttext: I think what we're seeing with good absorption in the communities, it's taking pressure off of margins and it's giving us, in certain communities, a little bit of pricing power to reduce incentives, and that's been showing up positively in margins. We plan to continue that. The plan A is to maintain the absorption pace that we budgeted for the year and we're seeing the market being very cooperative to that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I had was just trying to drill down a little bit across the regions from the order growth perspective during the quarter. You had, for example, some deceleration in the year-over-year order growth. I guess across the board, but more notably
componenttext: First question I had was just trying to drill down a little bit across the regions from the order growth perspective during the quarter. You had, for example, some deceleration in the year-over-year order growth.
