componenttext: In terms of Express, just curious what you're seeing in the market and how you're managing that in terms of price points? And also, the mix of that product, it's obviously been successful, but I'm curious how you're managing that and how you're seeing the behavior of the first time or that homebuyer evolving in this market?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Eric, as David mentioned that we've been very pleased with the rollout of Express. We've talked to you for several quarters that the majority of that business had been in Texas, the Carolinas and Florida. That's still the case, the majority of our s
componenttext: Sure, Eric, as David mentioned that we've been very pleased with the rollout of Express. We've talked to you for several quarters that the majority of that business had been in Texas, the Carolinas and Florida. That's still the case, the majority of our sales and closings are coming out of those markets, but we're starting to see a more meaningful share from some other parts of the country. The next largest state for us actually right now is California. The majority of that's in our Southern California markets, and that is bringing our average price point for Express up. This quarter it was $199,000. So in the next quarter, more than likely, we'll be over the $200,000 mark with our Express Homes product offering that's really just due to geographic mix. And we've been very pleased with the rollout of Express in those other markets, in addition to Texas, Carolinas and Florida, where the reception still remains very strong.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of how intentionality of how the product is moving in existing markets, and I appreciate the California expansion, but is there anything that is different, either from a price or cost or efficiency standpoint that's materially different than wher
componenttext: In terms of how intentionality of how the product is moving in existing markets, and I appreciate the California expansion, but is there anything that is different, either from a price or cost or efficiency standpoint that's materially different than where it's bad or in terms of where it's going?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say pretty consistent with where it's been. And we're going to drive where it's going. So the Express program is price point-driven. So we set absorption targets and drive to that price point. So it's -- we're -- I guess the overall express progra
componenttext: I would say pretty consistent with where it's been. And we're going to drive where it's going. So the Express program is price point-driven. So we set absorption targets and drive to that price point. So it's -- we're -- I guess the overall express program has been well received and continues to exceed what we'd thought it would be when it came out.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, in terms of your expectations for price or incentives, and, obviously, you're going to wait how to see how the spring selling season develops. But can you speak a little bit to what plan A looks like in regards to that relative to 1 yea
componenttext: And then secondly, in terms of your expectations for price or incentives, and, obviously, you're going to wait how to see how the spring selling season develops. But can you speak a little bit to what plan A looks like in regards to that relative to 1 year ago?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what we're seeing with good absorption in the communities, it's taking pressure off of margins and it's giving us, in certain communities, a little bit of pricing power to reduce incentives, and that's been showing up positively in margins. We pla
componenttext: I think what we're seeing with good absorption in the communities, it's taking pressure off of margins and it's giving us, in certain communities, a little bit of pricing power to reduce incentives, and that's been showing up positively in margins. We plan to continue that. The plan A is to maintain the absorption pace that we budgeted for the year and we're seeing the market being very cooperative to that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I had was just trying to drill down a little bit across the regions from the order growth perspective during the quarter. You had, for example, some deceleration in the year-over-year order growth. I guess across the board, but more notably
componenttext: First question I had was just trying to drill down a little bit across the regions from the order growth perspective during the quarter. You had, for example, some deceleration in the year-over-year order growth. I guess across the board, but more notably in the Southeast, still very strong at 22% growth versus -- but that was versus a stronger rate in '15. A couple of smaller regions fell off as well. So I was hoping to get any kind of color across the regions in terms of perhaps highlighting which markets right now that you might see as being stronger than others. And if there's any particular changes in community count growth that might have driven some of those regional changes quarter-to-quarter in terms of the year-over-year trend.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we saw an increase in our absorptions in every region, Mike, outside of the Midwest. The Midwest is a very small region for us and it does include Chicago, which we've pointed to for a while now as being a weaker market of ours. But otherwise, every
componenttext: Yes, we saw an increase in our absorptions in every region, Mike, outside of the Midwest. The Midwest is a very small region for us and it does include Chicago, which we've pointed to for a while now as being a weaker market of ours. But otherwise, every region in terms of sales on a year-over-year basis was up as we did see a decline in our community count in half of our regions. And as we noted already, our count -- community count was relatively flat. It was up just only slightly at about 1% on a year-over-year basis. So we're seeing a good pickup in absorptions in a majority of our markets today, I would say.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. I guess, secondly, just from the growth side, I think there's been a couple of questions previously around growth expectations and your land's been up, but kind of keeping your lot count flat and basically replacing what you're worki
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. I guess, secondly, just from the growth side, I think there's been a couple of questions previously around growth expectations and your land's been up, but kind of keeping your lot count flat and basically replacing what you're working through. Just thinking at the same time, you're expecting, I believe you said, double-digit growth. Correct me if I'm wrong, that's your goal over the next 2 or 3 years. So how are you -- at least from a revenue or order growth standpoint, now with community count flattish for 3 quarters, maybe for another couple of quarters here, is growth something that would be reinfused into the strategy as we think about fiscal '17 and '18? Obviously, you're also creating a lot of dry powder here, building up the cash or paying down some debt incrementally. And it seems like there's a little bit of a one foot on the pedal or halfway on the gas pedal, whereas, again, you're still well below midcycle levels as an industry. So any thoughts around, perhaps, a re-acceleration of our community count growth as we look into '17 or '18?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're looking for -- to continue to aggregate market share market-by-market. I think we're looking at double-digit growth year-over-year and profit sales, then closings. So it's -- we've got what we believe is a sustainable program. And the fact t
componenttext: I think we're looking for -- to continue to aggregate market share market-by-market. I think we're looking at double-digit growth year-over-year and profit sales, then closings. So it's -- we've got what we believe is a sustainable program. And the fact that we're generating cash and improving our balance sheet while gaining efficiency, is just going to open a lot of opportunity for us down the road.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And growth is a core part of that strategy. Growth at a double-digit pace is a core part of that strategy, but it is a balanced strategy. Our guidance for this year, in terms of top line revenue, equates to an 11% to 15% annual increase. Our closings guid
componenttext: And growth is a core part of that strategy. Growth at a double-digit pace is a core part of that strategy, but it is a balanced strategy. Our guidance for this year, in terms of top line revenue, equates to an 11% to 15% annual increase. Our closings guidance for the year equates to an 8% to 13% increase. And so our expectations this year are to be in the low double-digit range, which, from our perspective, is solid growth and in line with our expectations in this quarter with our sales pace. It's in the range of our expectations for the year and certainly puts us in position to continue consistent growth. Our investment levels, we think we've done a lot growth the last couple of years from absorption improvements, with the Express roll out, while our average community count has moderated. Our expectations this year, while we'll still see absorption improvements, it will be quite at the pace that was in prior years, but we still expect solid absorption improvements. And then certainly, going forward, when we achieve a much better level of efficiency than perhaps in future growth when a double-digit pace may come from some further community count growth. But today and for this year, we expect low -- flat to low single-digits community count growth with improved absorptions to drive a double-digit revenue growth.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Bill. And I think just maybe to press that further, that concept in terms of the shift between community count and absorption that's occurred in the last 6, 8 quarters. This year, again, it looks like perhaps a high single-digit or so, per
componenttext: That's helpful, Bill. And I think just maybe to press that further, that concept in terms of the shift between community count and absorption that's occurred in the last 6, 8 quarters. This year, again, it looks like perhaps a high single-digit or so, perhaps low double-digit absorption growth, with more flattish community count. To the extent that you're coming -- that, that growth would continue to moderate perhaps due to the mix shift more fully playing out from the Express standpoint, to the extent that you're expecting double-digit growth in '17, it would imply, to the extent that the absorption continues to moderate, some re-acceleration in community count. Is that fair?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe that's fair. Yes.
componenttext: I believe that's fair. Yes.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair.
componenttext: Fair.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question today is coming from Ken Zener from KeyBanc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question today is coming from Ken Zener from KeyBanc.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk about this 60% of your buyers that are not first time. Obviously, it appears that there was volatility on the existing-home-sales number in December some of that mortgage related, but it does seem that things are decelerating a
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk about this 60% of your buyers that are not first time. Obviously, it appears that there was volatility on the existing-home-sales number in December some of that mortgage related, but it does seem that things are decelerating a little bit on the existing side. Is there anything that would cause you concern? Or, David, Bill, could you kind of talk about what a gumming up of that existing side might look like and how that might concern you? I know, obviously, Houston is starting to see rising inventory of existing and slowing existing sales. Have you started seeing in any of the market issues with people not being able to sell their houses or anything because that was a big part of the market last time when it started to slow down.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll tell you, Ken, we're not seeing that in the markets we're operating in. The resale market is still relatively strong, with continuing positive signs. So I mean, our inventory turns are improving. Our absorption per flag are improving. We're stable an
componenttext: I'll tell you, Ken, we're not seeing that in the markets we're operating in. The resale market is still relatively strong, with continuing positive signs. So I mean, our inventory turns are improving. Our absorption per flag are improving. We're stable and, in some cases, improving margins. So we feel very good about the market right now and are not seeing, other than, obviously, Houston is slow, but the balance of our markets are doing very, very well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then if I could ask about California, where you did highlight your -- some Express product. Jessica, you talked about it lifting your ASP, and it also, as it relates to any of your other product, what percent of those homes do you believe are going to
componenttext: And then if I could ask about California, where you did highlight your -- some Express product. Jessica, you talked about it lifting your ASP, and it also, as it relates to any of your other product, what percent of those homes do you believe are going to or towards investors, be it, if you can split it out domestic and/or international?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have exact breakdown of the investors. Anecdotally, I would tell you it's very low. What we're hearing about any investors sales. A lot of it is just people that are moving out of a rental situation into a home that they can afford.
componenttext: We don't have exact breakdown of the investors. Anecdotally, I would tell you it's very low. What we're hearing about any investors sales. A lot of it is just people that are moving out of a rental situation into a home that they can afford.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall from RBC.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall from RBC.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Did you guys get any help with the December weather? Did that extend the construction season and assist the deliveries in 4Q?
componenttext: Did you guys get any help with the December weather? Did that extend the construction season and assist the deliveries in 4Q?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had real weather in the fourth quarter in a couple of our bigger markets across the Carolinas and Dallas/Fort Worth [ph]. But as Mike points out, we have weather every quarter. So would our numbers have better with typical weather? Yes, they would have
componenttext: We had real weather in the fourth quarter in a couple of our bigger markets across the Carolinas and Dallas/Fort Worth [ph]. But as Mike points out, we have weather every quarter. So would our numbers have better with typical weather? Yes, they would have been. But we're very happy with the numbers we've posted and think we're going to have a great year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sounds like it's a fast year to start. ASP was up 3.3% and average price growth of 2.7% on the new order side. And you're talking about maintaining a 19.5% to a 20% gross margin. I'm just trying to get a better picture of how to think about price as being
componenttext: Sounds like it's a fast year to start. ASP was up 3.3% and average price growth of 2.7% on the new order side. And you're talking about maintaining a 19.5% to a 20% gross margin. I'm just trying to get a better picture of how to think about price as being low single-digit, what you're seeing on the labor cost side and if you're experiencing any delays due to labor bottlenecks and if that's been resolved? How -- what's really giving you the confidence to reiterate your guidance for a very solid margin performance this year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the confidence is coming from being in touch with the operators out in the divisions and what they sense and what they feel is taking place in their markets. And across the board, our people feel very good about what's happening out there. The lab
componenttext: I think the confidence is coming from being in touch with the operators out in the divisions and what they sense and what they feel is taking place in their markets. And across the board, our people feel very good about what's happening out there. The labor side, I would say, it's still stressed but seems to be improving. And the trade bases are starting to add people. I think a big part of the improvement we're seeing is, the consistency in production in the community-by-community is allowing these rates to stay up and maintain a workforce to hit those numbers. And it's taken a while to get there, but they are adding people. I think our trade base is seeing -- is becoming more and more confident as well. So.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Bob, in terms of what we saw in price changes, our revenues per square foot outpaced our stick and brick per square foot on a year-over-year basis for the second time, so we've gotten to where that's in check. Sequentially, that was essentially net n
componenttext: And, Bob, in terms of what we saw in price changes, our revenues per square foot outpaced our stick and brick per square foot on a year-over-year basis for the second time, so we've gotten to where that's in check. Sequentially, that was essentially net neutral. So you saw our margins tick up by 10 basis points year-over-year and stayed flat from Q4 to Q1, we are continuing to experience higher loan costs, but in about the same range year-over-year as we were last quarter, so flat gross margin.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me ask you, Jessica, just on that point, are you really getting priced or is the driver really a reflection of the stronger mix with a bias towards the West Coast?
componenttext: And let me ask you, Jessica, just on that point, are you really getting priced or is the driver really a reflection of the stronger mix with a bias towards the West Coast?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're actually getting price. If we look at our price per square foot, which is the best way we can try to look at our business apples-to-apples, we did see a low single-digit increase.
componenttext: We're actually getting price. If we look at our price per square foot, which is the best way we can try to look at our business apples-to-apples, we did see a low single-digit increase.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And if I can sneak one final in. Can you just like a way to think about Houston versus Dallas in the sense that it sounds like Dallas is very strong. You said Houston is soft. How do we think about that? Is there any more of a book end you can giv
componenttext: Got it. And if I can sneak one final in. Can you just like a way to think about Houston versus Dallas in the sense that it sounds like Dallas is very strong. You said Houston is soft. How do we think about that? Is there any more of a book end you can give us?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will tell you, Bob, I spent a week driving Dallas and a week driving Fort Worth in January. And when I got back, I told Horton I had to get out of the field because if I stayed in Dallas and Fort Worth, I would become way too aggressive buying land. It
componenttext: I will tell you, Bob, I spent a week driving Dallas and a week driving Fort Worth in January. And when I got back, I told Horton I had to get out of the field because if I stayed in Dallas and Fort Worth, I would become way too aggressive buying land. It is as good a market as I have seen. And as for Houston, I think there's a lot of conversation, a lot of uncertainty, a lot of volatility within the oil and gas business, which I think is making people more conservative about buying homes. I think there's still pent-up demand in Houston. I think that pent-up demand is growing, but it is just not the frenzy what we've seen in the past or is really taking place in some other Texas markets.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from the line of James McCanless from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from the line of James McCanless from Sterne Agee.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could, maybe I can touch on the labor issue. I think some people are concerned about would there be enough labor to make the number of closings in the back half of the year that your guidance suggests.  Could you talk -- I mean, when you talk about l
componenttext: If I could, maybe I can touch on the labor issue. I think some people are concerned about would there be enough labor to make the number of closings in the back half of the year that your guidance suggests.  Could you talk -- I mean, when you talk about labor getting better and the subs adding more people, is it across-the-board? Or is it just in specific market versus specific areas like framing, et cetera?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's pretty much across the board. I mean, we're seeing the construction labor force increase. And I think our strive to create more efficiency in the process of building and selling homes and trying to actually take some labor out of a per-square-foot co
componenttext: It's pretty much across the board. I mean, we're seeing the construction labor force increase. And I think our strive to create more efficiency in the process of building and selling homes and trying to actually take some labor out of a per-square-foot cost of a home has paid off. And our trades are making money and we're seeing less pressure on the cost side. And I think providing more value for the customer. So we feel like we are positioned to deliver our year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then the second question I had on Express, could you just update us on how many markets you ultimately want to go to with that product? And how far along you think you are in that process?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then the second question I had on Express, could you just update us on how many markets you ultimately want to go to with that product? And how far along you think you are in that process?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, I think there are -- probably we're in 78 markets. We probably will end up mid-60s, primarily because some markets just don't -- we -- don't allow you to dual-market your product and we're not going to give up the Horton brand to sell Express. We have
componenttext: Oh, I think there are -- probably we're in 78 markets. We probably will end up mid-60s, primarily because some markets just don't -- we -- don't allow you to dual-market your product and we're not going to give up the Horton brand to sell Express. We have a lot of opportunities still to increase our position within most of the markets and are actively out there looking every day to do that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And how far along do you think you are in that process?
componenttext: Okay. And how far along do you think you are in that process?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe halfway.
componenttext: Maybe halfway.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're in 48 markets in 15 states today. But to echo David's comments, we haven't thoroughly saturated the markets that we're currently in with Express. So there's more runway within those 48 plus expanding to the mid-60s.
componenttext: We're in 48 markets in 15 states today. But to echo David's comments, we haven't thoroughly saturated the markets that we're currently in with Express. So there's more runway within those 48 plus expanding to the mid-60s.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we're allocating capital to the programs that are driving the best returns. And right now, Express is driving the great returns.
componenttext: I mean, we're allocating capital to the programs that are driving the best returns. And right now, Express is driving the great returns.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, if we could go back and put a finer point on the Texas discussion, it sounds like Dallas is clearly very strong. And if I look at your South Central trends overall, up 7% in orders, Dallas presumably outpacing that by a decent degree. So Houston, c
componenttext: David, if we could go back and put a finer point on the Texas discussion, it sounds like Dallas is clearly very strong. And if I look at your South Central trends overall, up 7% in orders, Dallas presumably outpacing that by a decent degree. So Houston, can you give us a ballpark around year-over-year what Houston's doing? And we've heard some other builders talk about the weakness extending down to the $250,000 price point. I know you said earlier you put up -- if you can put up a home at $250,000, you can sell it. But is there just any additional color on trends that across the price segmentation within your Houston business that you can provide?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Houston has been relatively stable for us on a year-over-year basis. So we didn't see a further slowdown in Houston, but we're also not seeing any meaningful pickup. We continue to see our lower-priced Express homes, very steady demands, steady sales pace
componenttext: Houston has been relatively stable for us on a year-over-year basis. So we didn't see a further slowdown in Houston, but we're also not seeing any meaningful pickup. We continue to see our lower-priced Express homes, very steady demands, steady sales pace. But as has been mentioned a couple of times on the call, definitely softer at the higher end. But we continue to see good, steady demand for the entry-level and people moving out of apartments, where we're providing an attractive rent versus buy equation and driving people into the sales offices each week. So we continue to have a close eye on Houston. We're not heavily reinvesting in Houston right now. We are replenishing where it makes sense and where we can continue to add those entry-level product offerings.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, just to add a little more color. We have some what I would call A+ project location positions in Houston that are maybe at the price point that we're seeing less demand for. And we are not going to accelerate or liquidate those positions. So we will
componenttext: Mike, just to add a little more color. We have some what I would call A+ project location positions in Houston that are maybe at the price point that we're seeing less demand for. And we are not going to accelerate or liquidate those positions. So we will see lower absorptions in those communities and these are -- they're communities we can't -- don't replace and don't want to. So it's -- we're going to protect the value in our core projects, take absorption at the $250,000 to $300,000 range. And if you're looking at what I look at, almost 0 margin deterioration on the projects that are at the price point that are turning right now. And we don't need nor do we want to force a sales in a core project where we have been selling $350,000 to $450,000 and are just seeing our absorptions reduce. So that's my color on Houston. I think it's going to be a tremendous market for us for a long time.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just a follow-up on that last point. As you take a step back and say, look, there's too much value in some of these A+ locations to give them away, we have heard increased chatter in terms of that competitors are starting to cut prices or pick up
componenttext: I guess just a follow-up on that last point. As you take a step back and say, look, there's too much value in some of these A+ locations to give them away, we have heard increased chatter in terms of that competitors are starting to cut prices or pick up incentives. So how much of it is related to the market is trading away from you and you're not chasing it, but the market has moved on price.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are very strong in the 2 -- I mean, we dominate the $250,000 to $300,000 -- $200,000 to $300,000 price point at Houston and we're going to continue to dominate that. And if you look at our -- the benefit -- one of the many benefits of being D.R. Horton
componenttext: We are very strong in the 2 -- I mean, we dominate the $250,000 to $300,000 -- $200,000 to $300,000 price point at Houston and we're going to continue to dominate that. And if you look at our -- the benefit -- one of the many benefits of being D.R. Horton is the broad geographic footprint. When the upper end in Houston slows down, the entry-level in Denver accelerates. So -- I mean, it's -- we have a lot of levers to pull, my consistent comment to the people inside the company is it's good to be us because we can hit our plan. And without being forced to sell a project we don't want to sell at the pace that it's been running at.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That is helpful and it's a good position to be in. If I could shift gears to another earlier discussion around community count and absorptions and just as it relates to the guide, I think you mentioned unit delivery is up 8% to 13%. If we look at
componenttext: Got it. That is helpful and it's a good position to be in. If I could shift gears to another earlier discussion around community count and absorptions and just as it relates to the guide, I think you mentioned unit delivery is up 8% to 13%. If we look at the orders, it seems like absorption is up about 8%. How much of the delta between hitting the low end versus the high end of the units will come from increasing your absorption beyond that 8% on a year-over-year basis versus getting more community -- communities open and getting that community count up into a low- to mid-single digit range by the end of the year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're pretty much running on our absorption targets. So I think we will, as we continue to push out the Express brand and follow up replacing the Horton positions, I think we will see some community count grow. We don't have visibility in that today. We d
componenttext: We're pretty much running on our absorption targets. So I think we will, as we continue to push out the Express brand and follow up replacing the Horton positions, I think we will see some community count grow. We don't have visibility in that today. We do have visibility in what we know we can deliver, so.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to know exactly where the contributions are sitting here in January, not knowing what the spring is going to hold. We're certainly seeing good early signs, but clearly, the strength of the spring selling season will help determine our year, it w
componenttext: It's hard to know exactly where the contributions are sitting here in January, not knowing what the spring is going to hold. We're certainly seeing good early signs, but clearly, the strength of the spring selling season will help determine our year, it will determine where we land in our range or whether we could perhaps exceed our range. And so sitting here in January, feeling good and feel good about our position, our preparations for the spring, and then we'll go try to execute as best we can over the next few months. And we'll know a whole lot more when we talk to you next quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Will Randow from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Will Randow from Citigroup.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was curious on the implementation of the know-before-you-owe on credit, if you will, for you guys, how that looked like? How do you feel about, I guess for lack of a better term, the complexity as well as days that's added to closings. And if you can ju
componenttext: I was curious on the implementation of the know-before-you-owe on credit, if you will, for you guys, how that looked like? How do you feel about, I guess for lack of a better term, the complexity as well as days that's added to closings. And if you can just share some color there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really haven't seen an appreciable impact in the delay in closings. Our team have worked very hard to prepare for the changing rules and worked with our captive mortgage company. DHI Mortgage's folks have done a yeoman's job preparing for this change a
componenttext: We really haven't seen an appreciable impact in the delay in closings. Our team have worked very hard to prepare for the changing rules and worked with our captive mortgage company. DHI Mortgage's folks have done a yeoman's job preparing for this change as well as working with our preferred lenders. So we really didn't see a material impact on our closings for the quarter. We'll continue to improve our processes and try to become more efficient and make it a good experience for the buyers.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up, as talked about a few times during Q&A, but on labor inflation, I think you guys are running at 2% or 3% in the prior reported quarter, while some of your competitors out there are running closer to 10%. Have you seen more in
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up, as talked about a few times during Q&A, but on labor inflation, I think you guys are running at 2% or 3% in the prior reported quarter, while some of your competitors out there are running closer to 10%. Have you seen more inflation? And has that been different for specs versus the total company?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the labor side has been minimized for us because we set absorption targets per community and drive to that, so we have consistency within the communities. And our trades are not out there looking for work one week and then add twice what they can
componenttext: I think the labor side has been minimized for us because we set absorption targets per community and drive to that, so we have consistency within the communities. And our trades are not out there looking for work one week and then add twice what they can do the next.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we are still just running a low single-digit percentage increase on cost per square foot. Stick and brick.
componenttext: And we are still just running a low single-digit percentage increase on cost per square foot. Stick and brick.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from John Lovallo from Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from John Lovallo from Merrill Lynch.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on the financial services margin. We have it at about 16%, I think, in the quarter versus a guide of 30% to 33%. Now, was there any trade-related expenses kind of lumped in there in the quarter?
componenttext: First question is on the financial services margin. We have it at about 16%, I think, in the quarter versus a guide of 30% to 33%. Now, was there any trade-related expenses kind of lumped in there in the quarter?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no doubt. The -- to be prepared for the new regulations, our mortgage company financial services operation had to make significant investments primarily in personnel. The effort to comply is a big one. And in order to meet those regulations and provi
componenttext: Yes, no doubt. The -- to be prepared for the new regulations, our mortgage company financial services operation had to make significant investments primarily in personnel. The effort to comply is a big one. And in order to meet those regulations and provide that experience to the homebuyers, they've had to increase costs there. Typically, those season on a -- from a seasonal basis, we see our lower operating margins in our first and second quarters and our lower-volume quarters. And then we typically see higher-than-average operating margins in financial services in Q3 and Q4. And so the margin here this quarter in the low 20s certainly does not preclude achieving the 30% to 33% guidance for the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then the one follow-up would be, realizing that weather is an issue every quarter somewhere, the recent weather we've had on the East Coast is -- has been pretty serious, particularly in areas like Carolina that are used to havin
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then the one follow-up would be, realizing that weather is an issue every quarter somewhere, the recent weather we've had on the East Coast is -- has been pretty serious, particularly in areas like Carolina that are used to having that kind of impact. So, I mean, are you guys anticipating any trouble in the coming quarter due to the storm?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly do appreciated it hasn't been a serious storm that's impacted a lot of people, but we feel it's fortunate it's early in our quarter and our operating teams will be able to take care of our existing homeowners in the communities and deal with the
componenttext: Certainly do appreciated it hasn't been a serious storm that's impacted a lot of people, but we feel it's fortunate it's early in our quarter and our operating teams will be able to take care of our existing homeowners in the communities and deal with the homes that are in backlog and the specs that are out there today, and be ready for sales next week end.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You have talked frequently about how you're just not seeing a lot of competition coming in to the sort of first-time Express kind of price point. What do you think is the biggest factor that would have to change, either from an operating kind of industry
componenttext: You have talked frequently about how you're just not seeing a lot of competition coming in to the sort of first-time Express kind of price point. What do you think is the biggest factor that would have to change, either from an operating kind of industry perspective or from a macro perspective that would finally push some of those peers to maybe perhaps come in and kind of create a bit more competition for you there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a hard enough time managing our people. I don't want to get in to trying to help them help themselves. So I don't know. All we do is get up every day and operate and pursue to be the best we can be. We're tough competition. Maybe they just -
componenttext: Well, we have a hard enough time managing our people. I don't want to get in to trying to help them help themselves. So I don't know. All we do is get up every day and operate and pursue to be the best we can be. We're tough competition. Maybe they just -- yes, I don't know.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But entry-level housing is something we've done for a very long time. It's a core competency of our business. And with our footprint and with that competency among our operating teams across the country, it's something that we've -- we got a lot to practi
componenttext: But entry-level housing is something we've done for a very long time. It's a core competency of our business. And with our footprint and with that competency among our operating teams across the country, it's something that we've -- we got a lot to practice at. So it's something we're focused on. Like we said earlier, it's a good market and there's a lot of demand there, we do expect some more competition down the line. And I think that'll be a natural next step in the cycle.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will say, we were first movers and we were aggressive first movers. And I would believe that the other companies that are also good at driving value will be following us in it. But then we've bought the lion's share of the finished lots. And when we saw
componenttext: I will say, we were first movers and we were aggressive first movers. And I would believe that the other companies that are also good at driving value will be following us in it. But then we've bought the lion's share of the finished lots. And when we saw the success, we started the investment. We have taken a development developing lots. So we just had a head start. I'm sure they're coming.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just follow up on trade. Obviously, you guys has done great job in rolling that out. But as we do get into the spring and start to just see overall activity levels increase, do you see anything out there that perhaps could start to trip thi
componenttext: Okay. And then just follow up on trade. Obviously, you guys has done great job in rolling that out. But as we do get into the spring and start to just see overall activity levels increase, do you see anything out there that perhaps could start to trip things up at all?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The area that we've watched the most closely, that we have less visibility to are the closings with outside lenders. Obviously, our internal mortgage company are captive closing, so we have more visibility in that process and feel confident about that. Bu
componenttext: The area that we've watched the most closely, that we have less visibility to are the closings with outside lenders. Obviously, our internal mortgage company are captive closing, so we have more visibility in that process and feel confident about that. But with outside lenders, it's something we watch closely, division by division or if they have relationships with outside lenders, they're working with them to make sure that we have the visibility to hit things on time, but I think that's where the greater risk is. But I honestly think month-by-month as everyone in the process gets more used to it, I think it will get smoother. And any disruption that may have occurred thus far I think will be alleviated over the coming months.
