headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call of D.R. Horton, America’s Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to i
componenttext:
Greetings and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call of D.R. Horton, America’s Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Jessica Hansen, Vice President of Investor Relations for D.R. Horton. Please go ahead.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our results for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securitie
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our results for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. 
Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there is no assurance that actual outcomes will not be materially different. All forward-looking statements are based upon information available to D.R. Horton on the date of this conference call and D.R. Horton does not undertake any obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. Additional information about issues that could lead to material changes in performance is contained in D.R. Horton's Annual Report on Form 10-K and our most recently quarterly report on Form 10-Q, both of which are filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. For your convenience, this morning's earnings release can be found on our website at investor.drhorton.com and we plan to file our 10-Q in next week. 
After the conclusion of the call, we will post updated supplementary historical data through our Investor Relations site on the presentations sections, under news and events for your reference. The supplementary information includes historical data on our homebuilding return on inventory, gross margins, changes in active selling commodities, product mix and our mortgage operations. 
Now, I will turn the call over to David Auld, our President and CEO.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jessica, and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I'm pleased to be joined on this call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.The sp
componenttext:
Thank you, Jessica, and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I'm pleased to be joined on this call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
The spring selling season that D.R. Horton has unfold swing and our team delivered a -- set a strong second quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased to $301 million, on $2.8 billion of revenue. And our pretax profit margin improved 130 basis points to 10.9%. Our homes sold increased 10% compared to the second quarter of 2015, driven by improving absorptions. These results continue to reflect the consistent, solid performance of our core D.R. Horton communities and our Emerald Homes and Express Homes brand. We're striving to be the leading builder in each of our markets and continue to expand our industry-leading market share. We plan to maintain broad product diversity with our 3 brands over the long term. Our continued strategic focus is to produce double-digit annual growth in both our revenue and pretax profits, while generating positive cash flows and increasing returns.
During the 6-months ended March, we generated $27 million cash from operations, on-track to meet our target of $300 million to $500 million of positive cash flows for the year. Our return on inventory, defined as homebuilding pretax income divided by average inventory improved to 13.8% for the 12-months, up from 10.7% a year ago. With a sales backlog of 13,695 homes at the end of March and a well stock supply of land, lots and homes, we are well-positioned for the remainder of 2016. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Net income for the second quarter increased 32% to $195 million or $0.52 per diluted share compared to $148 million or $0.40 per diluted share in the year-ago quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 31% to $301 million in the second quarter comp
componenttext: Net income for the second quarter increased 32% to $195 million or $0.52 per diluted share compared to $148 million or $0.40 per diluted share in the year-ago quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 31% to $301 million in the second quarter compared to $230 million in the year ago quarter. And homebuilding pretax income increased 36% to $283 million compared to $209 million in the prior year quarter. Our second quarter home sales revenues increased 16% to $2.7 billion on 9,262 homes closed, up from $2.3 billion on 8,243 ohms closed in the year ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was $290,000, up 3% compared to the prior year and flat sequentially from our first quarter. This quarter, entry level homes marketed under our Express Homes brands accounted for 23% of homes closed and 16% of home sales revenue. Our homes for higher-end move up and luxury buyers, created $500,000 accounted for 7% of our homes closed and 17% of our home sales revenue. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The value of our net sales orders in the second quarter increased 13% from the year-ago quarter to $3.6 billion and homes sold increased 10% to 12,292 homes on a relatively flat active selling community count. Our average sales price on net sales orders i
componenttext: The value of our net sales orders in the second quarter increased 13% from the year-ago quarter to $3.6 billion and homes sold increased 10% to 12,292 homes on a relatively flat active selling community count. Our average sales price on net sales orders in the second quarter was $290,900. The cancellation rate for the second quarter was 19%, consistent with the year ago quarter. The value of our backlog increased 14% from a year ago to $4.1 million, with an average sales price per home of $296,700 and homes in backlog increased 12% to 13,695 homes. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue for second quarter was 19.9%, consistent with the first quarter and up 20 basis point from second quarter last year. The consistency in our gross margin reflects the stability of most of our markets today. We'
componenttext:
Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue for second quarter was 19.9%, consistent with the first quarter and up 20 basis point from second quarter last year. The consistency in our gross margin reflects the stability of most of our markets today. We're raising prices, while reducing incentives when possible in communities where we are achieving our targeted absorptions. And we're also working to control cost increases. Our general gross margin expectations remain unchanged. In the current housing market, we continue to expect our average home sales gross margin to generally be around 20%, with quarterly fluctuations that may range from 19% to 21%, due to product and geographic mix and the relative impact of warranty and interest cost.
As a reminder, our reported gross margins include all of our interest costs. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the second quarter, home building SG&A was $258 million compared to $242 million in the prior-year quarter. As a percentage of homebuilding revenue, SG&A improved 80 basis points to 9.6% compared to 10.4% in the prior-year quarter. As our revenue incre
componenttext: In the second quarter, home building SG&A was $258 million compared to $242 million in the prior-year quarter. As a percentage of homebuilding revenue, SG&A improved 80 basis points to 9.6% compared to 10.4% in the prior-year quarter. As our revenue increase improved our leverage offered cost. We remained focused on controlling our SG&A, while ensuring that our infrastructure adequately supports our current and expected growth. Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Financial services pretax income in the second quarter was $17.4 million compared to $21.5 million in the year-ago quarter. 94% of our mortgage companies loan originations during the quarter related to homes closed by our home building operations and our
componenttext:
Financial services pretax income in the second quarter was $17.4 million compared to $21.5 million in the year-ago quarter. 94% of our mortgage companies loan originations during the quarter related to homes closed by our home building operations and our mortgage company handled the financing for 53% of our home buyers. FHA and VA 1 accounted for 48% of the mortgage company's volume compared to 45% in the year-ago quarter.
Borrowers originating loan with our mortgage company this quarter, have an average FICO score of 717 and average loan-to-value ratio of 88%. First-time homebuyers represented 45% at the closing, handled by our mortgage company compared to 43% in the second quarter last year. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At the end of March, we had 24,600 homes in inventory, of which 1,600 were 11,700 of our total homes respect homes with 8,400 in various stages of construction and 3,300 completed. Our construction in progress and finished homes inventory increased by $36
componenttext:
At the end of March, we had 24,600 homes in inventory, of which 1,600 were 11,700 of our total homes respect homes with 8,400 in various stages of construction and 3,300 completed. Our construction in progress and finished homes inventory increased by $361 million during the quarter, due to seasonal construction activity for the spring selling season. Our second quarter investments in lots, lands and development totaled $500 million, of which $271 million was to replenish finished lots and lands and $229 million was for land development.
We expect our investments in land and development to increase in the third and fourth quarters compared to the second quarter this year. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At March 31, 2016, our land and lot portfolio consisted of 189,000 lots, of which 112,000 are owned and 77,000 are controlled through option contracts. 69,000 of our total lots are finished, of which 31,000 are owned and 38,000 are auctioned. Our 189,000
componenttext:
At March 31, 2016, our land and lot portfolio consisted of 189,000 lots, of which 112,000 are owned and 77,000 are controlled through option contracts. 69,000 of our total lots are finished, of which 31,000 are owned and 38,000 are auctioned. Our 189,000 total lots owned and controlled provide us a strong competitive advantage in the current housing market, with a sufficient lots supply to support solid growth in sales and closings in future periods. Although our housing inventories will fluctuate, as we manage each of our committees to optimize returns, we expect our land and lot inventories to remained relatively stable in 2016.
We also expect to generate positive cash flows from operations for the second consecutive year, through increased profitability and disciplined inventory management. During the 6-months ended March, we generated $27 million of operating cash, an improvement of $196 million compared to the same period last year. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: During the second quarter, we recorded $2.8 million in land auction charges for write-offs, money deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded a $3.2 million inventory impairment charge in our east region
componenttext: During the second quarter, we recorded $2.8 million in land auction charges for write-offs, money deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded a $3.2 million inventory impairment charge in our east region related to a long-held inactive land parcel that we sold during the quarter. We will continue to evaluate our inventories for potential impairment, which may result in future charges, but the timing and magnitude of these charges will fluctuate. Our inactive land helped the development of $194 million at the end of the quarter, represents 10,100 lots, down 22% from a year ago. We continue to work through each of our remaining inactive land parcels to improve cash flows and returns and we expect that our land held for development will continue to decline. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At March 31, our homebuilding liquidity include $1.2 billion unrestricted homebuilding cash and $884 million of available capacity on our revolving credit facility. Our gross homebuilding leverage ratio improved 580 basis points from year ago to 33.6%. De
componenttext: At March 31, our homebuilding liquidity include $1.2 billion unrestricted homebuilding cash and $884 million of available capacity on our revolving credit facility. Our gross homebuilding leverage ratio improved 580 basis points from year ago to 33.6%. Developments of our public notes outstanding at March 31 was $3.2 billion. On April 15, we repaid $373 million of senior notes at their maturity and we have no debt maturities in the next 12 months. At March 31, first shareholders equity was $6.2 billion and book value per share was $16.85, up 14% from year ago. Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are updating our expectations for fiscal 26 in profitability, based on current housing market conditions and our financial performance to date this year. As we noted in our press release this morning, we are increasing our annual guidance for consolida
componenttext:
We are updating our expectations for fiscal 26 in profitability, based on current housing market conditions and our financial performance to date this year. As we noted in our press release this morning, we are increasing our annual guidance for consolidated pretax profit margin by 20 basis points through a range of 10.7% to 11.2% for fiscal 2016. We are also updating our annual guidance for home building SG&A through a range of 9% to 9.2% of homebuilding revenues from the previous range of 9.2% to 9.4%. Also as outlined in our press release this morning, we are reaffirming our previously issued guidance for fiscal 2016 as follows: consolidated revenues of between $12 billion and $12.5 billion; homes closed between 39,500 and 41,500 homes; our home sales gross margin for the full year of 2016 in high 19s to 20%; and annual financial services pretax profit margin of 30% to 33%; and income tax rate for the full year of between 35% and 36%; and annual diluted share count of approximately 375 million shares; and $300 million to $500 million of positive cash flow from operations for fiscal 2016.
Specifically, for the third quarter of fiscal 2016, we expect our number of homes closed will approximate beginning backlog conversion rate in a range of 76% to 80%. We anticipate our third quarter home sold gross margin will be in the high 19s to 20%, consistent with the first half of the year and we expect our homebuilding SG&A in the third quarter to be in the range of 8.9% to 9.1% at homebuilding revenues. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In closing, our second quarter growth in sales, closings and profits and the improvement in our pretax profit margin was a result of the strength of our people and our operating platform. We remained excited and are looking forward to the opportunities ah
componenttext:
In closing, our second quarter growth in sales, closings and profits and the improvement in our pretax profit margin was a result of the strength of our people and our operating platform. We remained excited and are looking forward to the opportunities ahead. We remain focused on growing both our revenue and pretax profits at a double-digit annual pace, while continue to generate positive cash flows and improve returns.
We are well-positioned to do so, with our solid balance sheet, industry-leading market share, broad geographic footprint, diversified product offerings across our D.R. Horton, Emerald and Express brands, attractive finished lot and land position, and most importantly, our tremendous team across country. We would like to thank our entire D.R. Horton team for their continued hard work and we look forward to working together to continue growing and improving our operation. Let's keep the momentum going week-by-week, fly-by-fly, throughout this year. This concludes our prepared remarks. We will now host questions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from Steve from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from Steve from Evercore ISI.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Paul on for Stephen. I'm impressed with the first half cash flow generation, given that's typically a period of heavy spend. What's the sustainability of that going out? I know you're looking for $300 million to $500 million for the year,
componenttext: This is actually Paul on for Stephen. I'm impressed with the first half cash flow generation, given that's typically a period of heavy spend. What's the sustainability of that going out? I know you're looking for $300 million to $500 million for the year, but should we expect first half cash generation in out years?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's hard to say in future years, Paul. For this year, we are on track, based on our current plans for fiscal 2016 to generate $300 million to $500 million for the full year. We would not be surprised if in Q3 we used cash, because we are building out o
componenttext: That's hard to say in future years, Paul. For this year, we are on track, based on our current plans for fiscal 2016 to generate $300 million to $500 million for the full year. We would not be surprised if in Q3 we used cash, because we are building out our backlog, building out our homes and construction. And as we stated, we do expect our land and lot inventory -- investments to be higher in Q3 and Q4 than it was this quarter, but we are on track for $300 million to $500 million. And our expectations for future years is our business model is designed to continue to generate positive cash flows from operations, while growing at a double-digit pace. And exactly what level it might be each year, we will determine as we get the better visibility into the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up, I've heard rumblings that you're looking at expanding not so much the Express name, but the express business model to higher price points, I mean basically everything is included, do you have any color on that?
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up, I've heard rumblings that you're looking at expanding not so much the Express name, but the express business model to higher price points, I mean basically everything is included, do you have any color on that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're learning a lot with the Express rollout that efficiency and value is a big-time driver in sales. And yes, I mean, as we create operational efficiencies in express that translate into D.R. Horton, we're moving that way. We will always be a loca
componenttext: Well, we're learning a lot with the Express rollout that efficiency and value is a big-time driver in sales. And yes, I mean, as we create operational efficiencies in express that translate into D.R. Horton, we're moving that way. We will always be a locally controlled business, I mean, we are decentralized. Our operators in the field will respond to the market. And if it is a value-based market, they're going to have to drive more efficient homes. If it is a custom-based platform, then we're going to continue to modify plans and introduce plans at the local level.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is coming from Ken Zener with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question is coming from Ken Zener with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder -- not to get specific into particular markets, but it's useful to the Express Homes. I think you guys have opened up 5 or 6 new express communities, can you talk about the trend that you're seeing in Denver, the existing home sales tightened up
componenttext: I wonder -- not to get specific into particular markets, but it's useful to the Express Homes. I think you guys have opened up 5 or 6 new express communities, can you talk about the trend that you're seeing in Denver, the existing home sales tightened up there, either due to lack of supply -- I mean, you guys seem to be growing while others have not seen that type of acceleration. Could you kind of give us a little market dynamic on how that market and that product is working?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we opened up Express in Denver over the past year. The team up there has done a great job getting that online. And it shows that there is a real need for affordable housing in that market, and we're delivering a value product to the market and it'
componenttext: I think we opened up Express in Denver over the past year. The team up there has done a great job getting that online. And it shows that there is a real need for affordable housing in that market, and we're delivering a value product to the market and it's just being absorbed and people are very happy with it. We're very happy we can do it and looking forward to try to do more of it.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Kenneth, it's kind of consistent with what we've seeing in the the market. Lot of pent-up demand, absorptions have come in higher than we expected. So it's a powerful tool in what we are accomplishing.
componenttext: And Kenneth, it's kind of consistent with what we've seeing in the the market. Lot of pent-up demand, absorptions have come in higher than we expected. So it's a powerful tool in what we are accomplishing.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, Ken, we're in 51 markets and 17 states today, so we're continuing to see that expansion as we move throughout the year.
componenttext: Sorry, Ken, we're in 51 markets and 17 states today, so we're continuing to see that expansion as we move throughout the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, and then I guess relative to idea of pace, the idea of pace in price, I'm not a big fan of that notion, but I mean are you constraining your pace or you're really accepting as many sales as well lock in the door, can you describe that dynamic broad
componenttext: Right, and then I guess relative to idea of pace, the idea of pace in price, I'm not a big fan of that notion, but I mean are you constraining your pace or you're really accepting as many sales as well lock in the door, can you describe that dynamic broadly speaking? Thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, we have been trying in successfully setting absorption targets on communities, based upon what we think is a sustainable demand in a submarket. And we are building and selling to that pace.
componenttext: Ken, we have been trying in successfully setting absorption targets on communities, based upon what we think is a sustainable demand in a submarket. And we are building and selling to that pace.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next question is coming from Alan Ratner with Zelman and Associates.
componenttext: You're next question is coming from Alan Ratner with Zelman and Associates.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I guess, on the price point conversation, obviously you guys have done a great job with Express, and I think that, at least in the investment community, there is this perception that entry-level is accelerating nicely, where as maybe higher end lux
componenttext: David, I guess, on the price point conversation, obviously you guys have done a great job with Express, and I think that, at least in the investment community, there is this perception that entry-level is accelerating nicely, where as maybe higher end luxury segment is seeing some softness. Can you guys have been expanding Emerald as well, I don't think it's much of a topic of conversation. But I was wondering if you can give some updated color on the luxury and how that compares to the obviously the strength you've been seeing in Express and how you think about allocating dollars going forward between the segments?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From a allocation of dollars, we -- it's a market-by-market program. The markets where the upper end is continuing to stay strong, we will be putting more money on it. But what's really driving the growth right now and the improvements in returns is lower
componenttext: From a allocation of dollars, we -- it's a market-by-market program. The markets where the upper end is continuing to stay strong, we will be putting more money on it. But what's really driving the growth right now and the improvements in returns is lower end, either express or lower Horton.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would that be true on the margin side as well, because obviously I think you probably go into it thinking that Express is going to generate a lower margin, but it seems like the pricing power has been strong there, so what does the spread look like be
componenttext: And would that be true on the margin side as well, because obviously I think you probably go into it thinking that Express is going to generate a lower margin, but it seems like the pricing power has been strong there, so what does the spread look like between the Emerald and the Express branch right now?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now it's in a pretty tight range, both our near our company average. Obviously with the pent-up demand in Express and really not enough supply out there, we've seeing better margins than we originally underwrote the deals to. So right now, it's in a
componenttext: Right now it's in a pretty tight range, both our near our company average. Obviously with the pent-up demand in Express and really not enough supply out there, we've seeing better margins than we originally underwrote the deals to. So right now, it's in a pretty tight range.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks a lot. And if I could sneak in one more, just on the land supply, options lots this quarter, if I heard that number correctly and I think you're looking at over 40% of your control lots or options right now. Just curious, what you're seeing
componenttext: Great, thanks a lot. And if I could sneak in one more, just on the land supply, options lots this quarter, if I heard that number correctly and I think you're looking at over 40% of your control lots or options right now. Just curious, what you're seeing in the land market that's allowing you to pursue the strategy. Obviously tied into your focus on cash generation, but is that a function of just more radiance the capital available to the developers? Or something else that you've been focusing on to drive that number higher?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've been focusing heavily on developer relationships and working with them where we can. It's also a little bit of a timing functionality to that and that it can be very high in the middle of the quarter, come down as you're buying land in lots.
componenttext: I think we've been focusing heavily on developer relationships and working with them where we can. It's also a little bit of a timing functionality to that and that it can be very high in the middle of the quarter, come down as you're buying land in lots. And at this quarter end, we have a little bit more than we might have been in prior quarter ends. But it has been a focus for us. We're pleased with the results we are getting and being able to control more of our future lots supply with options and with developers. And we're going to continue to focus, you're right, it's a key part of our cash generation  strategy and we're very excited about the results we're seeing.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But we're not really saying the A&D environment with the banks improved much. This is really the result of taking the very best of the best developers and trying to improve our relationships with them.
componenttext: But we're not really saying the A&D environment with the banks improved much. This is really the result of taking the very best of the best developers and trying to improve our relationships with them.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research Company.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research Company.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious about the strategy moving forward of growing community counts and then also looking at your growth relative to market in total. Last year, you grew faster than the market, really rolling out Express, but if you look at where demand is, and where t
componenttext: Curious about the strategy moving forward of growing community counts and then also looking at your growth relative to market in total. Last year, you grew faster than the market, really rolling out Express, but if you look at where demand is, and where trends are in the market, just curious about how you think about investing and growing communities and accelerating growth, how you're feeling about that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are in 51 markets right now with Express. So we have, I think, runway there. We are relatively new with the Express brand in another 15 and 20 markets that we think we can certainly gain market share in those markets. And we're pretty much tracking job
componenttext: We are in 51 markets right now with Express. So we have, I think, runway there. We are relatively new with the Express brand in another 15 and 20 markets that we think we can certainly gain market share in those markets. And we're pretty much tracking job growths and where the economy is supporting housing, that's where we're looking to expand our investments.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of the pace of the overall growth, are you satisfied with what you've seen, is there desire to invest more to grow faster? Or is this kind of what you're targeting and what you would like to sustain?
componenttext: In terms of the pace of the overall growth, are you satisfied with what you've seen, is there desire to invest more to grow faster? Or is this kind of what you're targeting and what you would like to sustain?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got a solid, consistent double-digit growth, both top line, bottom line. We will continue to create separation from other builders in the industry. And to date, we are very happy with that strategy.
componenttext: We've got a solid, consistent double-digit growth, both top line, bottom line. We will continue to create separation from other builders in the industry. And to date, we are very happy with that strategy.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we believe our current lot position is sufficient to support that double-digit growth pace.
componenttext: And we believe our current lot position is sufficient to support that double-digit growth pace.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This quarter you had a terrific SG&A performance. And so just a market improvements, just a trend and over last year. Your gross margins have also been very consistent. You're only taking up your pretax range by about 20 basis points, so I just wanted to
componenttext: This quarter you had a terrific SG&A performance. And so just a market improvements, just a trend and over last year. Your gross margins have also been very consistent. You're only taking up your pretax range by about 20 basis points, so I just wanted to make sure I understood that, does that mean that there were some temporary factors that may have depressed SG&A? Why would you expect seemingly the terrific performance to reverse? Or is it something on the gross margin side for the rest of the year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: issue. We didn't say anything unusual this quarter. We did deliver strong backlog conversion. We delivered a little bit above our guidance range on our closings this quarter and that helped leverage our SG&A a bit further. But we were very pleased with th
componenttext: issue. We didn't say anything unusual this quarter. We did deliver strong backlog conversion. We delivered a little bit above our guidance range on our closings this quarter and that helped leverage our SG&A a bit further. But we were very pleased with the leverage saw on SG&A. And we are tracking a better pace, a better ratio for the year than we had originally guided to. And we were guiding to some improvement in SG&A that we're simply showing such a better improvement on that. And certainly, as we get further into the year and depending on what our deliveries are later in the year, there is potential we could leverage it a bit better than what we are guided to here. If we were to be at the high-end of our volume range, then perhaps we have a chance of beating the low end of our leverage range, our SG&A leverage range. But right now we're comfortable with the range we've guided to. Nothing unusual, no declining or degradation in our SG&A performance is expected.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it. And kind of following up on question from earlier. You folks as well as many of the other builders have been scaling back land purchases, discussed obviously the increased use of options. I was just wondering with the stepback that many of
componenttext: Got it. Got it. And kind of following up on question from earlier. You folks as well as many of the other builders have been scaling back land purchases, discussed obviously the increased use of options. I was just wondering with the stepback that many of the builders including yourselves have taken, have you seen pricing, fees the options would argue that it's little bit easier to get terms like option takedowns, but what are you seeing in terms of the availability and pricing of deal, as the stepping back of the public is the land price pressures that have been discussed so much in the last couple of years?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nishu, we're looking to continue our land investment. In fact, we'll be increasing our investment this year than what we had last year, just to replenish the lots and then probably a little more to bring it up a little bit. We did see an increase in our o
componenttext: Nishu, we're looking to continue our land investment. In fact, we'll be increasing our investment this year than what we had last year, just to replenish the lots and then probably a little more to bring it up a little bit. We did see an increase in our option lot position in the control pipeline, some of that will be land we will purchase, that's represented as options lots there that land that's controlled under contracts that we will purchase as land to develop ourselves. Other contacts within that portfolio would be, where we will be acquiring finished lots or superpads if you will, in some cases from third-party developers. But we feel that there are still very good opportunities out there for land acquisition, for well-capitalized builders and for well-capitalized developers to work through. It's hard to quantitatively look and say what's happening with land pricing globally. I would tell you that it seems like we're getting anecdotally look at a few more deals, and things need to come back around, which is just good for us, we like that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question today is coming from Stephen Kim from Barclays.
componenttext: The next question today is coming from Stephen Kim from Barclays.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a remark that your SG&A, if you actually do a little bit in your range, that's like -- I think if I'm not mistaken, that's an all-time record for the company, so that's pretty encouraging. I guess, my first question relates to M&A and the opportunity
componenttext: Just a remark that your SG&A, if you actually do a little bit in your range, that's like -- I think if I'm not mistaken, that's an all-time record for the company, so that's pretty encouraging. I guess, my first question relates to M&A and the opportunity for it. Obviously there has been and there still is a pretty big disparity in valuations between the large and small builders and you all are pretty much leaving the pack. I guess my question is, do you see this kind of disparity mirrored in the private market? And particularly where some of the smaller cap publics are trading at book value or below, I mean, are you seeing that kind of valuation mirrored in the private market in expectations? And can you talk about whether or not you think this generally is the right time where you amenable to acquiring assets in that kind of way M&A, given the fact that your strategic focus is on reducing your land investment relative to revenues right now?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're correct, Steven. We do have a strategic focus to improve our ratio of revenues to our land investment today. We are always looking to do that. That makes us better steward of the capital that we're interested with. We do look at M&A as an opportuni
componenttext: You're correct, Steven. We do have a strategic focus to improve our ratio of revenues to our land investment today. We are always looking to do that. That makes us better steward of the capital that we're interested with. We do look at M&A as an opportunity to acquire lots, acquire assets and acquire people and operating platforms and teams. And we do look at several opportunities. They can be very good, if buyer and seller expectations are aligned and something can work that's accretive to both. So we will always be looking at M&A opportunities to grow the business. But there is a lot of expectation get sometimes, sometimes some people think what their platform should fetch and what the buyers want actually to transact for. So there has not been as many transactions, I think some people expected to occur.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, it's David. I'll also add, we're going to look at a lot -- anybody out there, we're going to take a look at and try to see if they fit the culturally, strategically within our company. But it's got to be a very good company for it to make sense to
componenttext: Steven, it's David. I'll also add, we're going to look at a lot -- anybody out there, we're going to take a look at and try to see if they fit the culturally, strategically within our company. But it's got to be a very good company for it to make sense to us. We like where we are. We like what we're accomplishing and we really don't want to jump after and do anything that's going to write that focus.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. Good luck finding another company is strong you guys are though.
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. Good luck finding another company is strong you guys are though.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are some small operators or even midsize operators that are doing a great job. I mean if you look back at the 4 acquisitions we've made, we have learned it become better with every one of those. And integrated into our company.
componenttext: There are some small operators or even midsize operators that are doing a great job. I mean if you look back at the 4 acquisitions we've made, we have learned it become better with every one of those. And integrated into our company.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, I guess, my second question relates to the role of master plan communities and some of the opportunity is that those larger parcels could potentially provide for you. I was wondering if you could give us some handle on, what percent of your busines
componenttext: Great, I guess, my second question relates to the role of master plan communities and some of the opportunity is that those larger parcels could potentially provide for you. I was wondering if you could give us some handle on, what percent of your business you think is coming for master-planned committees today? And where do you think that could go to? And as a follow on to that, would you generally think that in some of these larger parcels, you have the ability to maybe take on a little bit of multifamily construction or even like commercial opportunities longer-term?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The master plans, I'd say is probably 10%, 15% of our business and that's just a guess really. It's not really something we have broken down. And yes, I think as we get bigger or continue to get bigger, that percentage is going to grow. It's just a lot mo
componenttext: The master plans, I'd say is probably 10%, 15% of our business and that's just a guess really. It's not really something we have broken down. And yes, I think as we get bigger or continue to get bigger, that percentage is going to grow. It's just a lot more efficient to deliver more out on one location than it is on multiple locations.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Steve, as you know, we always investigate new business lines that they could complement our business. And so we have built -- on land we own on a limited basis when it makes business sense. And we do currently own a few larger projects with parce
componenttext: And then Steve, as you know, we always investigate new business lines that they could complement our business. And so we have built -- on land we own on a limited basis when it makes business sense. And we do currently own a few larger projects with parcel multifamily that we're evaluating in the process of building apartments on. But we wouldn't expect that to have any financial impact on our 2016 results.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall with RBC.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall with RBC.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys are crushing it, nice job. That's a technical term. Talk to me about ASP appreciation during the balance of the year, how do you think that plays out? What kind of growth rate should we be expecting? And I'm really kind of thinking about this, in
componenttext: You guys are crushing it, nice job. That's a technical term. Talk to me about ASP appreciation during the balance of the year, how do you think that plays out? What kind of growth rate should we be expecting? And I'm really kind of thinking about this, in the context of not including mix, if you took like-for-like and you blend it together, what do you see going on in the next couple of quarters?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would expect to continue to see, if you're looking like-for-like, sustainability to move price up. We've continue to see of our revenues per square foot outpace our per square foot now, once we got -- that can check the couple of quarters ago. So very
componenttext: We would expect to continue to see, if you're looking like-for-like, sustainability to move price up. We've continue to see of our revenues per square foot outpace our per square foot now, once we got -- that can check the couple of quarters ago. So very positive on that front and definitely still the ability to push price. In terms of other overall ASP, we did see on our sales front that really kind of flattened out sequentially, which isn't surprising, because of the heavier mix that continues to come from Express.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. But you're still getting the operating leverage off that, which offsets the weaker mix, but I got to say on a like-for-like basis, would you expect low single-digit or mid-single digit?
componenttext: Got it. But you're still getting the operating leverage off that, which offsets the weaker mix, but I got to say on a like-for-like basis, would you expect low single-digit or mid-single digit?

componenttext: Yes, low single-digits.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: All right, that's helpful. And then just kind of thinking about, like taxes in California, some of your major markets where you were leader. Or would you say that in your core most important markets that demand is stronger and better than you had anticipated? I'm just trying to understand a little bit better, if you're gauging strength of demand in your most important markets, is it coming out ahead of your expectations? Thanks and good luck.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. It's kind of a mix, like taxes, at least in my mind, Houston has probably underperformed my expectations over the last couple of quarters, but it's been offset by an overperform in Austin, Dallas and San Antonio. I mean, balance of the sta
componenttext: Thank you, Bob. It's kind of a mix, like taxes, at least in my mind, Houston has probably underperformed my expectations over the last couple of quarters, but it's been offset by an overperform in Austin, Dallas and San Antonio. I mean, balance of the state is doing incredibly well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: An overall, we expected a good spring and we are seeing a good spring. So overall, I guess, it's in line with our expectations for good, solid, consistent moderately growing market with variations from market to market.
componenttext: An overall, we expected a good spring and we are seeing a good spring. So overall, I guess, it's in line with our expectations for good, solid, consistent moderately growing market with variations from market to market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our absorption to pick up in those in the South East and South central regions, which is what you've heard us say, really kind of taxes across the Florida and up into the Carolinas. It's a piece of our business that we expect to be very robust and we've s
componenttext: Our absorption to pick up in those in the South East and South central regions, which is what you've heard us say, really kind of taxes across the Florida and up into the Carolinas. It's a piece of our business that we expect to be very robust and we've seeing very good level of demand in those markets and a good return on our inventory investments.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, we do have very high expectations all time and we are pleased with the way the results of the spring have come out and really across-the-board at all of our markets.
componenttext: Bob, we do have very high expectations all time and we are pleased with the way the results of the spring have come out and really across-the-board at all of our markets.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question just on the sales pace, continued expansion there, we have roughly -- up 8%. Just want to make sure in terms of the drivers there. It seems like primarily that's due to the continued expansion of express, as part of your business. Just want
componenttext: First question just on the sales pace, continued expansion there, we have roughly -- up 8%. Just want to make sure in terms of the drivers there. It seems like primarily that's due to the continued expansion of express, as part of your business. Just want to make sure that, that's still is the case in effect and would you expect -- it seems like there is still more room to go, is that something that you would expect to continue to benefit your results even into fiscal '17?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we're -- fully rolled out in Texas, Carolinas on the Express model, still got room to grow in all the other markets. So I think we have got benefit from that brand and that initiative for this year, next year and the year after that, where we
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we're -- fully rolled out in Texas, Carolinas on the Express model, still got room to grow in all the other markets. So I think we have got benefit from that brand and that initiative for this year, next year and the year after that, where we're fully integrated, fully rolled out.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is it -- it's fair to say that that's really, let's say, the biggest driver of your improvement in your overall sales pace is reported this quarter?
componenttext: And is it -- it's fair to say that that's really, let's say, the biggest driver of your improvement in your overall sales pace is reported this quarter?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually it is a major contributor. The other brands are doing well also, but there is just a whole lot less competition at that entry-level.
componenttext: Actually it is a major contributor. The other brands are doing well also, but there is just a whole lot less competition at that entry-level.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And therefore, more pent-up demand and it's easier to drive absorption.
componenttext: And therefore, more pent-up demand and it's easier to drive absorption.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Right, certainly. I guess second question just on the improved SG&A guidance that you rolled out this quarter that helps your pretax by 20 bips now, you've expanded that guidance. Given that you still kind of have that similar expectations on the u
componenttext: Right. Right, certainly. I guess second question just on the improved SG&A guidance that you rolled out this quarter that helps your pretax by 20 bips now, you've expanded that guidance. Given that you still kind of have that similar expectations on the units and it seems like the ASPs, it would kind of suggest that you're not necessarily expecting better -- that the improved leverages isn't coming off of improved volume per se and express and your overall again top line seems to be coming in as expected. So are there other things in the SG&A line item that's helping here in terms of kind of concrete items around perhaps advertising or other types of SG&A controllables that are coming in better-than-expected or is it just the overall model in effect, just the overall efficiency just being that much better even with the same type of closings that you expect 3 months ago?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, it's really just a result of our overall focus on SG&A. It's no anyone thing. It's always been a hallmark of our business, it's something we're very focused on. We said 9.6% SG&A in fiscal 2015, which was the best SG&A we'd had other than 2 years in
componenttext: Mike, it's really just a result of our overall focus on SG&A. It's no anyone thing. It's always been a hallmark of our business, it's something we're very focused on. We said 9.6% SG&A in fiscal 2015, which was the best SG&A we'd had other than 2 years in the company's history when we had 9 handle as well. Now we're guided to 9.0% to 9.2%. And I would say it is a focus and something that all of our guys in the field are looking at. It's how can we run the business more efficiently and leverage our overhead better than we have in the past.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is David. We get up everyday and try to figure out how to make it easy -- a little bit easier to sell the house and a little bit easier to get the house closed. And we work on that every single day, because that is a sustainable competitive adv
componenttext: Mark, this is David. We get up everyday and try to figure out how to make it easy -- a little bit easier to sell the house and a little bit easier to get the house closed. And we work on that every single day, because that is a sustainable competitive advantage, and that is -- that's what we try to be.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And obviously it's great to see as the recovery continues. One last quick question, if I could. Committee count, now flattish throughout fourth quarters, is that something that you would expect to reaccelerate at some point, maybe into the m
componenttext: That's great. And obviously it's great to see as the recovery continues. One last quick question, if I could. Committee count, now flattish throughout fourth quarters, is that something that you would expect to reaccelerate at some point, maybe into the mid-single-digit or high single-digit growth into next year or should we just continue to expect sales pace over the next couple of years to drive the bus?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, for this year, we stated our committee count to be in low single-digit or relatively flat this year with the improvement in sales coming from improved absorptions and certainly the Express rollout is a driver of that. I think it will continue to be
componenttext: Mike, for this year, we stated our committee count to be in low single-digit or relatively flat this year with the improvement in sales coming from improved absorptions and certainly the Express rollout is a driver of that. I think it will continue to be a driver next year, as Express matures, if you're looking what next year or 2, you would naturally expect to grow at the double-digit growth. You would see stronger community count growth over the longer-term. We don't really have the visibility fully for '17 yet to make any specific comments on that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And right now Michael, we're replacing committees every quarter every month. And you trade a community that's driving an absorption level of 2 or 3, for a new community that's express model that's driving 6 or 8. Flat community count, there is a lot of ef
componenttext: And right now Michael, we're replacing committees every quarter every month. And you trade a community that's driving an absorption level of 2 or 3, for a new community that's express model that's driving 6 or 8. Flat community count, there is a lot of efficiencies and absorption improvement in that. So yes. But overtime, we will be expanding our community count to market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Jack Micenko from SIG.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Jack Micenko from SIG.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question for Bill, you're generating a ton of cash, and it sounds like that's going to continue in the next year and years beyond. Your leverage levels are getting to the lower end of I think probably optimal. Your land strategy is changed a bit, bu
componenttext: First question for Bill, you're generating a ton of cash, and it sounds like that's going to continue in the next year and years beyond. Your leverage levels are getting to the lower end of I think probably optimal. Your land strategy is changed a bit, but it sounds like you're going to keep it at the same point, even if the mix is going to change from absolute level. I guess the question is, what do you do with the cash? I know in the past, there have been share repurchase, that has been debt repurchase, what do we think about longer-term goals for the cash, beyond sort of second-half spend that sort of thing around capital management?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly this year, Jack, we're generating $300 million to $500 million and we're paying off over $500 million of debt for this year. So for fiscal '16, it's essentially debt retirement and continuing to invest in the business. We do continue to look at
componenttext: Certainly this year, Jack, we're generating $300 million to $500 million and we're paying off over $500 million of debt for this year. So for fiscal '16, it's essentially debt retirement and continuing to invest in the business. We do continue to look at M&A opportunities. We have done some readies over the last couple of years and to the extent that we see good deals that are a good fit for us, as we described earlier, that will be a priority as well. And then beyond that, we want to stay opportunistic. And so, we're going to tire ourselves down to anything specific beyond this year. But right now, we're focused on debt retirement, being opportunistic, investing in the business and we will assess further, as we get visibility into '17.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up question, through our travels, I think one of the things that we've seeing is the Express type product is appealing to buy a group, maybe beyond the entry or first-time buyer. And we're really surprised by the trade down, empty
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up question, through our travels, I think one of the things that we've seeing is the Express type product is appealing to buy a group, maybe beyond the entry or first-time buyer. And we're really surprised by the trade down, empty nester, sort of mid-to upper end product, but we're seeing a lot in the lower price points as well. Are you seeing that a meaningful way? Has it changed the trajectory or the direction of the rollout of the Express product or maybe even location? What can you share with us about that dynamic?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say that it has changed direction. We have seen that take place especially on Florida. It surprised me as well. When we lost Express in Florida, 40%, 45% or actually people buying last time, not the first time. And that's something we're take n
componenttext: I wouldn't say that it has changed direction. We have seen that take place especially on Florida. It surprised me as well. When we lost Express in Florida, 40%, 45% or actually people buying last time, not the first time. And that's something we're take note of and making sure that we're in a position to accommodate those buyers.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Susan Maklari with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Susan Maklari with UBS.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is just going back to your third quarter guidance, in terms of the conversion rate. I believe you said 76% to 80%, that just feels a little like relative to where we were modeling, our expectations, would you say that you saw any pull fo
componenttext: My first question is just going back to your third quarter guidance, in terms of the conversion rate. I believe you said 76% to 80%, that just feels a little like relative to where we were modeling, our expectations, would you say that you saw any pull forward in demand in the second quarter, perhaps maybe due to the overall better weather that most of the country saw?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily that we're attributing that to better weather, but our operators did convert their backlog at a higher rate than we anticipated and what we told you for Q2. When we look at our business plan for Q3, which we're expected to deliver on. It's
componenttext: Not necessarily that we're attributing that to better weather, but our operators did convert their backlog at a higher rate than we anticipated and what we told you for Q2. When we look at our business plan for Q3, which we're expected to deliver on. It's right now hard about 76% to 80% that we've guided to for Q3.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The timing of deliveries for the year is a function of really the roll-up of all of our committees and the timing of communities come online and when housing start to get started and right now the weight is rolling up, division by division points to that
componenttext: The timing of deliveries for the year is a function of really the roll-up of all of our committees and the timing of communities come online and when housing start to get started and right now the weight is rolling up, division by division points to that range. But still for the year, it points to the same range we gave it at the start of the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And historically, we typically do see a tickdown in our conversion rate from Q2 to Q3, that's a normal seasonal trend for us.
componenttext: And historically, we typically do see a tickdown in our conversion rate from Q2 to Q3, that's a normal seasonal trend for us.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then looking at your spec levels, it seems like there continued to sort of trend down overtime. Can you just talk a little bit about what went into that ends what should we make of that?
componenttext: Okay. And then looking at your spec levels, it seems like there continued to sort of trend down overtime. Can you just talk a little bit about what went into that ends what should we make of that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we can continue to very strong demand in the marketplace right now and then we're starting specs and getting them up there and getting them sold early in the construction process. And its you got to start more outfits and then -- so you get those
componenttext: I think we can continue to very strong demand in the marketplace right now and then we're starting specs and getting them up there and getting them sold early in the construction process. And its you got to start more outfits and then -- so you get those started and you get those sold. In addition, we're starting some office to be build out as well. So our overall mix of build versus spec is staying the same, we're just seeing very strong demand in the marketplace, more efficient with turning of our homes is one of the key drivers of our cash flow generation. Doing more revenue, more closings with the same number of homes under construction at any point of time, key part of our focus.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Will Randow from Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Will Randow from Citigroup.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to Susan's question, when you look at your current percentage of closings that are spec, could you talk about that? And how you feel going into kind of peak construction period with regards to potential labor inflation and/or delays?
componenttext: Just going back to Susan's question, when you look at your current percentage of closings that are spec, could you talk about that? And how you feel going into kind of peak construction period with regards to potential labor inflation and/or delays?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of specs that we closed in the quarter, it was in our normal range, which is every quarter 70% to 80% of what we're closing and is a spec. And so when you look at our reported gross margin, you're essentially seeing our spec gross margins in
componenttext: And in terms of specs that we closed in the quarter, it was in our normal range, which is every quarter 70% to 80% of what we're closing and is a spec. And so when you look at our reported gross margin, you're essentially seeing our spec gross margins in terms of labor.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not seeing that amount of labor inflation. In fact we've been able to stay ahead of the cost increases we've seen on stick and brick, which any cost increase that have come to have been more labor-oriented versus the materials and the commodities to
componenttext: We're not seeing that amount of labor inflation. In fact we've been able to stay ahead of the cost increases we've seen on stick and brick, which any cost increase that have come to have been more labor-oriented versus the materials and the commodities today. But we haven't seen the tremendous amount of pressure and in terms of shortages effecting delays, our cycle times have remained very consistent and we've not had -- backlog conversion rate last quarter, we have not had a real labor constraint widespread that's effected closings.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, as you drive higher absorption in a community-by-community basis, you take a lot of pressure of the trade base, because a lot of their time is just going from community-to-community. And if we can get them into the community and keep them there, th
componenttext: Again, as you drive higher absorption in a community-by-community basis, you take a lot of pressure of the trade base, because a lot of their time is just going from community-to-community. And if we can get them into the community and keep them there, they can make more money, a lot less pressure on pricing.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow up, you mentioned your stick and brick cost are fairly stable. Is there any relative way to parse down on the categories in terms of the movements for example, lumber and how you think about that go into the year?
componenttext: And just as a follow up, you mentioned your stick and brick cost are fairly stable. Is there any relative way to parse down on the categories in terms of the movements for example, lumber and how you think about that go into the year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of overall revenue per square foot, year-over-year was up about 4% and our stick and brick was up about 2.5%. Sequentially, it was closer to both being up about 1%. The majority of the cost inflation, as Mike mentioned, we continue to see on the
componenttext: In terms of overall revenue per square foot, year-over-year was up about 4% and our stick and brick was up about 2.5%. Sequentially, it was closer to both being up about 1%. The majority of the cost inflation, as Mike mentioned, we continue to see on the labor side, not the material side. And so lumber specifically, I wouldn't say we've seen anything unusual in lumber prices. They tend to follow a seasonal trend and we haven't seen anything unusual this year.

componenttext: First question, last quarter I believe you mentioned, heavily reinvesting in Houston at this point but kind of more replenishing strategy. Was that the case in the second quarter? And did anything happen in the quarter, where you might have change that strategy going forward?

componenttextpreview: Really comes down to our overall revenue volume or closings volume. Is the main driver, we expect that predominance of that cash flow to come in our fourth quarter, when we have our largest closing quarter. And that it's essentially the end of the wide ra
componenttext: Really comes down to our overall revenue volume or closings volume. Is the main driver, we expect that predominance of that cash flow to come in our fourth quarter, when we have our largest closing quarter. And that it's essentially the end of the wide range is attributable to a little bit on the timing of when land purchases will close. And so as we get a little closer to end of the year, we might be able to tighten that a bit. But there is some unpredictability and the timing of when land deals will close.

componenttext: Yes. We mentioned that our year-over-year community count was essentially flat, and really when we look at that going forward, we would expect no more than a low single-digit movement. Either way, it could be up or down in a low single-digit percentage here over the next couple of quarters.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Mike Dahl with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Mike Dahl with Crédit Suisse.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to some of the comments and obviously a lot of questions and remarks about the Express side, but just made a comment about this seeing a lot less competition there. And clearly you've had a period of number of quarters of success, comp
componenttext: I wanted to go back to some of the comments and obviously a lot of questions and remarks about the Express side, but just made a comment about this seeing a lot less competition there. And clearly you've had a period of number of quarters of success, competitors have taken notice. It feels like the market in general, there is some more positive tone on the entry level and some acknowledgment that it seems like that demand is pushing outward. And so I'm just curious to hear your take on, we've kind of heard that some other builders are starting to explore similar things, maybe not quite the same, but as you're looking at new land deals, are you running up against more competition than you would have seen kind of 6, 9, 12 months ago? And how do you think that your positioned or what do you think that they are doing differently?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We tend to focus a lot on what we're doing and we do see some competition on the land front. It's constant out there and it's market-by-market and it varies. What others are going to do with their entry level entrants, I've heard about others coming to ma
componenttext: We tend to focus a lot on what we're doing and we do see some competition on the land front. It's constant out there and it's market-by-market and it varies. What others are going to do with their entry level entrants, I've heard about others coming to market, there is some out there. But broadly, we're not seeing widespread, heavy competition today with us flag by flag. Certain in our pockets, there is more competition, but generally we're not seeing it. How others tend to approach that market, that will be up to them. We're focused on providing a great value for the homebuyer. And so our customer can be in their house, they can be there at good price, they can afford a place for their family.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But as entry-level grows, we do expect more competition to come and we're certainly prepared to do as it comes.
componenttext: But as entry-level grows, we do expect more competition to come and we're certainly prepared to do as it comes.

componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Jamie Rahmani from KBW.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Just wanted to ask regarding leverage at this point in the cycle, is that plan to retire near term debt maturities as was indicated in the press release to reduce leverage? Or do you plan to essentially replace those maturities similar sized debt offerings?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will always look at debt markets and we will remain opportunistic there. There are certainly -- it's a favorable market right now, but where we sit today with our cash position, with our expectation of our cash flows. We right now do not expect to be i
componenttext: We will always look at debt markets and we will remain opportunistic there. There are certainly -- it's a favorable market right now, but where we sit today with our cash position, with our expectation of our cash flows. We right now do not expect to be into that market in the short term. We have already paid off $373 million that came due on April 15, we paid that out of cash. And we believe our cash position, our liquidity available on our revolver and our cash flows are sufficient for the remainder of the year, as we sit here today.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just regarding other income, can you comment on what drove the spike in the second quarter?
componenttext: And just regarding other income, can you comment on what drove the spike in the second quarter?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did have -- we sold an investment that we have in debt securities. Even look back at our 10-Qs, there has been a disclosure around that investment. We had some debt securities that we had acquired a while back that gave us access to some lands, th
componenttext: Yes, we did have -- we sold an investment that we have in debt securities. Even look back at our 10-Qs, there has been a disclosure around that investment. We had some debt securities that we had acquired a while back that gave us access to some lands, that we have now acquired the land and are actively developing it. And we're able to restructure those debt securities and the sentimental market. So we had again on that sale of $4.5 million, which was an improvement in our other income line this quarter.

componenttext: Hard to contribute to any one factor. Just a competitive environment, deal by deal, it's different, we are seeing a few second looks, so that's been a very positive for us.

componenttext: You know James, it's business as usual. We feel for the people and what they're going through in Houston right now with horrendous flooding. But our operations are fine and we don't expect any noticeable impact on our business in Houston. Clearly, the market has a bit softened and due to lower oil prices, but we continue to see very consistent, steady demand at price points below $300,000.

componenttext: The east for us, is the Carolinas at north, so its really more northeast for us and we were down only 2% in sales units. Our community count in that region was actually down. So our absorptions were actually up mid-single-digit there. So really just reflects -- probably fewer investments over the last few years manifesting itself in the communities.
