headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call of D.R. Horton, America’s Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to i
componenttext:
Greetings and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call of D.R. Horton, America’s Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Jessica Hansen, Vice President of Investor Relations for D.R. Horton. Please go ahead.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our results for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securitie
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our results for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. 
Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there is no assurance that actual outcomes will not be materially different. All forward-looking statements are based upon information available to D.R. Horton on the date of this conference call, and D.R. Horton does not undertake any obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. Additional information about issues that could lead to material changes in performance is contained in D.R. Horton's annual report on Form 10-K and our most recently quarterly report on Form 10-Q, both of which are filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. For your convenience, this morning's earnings release can be found on our website at investor.drhorton.com, and we plan to file our 10-Q next week. 
After the conclusion of the call, we will post updated supplementary historical data to our Investor Relations site on the presentations section under news and events for your reference. The supplementary information includes historical data on our homebuilding return on inventory, gross margins, changes in active selling communities, product mix and our mortgage operations. 
Now I will turn the call over to David Auld, our President and CEO.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jessica, and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I'm pleased to be joined on this call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.The sp
componenttext:
Thank you, Jessica, and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I'm pleased to be joined on this call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
The spring selling season at D.R. Horton is in full swing, and our team delivered a  strong second quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased to $301 million on $2.8 billion of revenue, and our pretax profit margin improved 130 basis points to 10.9%. Our homes sold increased 10% compared to the second quarter of 2015, driven by improving absorptions. These results continue to reflect the consistent, solid performance of our core D.R. Horton communities and our Emerald Homes and Express Homes brands. We are striving to be the leading builder in each of our markets and to continue to expand our industry-leading market share. We plan to maintain broad product diversity with our 3 brands over the long term. Our continued strategic focus is to produce double-digit annual growth in both our revenue and pretax profits while generating positive cash flows and increasing returns.
During the 6 months ended March, we generated $27 million of cash from operations, on track to meet our target of $300 million to $500 million of positive cash flows for the year. Our return on inventory, defined as homebuilding pretax income divided by average inventory improved to 13.8% for the 12 months, up from 10.7% a year ago. With a sales backlog of 13,695 homes at the end of March and a well-stocked supply of land, lots and homes, we are well positioned for the remainder of 2016. 
Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Net income for the second quarter increased 32% to $195 million or $0.52 per diluted share compared to $148 million or $0.40 per diluted share in the year-ago quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 31% to $301 million in the second quarter comp
componenttext:
Net income for the second quarter increased 32% to $195 million or $0.52 per diluted share compared to $148 million or $0.40 per diluted share in the year-ago quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 31% to $301 million in the second quarter compared to $230 million in the year-ago quarter. And homebuilding pretax income increased 36% to $283 million compared to $209 million in the prior year quarter. 
Our second quarter home sales revenues increased 16% to $2.7 billion on 9,262 homes closed, up from $2.3 billion on 8,243 homes closed in the year-ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was $290,000, up 3% compared to the prior year and flat sequentially from our first quarter. 
This quarter, entry-level homes, marketed under our Express Homes brand, accounted for 23% of homes closed and 16% of home sales revenue. Our homes for higher-end, move-up and luxury buyers priced greater than $500,000 accounted for 7% of our homes closed and 17% of our home sales revenue. 
Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The value of our net sales orders in the second quarter increased 13% from the year-ago quarter to $3.6 billion, and homes sold increased 10% to 12,292 homes on a relatively flat active selling community count. Our average sales price on net sales orders
componenttext:
The value of our net sales orders in the second quarter increased 13% from the year-ago quarter to $3.6 billion, and homes sold increased 10% to 12,292 homes on a relatively flat active selling community count. Our average sales price on net sales orders in the second quarter was $290,900. The cancellation rate for the second quarter was 19%, consistent with the year-ago quarter. The value of our backlog increased 14% from a year ago to $4.1 billion, with an average sales price per home of $296,700, and homes in backlog increased 12% to 13,695 homes. 
Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the second quarter was 19.9%, consistent with the first quarter and up 20 basis points from the second quarter of last year. The consistency on our gross margin reflects the stability of most of our markets
componenttext:
Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the second quarter was 19.9%, consistent with the first quarter and up 20 basis points from the second quarter of last year. The consistency on our gross margin reflects the stability of most of our markets today. We are raising prices or reducing incentives when possible in communities where we are achieving our targeted absorptions. And we are also working to control cost increases. 
Our general gross margin expectations remain unchanged. In the current housing market, we continue to expect our average home sales gross margin to generally be around 20% with quarterly fluctuations that may range from 19% to 21% due to product and geographic mix and the relative impact of warranty and interest cost.
As a reminder, our reported gross margins include all of our interest cost.
David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the second quarter, home building SG&A expense was $258 million compared to $242 million in the prior year quarter. As a percentage of homebuilding revenue, SG&A improved 80 basis points to 9.6% compared to 10.4% in the prior year quarter as our revenu
componenttext:
In the second quarter, home building SG&A expense was $258 million compared to $242 million in the prior year quarter. As a percentage of homebuilding revenue, SG&A improved 80 basis points to 9.6% compared to 10.4% in the prior year quarter as our revenue increase improved our leverage of fixed overhead cost. We remain focused on controlling our SG&A while ensuring that our infrastructure adequately supports our current and expected growth. 
Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Financial services pretax income in the second quarter was $17.4 million compared to $21.5 million in the year-ago quarter. 94% of our mortgage companies loan originations during the quarter related to homes closed by our home building operations, and our
componenttext:
Financial services pretax income in the second quarter was $17.4 million compared to $21.5 million in the year-ago quarter. 94% of our mortgage companies loan originations during the quarter related to homes closed by our home building operations, and our mortgage company handled the financing for 53% of our home buyers. FHA and VA loans accounted for 48% of the mortgage company's volume compared to 45% in the year-ago quarter.
Borrowers' originating loans with our mortgage company this quarter had an average FICO score of 717 and an average loan-to-value ratio of 88%. First-time homebuyers represented 45% of the closings handled by our mortgage company compared to 43% in the second quarter last year. 
Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At the end of March, we had 24,600 homes in inventory, of which 1,600 were models. 11,700 of our total homes were spec homes, with 8,400 in various stages of construction and 3,300 completed. Our construction in progress and finished homes inventory incre
componenttext:
At the end of March, we had 24,600 homes in inventory, of which 1,600 were models. 11,700 of our total homes were spec homes, with 8,400 in various stages of construction and 3,300 completed. Our construction in progress and finished homes inventory increased by $361 million during the quarter, due to seasonal construction activity for the spring selling season. 
Our second quarter investments in lots, land and development totaled $500 million, of which $271 million was to replenish finished lots and land and $229 million was for land development. We expect our investments in land and development to increase in the third and fourth quarters compared to the second quarter this year. 
David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At March 31, 2016, our land and lot portfolio consisted of 189,000 lots, of which 112,000 are owned and 77,000 are controlled through option contracts. 69,000 of our total lots are finished, of which 31,000 are owned and 38,000 are optioned. Our 189,000 t
componenttext:
At March 31, 2016, our land and lot portfolio consisted of 189,000 lots, of which 112,000 are owned and 77,000 are controlled through option contracts. 69,000 of our total lots are finished, of which 31,000 are owned and 38,000 are optioned. Our 189,000 total lots owned and controlled provide us a strong competitive advantage in the current housing market with a sufficient lot supply to support solid growth in sales and closings in future periods. Although our housing inventories will fluctuate as we manage each of our communities to optimize returns, we expect our land and lot inventories to remain relatively stable in 2016.
We also expect to generate positive cash flows from operations for the second consecutive year through increased profitability and disciplined inventory management. During the 6 months ended March, we generated $27 million of operating cash, an improvement of $196 million compared to the same period last year. 
Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: During the second quarter, we recorded $2.8 million in land option charges for write-offs of earnest money deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded a $3.2 million inventory impairment charge in our ea
componenttext:
During the second quarter, we recorded $2.8 million in land option charges for write-offs of earnest money deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded a $3.2 million inventory impairment charge in our east region related to a long-held, inactive land parcel that we sold during the quarter. We will continue to evaluate our inventories for potential impairment, which may result in future charges, but the timing and magnitude of these charges will fluctuate. 
Our inactive land held for development of $194 million at the end of the quarter represents 10,100 lots, down 22% from a year ago. We continue to work through each of our remaining inactive land parcels to improve cash flows and returns, and we expect that our land held for development will continue to decline. 
Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At March 31, our homebuilding liquidity included $1.2 billion of unrestricted homebuilding cash and $884 million of available capacity on our revolving credit facility. Our gross homebuilding leverage ratio improved 580 basis points from year ago to 33.6%
componenttext:
At March 31, our homebuilding liquidity included $1.2 billion of unrestricted homebuilding cash and $884 million of available capacity on our revolving credit facility. Our gross homebuilding leverage ratio improved 580 basis points from year ago to 33.6%. The balance of our public notes outstanding at March 31 was $3.2 billion. On April 15, we repaid $373 million of senior notes at their maturity, and we have no debt maturities in the next 12 months. At March 31, our shareholders' equity was $6.2 billion, and book value per share was $16.85, up 14% from year ago. 
Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are updating our expectations for our fiscal 2016 profitability based on current housing market conditions and our financial performance to date this year. As we noted in our press release this morning, we are increasing our annual guidance for consoli
componenttext:
We are updating our expectations for our fiscal 2016 profitability based on current housing market conditions and our financial performance to date this year. As we noted in our press release this morning, we are increasing our annual guidance for consolidated pretax profit margin by 20 basis points to a range of 10.7% to 11.2% for fiscal 2016. We are also updating our annual guidance for homebuilding SG&A to a range of 9% to 9.2% of homebuilding revenues from the previous range of 9.2% to 9.4%. Also as outlined in our press release this morning, we are reaffirming our previously issued guidance for fiscal 2016 as follows: consolidated revenues of between $12 billion and $12.5 billion; homes closed between 39,500 and 41,500 homes; our home sales gross margin for the full year of 2016 in the high 19s to 20%; and annual financial services pretax profit margin of 30% to 33%; an income tax rate for the full year of between 35% and 36%; an annual diluted share count of approximately 375 million shares; and $300 million to $500 million of positive cash flow from operations for fiscal 2016.
Specifically, for the third quarter of fiscal 2016, we expect our number of homes closed will approximate a beginning backlog conversion rate in a range of 76% to 80%. We anticipate our third quarter home sales gross margin will be in the high 19s to 20%, consistent with the first half of the year, and we expect our homebuilding SG&A in the third quarter to be in the range of 8.9% to 9.1% of homebuilding revenues. 
David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In closing, our second quarter growth in sales, closings and profits and the improvement in our pretax profit margin are the result of the strength of our people and our operating platform. We remain excited and are looking forward to the opportunities ah
componenttext:
In closing, our second quarter growth in sales, closings and profits and the improvement in our pretax profit margin are the result of the strength of our people and our operating platform. We remain excited and are looking forward to the opportunities ahead. We remain focused on growing both our revenue and pretax profits at a double-digit annual pace while continuing to generate positive cash flows and improve returns.
We are well positioned to do so, with our solid balance sheet, industry-leading market share, broad geographic footprint, diversified product offerings across our D.R. Horton, Emerald and Express brands, attractive finished lot and land position and, most importantly, our tremendous team across the country. 
We would like to thank our entire D.R. Horton team for their continued hard work, and we look forward to working together to continue growing and improving our operation. Let's keep the momentum going week-by-week, flag-by-flag throughout this year. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. We will now host questions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from Stephen East from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from Stephen East from Evercore ISI.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Paul Przybylski on for Stephen. Impressed with the first half cash flow generation, given that that's typically a period of heavy spend. What's the sustainability of that going out? I know you're looking for $300 million to $500 million f
componenttext: This is actually Paul Przybylski on for Stephen. Impressed with the first half cash flow generation, given that that's typically a period of heavy spend. What's the sustainability of that going out? I know you're looking for $300 million to $500 million for the year, but should we expect first half cash generation in out years?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's hard to say in future years, Paul. For this year, we are on track, based on our current plans for fiscal 2016, to generate $300 million to $500 million for the full year. We would not be surprised if in Q3 we used cash, because we are building out
componenttext: That's hard to say in future years, Paul. For this year, we are on track, based on our current plans for fiscal 2016, to generate $300 million to $500 million for the full year. We would not be surprised if in Q3 we used cash, because we are building out our backlog, building out our homes and construction. And as we stated, we do expect our land and lot investments to be higher in Q3 and Q4 than it was this quarter. But we are on track for $300 million to $500 million. And our expectations for future years is -- our business model is designed to continue to generate positive cash flows from operations while growing at a double-digit pace. At exactly what level that might be in each year, we will determine as we get better visibility into the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then for a follow-up, I've heard rumblings that you're looking at expanding not so much the Express name but the Express business model to higher price points, basically, everything is included. Do you have any color on that?
componenttext: Okay. And then for a follow-up, I've heard rumblings that you're looking at expanding not so much the Express name but the Express business model to higher price points, basically, everything is included. Do you have any color on that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're learning a lot with the Express rollout, that efficiency and value is a big-time driver in sales. And yes, I mean, as we create operational efficiencies in Express that translate into D.R. Horton, we are moving that way. Now we will always be
componenttext: Well, we're learning a lot with the Express rollout, that efficiency and value is a big-time driver in sales. And yes, I mean, as we create operational efficiencies in Express that translate into D.R. Horton, we are moving that way. Now we will always be a locally controlled business, I mean, we're decentralized. Our operators in the field will respond to the market. And if it is a value-based market, they're going to have to drive more efficient homes. If it is a custom-based price point, then we're going to continue to modify plans and introduce plans at the local level.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Ken Zener from KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Ken Zener from KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder -- not to get too specific in particular markets, but it's useful to the Express Home, where I think you guys have opened up 5 or 6 new Express communities. Can you talk about the kind of trends you're seeing in Denver, as the existing home sales
componenttext: I wonder -- not to get too specific in particular markets, but it's useful to the Express Home, where I think you guys have opened up 5 or 6 new Express communities. Can you talk about the kind of trends you're seeing in Denver, as the existing home sales tighten up there, either due to lack of supply -- I mean, you guys seem to be growing whereas others are not seeing that type of acceleration. Could you kind of give us a little market dynamic on how that product and that market is working?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we opened up Express in Denver over the past year. The team up there has done a great job getting that online. And it shows that there is a real need for affordable housing in that market, and we're delivering a value product to the market. And it
componenttext: I think we opened up Express in Denver over the past year. The team up there has done a great job getting that online. And it shows that there is a real need for affordable housing in that market, and we're delivering a value product to the market. And it's being absorbed, and people are very happy with it. We're very happy we can do it and looking forward to try to do more of it.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ken, it's kind of consistent with what we've seen in other markets, a lot of pent-up demand when we opened. Absorptions have come in higher than we expected. So it's a powerful tool in what we're accomplishing.
componenttext: And Ken, it's kind of consistent with what we've seen in other markets, a lot of pent-up demand when we opened. Absorptions have come in higher than we expected. So it's a powerful tool in what we're accomplishing.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're in 51 markets in 17 states today, so we're continuing to see that expansion as we move throughout the year.
componenttext: We're in 51 markets in 17 states today, so we're continuing to see that expansion as we move throughout the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then, I guess, relative to the idea of pace -- the idea of pace in price, I'm not a big fan of that notion, but I mean, are you constraining your pace or you're really accepting as many sales as will walk in the door? Can you describe that dyna
componenttext: Right. And then, I guess, relative to the idea of pace -- the idea of pace in price, I'm not a big fan of that notion, but I mean, are you constraining your pace or you're really accepting as many sales as will walk in the door? Can you describe that dynamic, broadly speaking?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, we've been trying and successfully setting absorption targets on communities, based upon what we think is a sustainable demand in a submarket. And we are building and selling to that pace.
componenttext: Ken, we've been trying and successfully setting absorption targets on communities, based upon what we think is a sustainable demand in a submarket. And we are building and selling to that pace.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Alan Ratner from Zelman & Associates.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Alan Ratner from Zelman & Associates.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I guess, on the price point conversation, obviously, you guys have done a great job with Express, and I think that, at least in the investment community, there's this perception that entry level is accelerating nicely, whereas maybe the higher-end
componenttext: David, I guess, on the price point conversation, obviously, you guys have done a great job with Express, and I think that, at least in the investment community, there's this perception that entry level is accelerating nicely, whereas maybe the higher-end luxury segment is seeing some softness, and you guys have been expanding Emerald as well. I don't think it's as much of a topic of conversation. But I was wondering if you can give some updated color on the luxury end, how that compares to the, obviously, the strength you've been seeing in Express and how you think about allocating dollars going forward between the segments.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From an allocation of dollars, we -- it's a market-by-market program. The markets where the upper end is continuing to stay strong, we will be putting more money in it. But what's really driving the growth right now and the improvement in returns is the l
componenttext: From an allocation of dollars, we -- it's a market-by-market program. The markets where the upper end is continuing to stay strong, we will be putting more money in it. But what's really driving the growth right now and the improvement in returns is the lower end, either Express or the lower Horton price...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would that be true on the margin side as well? Because obviously, I think you probably go into it thinking that Express is going to generate a lower margin, but it seems like the pricing power has been strong there. So what does the spread look like b
componenttext: And would that be true on the margin side as well? Because obviously, I think you probably go into it thinking that Express is going to generate a lower margin, but it seems like the pricing power has been strong there. So what does the spread look like between the Emerald and the Express brands right now?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, it's in a pretty tight range. Both our near our company average. Obviously, with the pent-up demand in Express and really not enough supply out there, we've seen better margins than we originally underwrote the deals to. So right now, it's in a
componenttext: Right now, it's in a pretty tight range. Both our near our company average. Obviously, with the pent-up demand in Express and really not enough supply out there, we've seen better margins than we originally underwrote the deals to. So right now, it's in a pretty tight range.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I could sneak in one more, just on the land supply, a pretty big spike in option lots this quarter, if I heard that number correctly. And I think you're looking at over 40% of your control lots are optioned right now. Just curious what you'r
componenttext: Great. And if I could sneak in one more, just on the land supply, a pretty big spike in option lots this quarter, if I heard that number correctly. And I think you're looking at over 40% of your control lots are optioned right now. Just curious what you're seeing in the land market that's allowing you to pursue that strategy. Obviously, it ties into your focus on cash generation, but is that a function of just more AD&C [ph] capital available to the developers or something else that you've been focusing on to drive that number higher?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've been focusing heavily on developer relationships and working with them where we can. There's also a little bit of a timing functionality to that in that it can be very high in the middle of the quarter, come down a little bit as you're buyin
componenttext: I think we've been focusing heavily on developer relationships and working with them where we can. There's also a little bit of a timing functionality to that in that it can be very high in the middle of the quarter, come down a little bit as you're buying land or lots through the quarter. And at this quarter end, we had a little bit more than we might have been at prior quarter ends. But it has been a focus for us. We're pleased with the results we're getting and being able to control more of our future lot supply with options and with developers. And we're going to continue to focus on that. You're right. It is a key part of our cash-generation  strategy, and we're very excited about the results we've seen.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But no, we're not really seeing the A&D environment with the banks improve much. This is really the result of taking the very best of the best developers and trying to improve our relationships with them.
componenttext: But no, we're not really seeing the A&D environment with the banks improve much. This is really the result of taking the very best of the best developers and trying to improve our relationships with them.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research Company.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research Company.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious about the strategy moving forward of growing community counts and then also looking at your growth relative to the market in total. Last year, you grew faster than the market, really rolling out Express. But as you look at where demand is and wher
componenttext: Curious about the strategy moving forward of growing community counts and then also looking at your growth relative to the market in total. Last year, you grew faster than the market, really rolling out Express. But as you look at where demand is and where trends are in the market, just curious about how you think about investing and growing communities and accelerating growth, how you're feeling about that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, We're in 51 markets right now with Express. So we have, I think, runway there. We are relatively new with the Express brand in another 15, 20 markets, that we think we can certainly gain market share in those markets. And we're pretty much tracking
componenttext: Well, We're in 51 markets right now with Express. So we have, I think, runway there. We are relatively new with the Express brand in another 15, 20 markets, that we think we can certainly gain market share in those markets. And we're pretty much tracking job growth and where the economy is supporting housing. That's where we're looking to expand our investments.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of the pace of the overall growth, are you satisfied with what you're seeing? Is there desire to invest more to grow faster? Or is this kind of what you're targeting and what you would like to sustain?
componenttext: In terms of the pace of the overall growth, are you satisfied with what you're seeing? Is there desire to invest more to grow faster? Or is this kind of what you're targeting and what you would like to sustain?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've think a solid, consistent double-digit growth, both top line, bottom line will continue to create separation from other builders in the industry. And today, we're very happy with that strategy.
componenttext: We've think a solid, consistent double-digit growth, both top line, bottom line will continue to create separation from other builders in the industry. And today, we're very happy with that strategy.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we believe our current lot position is sufficient to support that double-digit growth pace.
componenttext: And we believe our current lot position is sufficient to support that double-digit growth pace.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This quarter you had a terrific SG&A performance. And so just a market improvement, just on trend and over last year. Your gross margins have also been very consistent. You're only taking up your pretax range by about 20 basis points. So I just wanted to
componenttext: This quarter you had a terrific SG&A performance. And so just a market improvement, just on trend and over last year. Your gross margins have also been very consistent. You're only taking up your pretax range by about 20 basis points. So I just wanted to make sure I understood that. Does that mean that there were some temporary factors that may have depressed SG&A? What -- why would you expect seemingly the terrific performance to reverse? Or is it something on the gross margin side for the rest of the year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nishu, we didn't see anything unusual this quarter. We did deliver a strong backlog conversion. We delivered a little bit above our guidance range on our closings this quarter, and that helped leverage our SG&A a bit further. But we were very pleased with
componenttext: Nishu, we didn't see anything unusual this quarter. We did deliver a strong backlog conversion. We delivered a little bit above our guidance range on our closings this quarter, and that helped leverage our SG&A a bit further. But we were very pleased with the leverage we saw on SG&A. And we're tracking to a better pace, a better ratio for the year than we had originally guided to. We were guiding to some improvement in SG&A. Now we've simply -- showing to better improvement on that. And certainly, as we get further into the year and depending on what our deliveries are later in the year, there is potential we could leverage it a bit better than what we have guided to here. If we were to be at the high end of our volume range, then perhaps, we have a chance of beating the low end of our leverage range -- our SG&A leverage range. But right now, we're comfortable with the range we've guided to. Nothing unusual, no declining or degradation in our SG&A performance is expected.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it. And kind of following up on Alan's question from earlier. You folks as well as many of the other builders have been scaling back land purchases. Alan discussed, obviously, the increased use of options. I was just wondering, with the step b
componenttext: Got it. Got it. And kind of following up on Alan's question from earlier. You folks as well as many of the other builders have been scaling back land purchases. Alan discussed, obviously, the increased use of options. I was just wondering, with the step back that many of the builders, including yourselves, have taken, have you seen pricing ease? The options would argue that it's a little bit easier to get terms like option takedowns, but what are you seeing in terms of the availability and pricing of deals as the stepping back of the public eased the land price pressures that have been discussed so much in the last couple of years?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nishu, we're looking to continue our land investment. In fact, we'll be increasing our investment this year than what we did last year just to replenish lots and then probably a little more to bring it up a little bit. We did see an increase in our option
componenttext: Nishu, we're looking to continue our land investment. In fact, we'll be increasing our investment this year than what we did last year just to replenish lots and then probably a little more to bring it up a little bit. We did see an increase in our option lot position in the control pipeline. Some of that will be land we will purchase that's represented as option lots today, that's land that's controlled under contracts that we will purchase as land to do the development ourselves. Other contacts within that portfolio would be where we will be acquiring finished lots or superpads, if you will, in some cases from third-party developers. But we feel that there are still very good opportunities out there for land acquisition, for well-capitalized builders and for well-capitalized developers to work through. It's hard to quantitatively look and say what's happening with land pricing globally. I would tell you it seems like we're getting, anecdotally, a second look at a few more deals, and things seem to come back around, which is good for us. We like that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question today is coming from Stephen Kim from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question today is coming from Stephen Kim from Barclays.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a remark that your SG&A, if you actually do, do a little better in your range, that's like -- I think if I'm not mistaken, that's an all-time record for the company, so that's pretty encouraging. I guess, my first question relates to M&A and the oppo
componenttext: Just a remark that your SG&A, if you actually do, do a little better in your range, that's like -- I think if I'm not mistaken, that's an all-time record for the company, so that's pretty encouraging. I guess, my first question relates to M&A and the opportunity for it. Obviously, there's been and there still is a pretty big disparity in valuations between the large and small builders, and you all are pretty much leading the pack. I guess my question is, do you see this kind of disparity mirrored in the private market? And particularly, where some of the smaller cap publics are trading at book value or below, I mean, are you seeing that kind of valuation mirrored in the private market and expectations? And can you talk about whether or not you think this generally is the right time where you'd be amenable to acquiring assets in that kind of way M&A, given the fact that your strategic focus is on reducing your land investment relative to your revenues right now?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are -- you're correct, Stephen. We do have a strategic focus to improve our ratio of revenues to our land investment today, always looking to do that. That makes us a better steward of the capital that we're entrusted with. We do look at M&A as an oppo
componenttext: We are -- you're correct, Stephen. We do have a strategic focus to improve our ratio of revenues to our land investment today, always looking to do that. That makes us a better steward of the capital that we're entrusted with. We do look at M&A as an opportunity to acquire lots, acquire assets and acquire people and operating platforms and teams. And we do look at several opportunities. They can be very good if buyer and seller expectations are aligned and something can work that's accretive to both. So we will always be looking at M&A opportunities to grow the business. But there's a lot of expectation gaps sometimes between what some people think what their platform should fetch and what the buyers are willing to actually to transact for. So there's not been as many transactions, I think, as some people expected to occur.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, this is David. I'll also add, we're going to look at a lot -- anybody out there, we're going to take a look at and try to see if they fit culturally, strategically within our company. But it's got to be a very good company for it to make sense to
componenttext: Stephen, this is David. I'll also add, we're going to look at a lot -- anybody out there, we're going to take a look at and try to see if they fit culturally, strategically within our company. But it's got to be a very good company for it to make sense to us. We're -- we like where we are, we like what we're accomplishing, and we really don't want to jump out there and do anything that's going to break that focus.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough, yes. Good luck finding another company as strong you guys are, though.
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough, yes. Good luck finding another company as strong you guys are, though.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are some small operators or even mid-size operators that are doing a great job. I mean, if you look back at the 4 acquisitions we've made, we have learned and become better with every one of those. We take what they're doing good and integrate it in
componenttext: There are some small operators or even mid-size operators that are doing a great job. I mean, if you look back at the 4 acquisitions we've made, we have learned and become better with every one of those. We take what they're doing good and integrate it into our company.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I guess, my second question relates to the role of master plan communities and some of the opportunities that those larger parcels could potentially provide for you. I was wondering if you could give us some handle on what percent of your business
componenttext: Great. I guess, my second question relates to the role of master plan communities and some of the opportunities that those larger parcels could potentially provide for you. I was wondering if you could give us some handle on what percent of your business you think is coming from master-planned committees today? And where do you think that could go to? And as a follow on to that, would you generally think that in some of these larger parcels, you have the ability to maybe take on a little bit of multifamily construction or even like commercial opportunities longer term?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The master plans, I'd say, is probably 10%, 15% of our business, and that's just a guess, really. It's not something we've broken down. And yes, I think, as we get bigger or continue to get bigger, that percentage is going to grow. It's just a lot more ef
componenttext: The master plans, I'd say, is probably 10%, 15% of our business, and that's just a guess, really. It's not something we've broken down. And yes, I think, as we get bigger or continue to get bigger, that percentage is going to grow. It's just a lot more efficient to deliver more houses out of one location than it is multiple locations.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Steve, as you know, we always investigate new business lines if they could complement our business. And so we have built for rent on land we own on a limited basis when it makes business sense. And we do currently own a few larger projects with
componenttext: And then, Steve, as you know, we always investigate new business lines if they could complement our business. And so we have built for rent on land we own on a limited basis when it makes business sense. And we do currently own a few larger projects with parcels that are zoned multifamily that we're evaluating or in the process of building apartments on. But we wouldn't expect that to have any financial impact on our 2016 results.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall from RBC.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall from RBC.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys are crushing it, nice job. That's a technical term. Talk to me about ASP appreciation during the balance of the year, how do you think that plays out? What kind of growth rates should we be expecting? And I'm really kind of thinking about this in
componenttext: You guys are crushing it, nice job. That's a technical term. Talk to me about ASP appreciation during the balance of the year, how do you think that plays out? What kind of growth rates should we be expecting? And I'm really kind of thinking about this in the context of not including mix, if you took like-for-like and you blend it together, what do you see going on in the next couple of quarters?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would expect to continue to see, if you're looking like-for-like, some ability to move price up. We've continued to see our revenues per square foot outpace our stick-and-brick per square foot now once we got that back in check a couple of quarters ago
componenttext: We would expect to continue to see, if you're looking like-for-like, some ability to move price up. We've continued to see our revenues per square foot outpace our stick-and-brick per square foot now once we got that back in check a couple of quarters ago. So very positive on that front and definitely still the ability to push price. In terms of our overall ASP, we did see, on our sales front, that really kind of flattened out sequentially, which isn't surprising because of the heavier mix that continues to come from Express.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. But you're still getting the operating leverage off that, which offsets the weaker mix, but if you had to say, like, on a like-for-like basis, would you expect low single-digit or mid-single-digit?
componenttext: Got it. But you're still getting the operating leverage off that, which offsets the weaker mix, but if you had to say, like, on a like-for-like basis, would you expect low single-digit or mid-single-digit?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, low single-digits.
componenttext: Yes, low single-digits.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, that's helpful. And then just kind of thinking about, like Texas and California, some of your major markets where you're a leader, would you say that the trends you saw this quarter were in line with your expectations a couple of months ago? Or
componenttext: All right, that's helpful. And then just kind of thinking about, like Texas and California, some of your major markets where you're a leader, would you say that the trends you saw this quarter were in line with your expectations a couple of months ago? Or would you say that in your core most important markets that demand is stronger and better than you had anticipated your start [ph]. I'm just trying to understand a little bit better, if you're gauging strength in demand in your most important markets, is it coming out ahead of your expectations?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Kind of a mix, like, Texas, at least, in my mind, Houston has probably underperformed my expectations over the last couple of quarters. But it's been offset by an overperform in Austin, Dallas and Fort Worth and San Antonio. I mean, the ba
componenttext: Thank you, Bob. Kind of a mix, like, Texas, at least, in my mind, Houston has probably underperformed my expectations over the last couple of quarters. But it's been offset by an overperform in Austin, Dallas and Fort Worth and San Antonio. I mean, the balance of the state is doing incredibly well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And overall, we expected a good spring, and we're seeing a good spring. So overall, I think it's in line with our expectations for a good, solid, consistent, moderately growing market with variations from market to market.
componenttext: And overall, we expected a good spring, and we're seeing a good spring. So overall, I think it's in line with our expectations for a good, solid, consistent, moderately growing market with variations from market to market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our absorptions have picked up the most in the South East and South Central regions, which is what you've heard us say, really kind of Texas across to Florida and up into the Carolinas is a big piece of our business that we expect to be very robust. And w
componenttext: Our absorptions have picked up the most in the South East and South Central regions, which is what you've heard us say, really kind of Texas across to Florida and up into the Carolinas is a big piece of our business that we expect to be very robust. And we've seeing a very good level of demand in those markets and a good return on our inventory investments.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, we do have -- you know us. We do have very high expectations at all times. And we are pleased with where the results of the spring have come out and really across the board in all of our markets.
componenttext: Bob, we do have -- you know us. We do have very high expectations at all times. And we are pleased with where the results of the spring have come out and really across the board in all of our markets.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question just on the sales pace, continued expansion there. We have it roughly up 8%. Just want to make sure in terms of the drivers there. It seems like primarily that's due to the continued expansion of Express as part of your business. Just want
componenttext: First question just on the sales pace, continued expansion there. We have it roughly up 8%. Just want to make sure in terms of the drivers there. It seems like primarily that's due to the continued expansion of Express as part of your business. Just want to make sure that, that still is the case, in effect, and would you expect -- it seems like there's still more room to go. Is that something that you would expect to continue to benefit your results even into fiscal '17?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're, I would say, fully rolled out in Texas, Carolinas on the Express model. We still got room to grow in all the other markets. So I think we're going to benefit from that brand and that initiative for this year, next year and the year aft
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're, I would say, fully rolled out in Texas, Carolinas on the Express model. We still got room to grow in all the other markets. So I think we're going to benefit from that brand and that initiative for this year, next year and the year after that, where we're fully integrated, fully rolled out.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just -- is it -- it's fair to say that, that's really the, let's say, biggest driver of your improvement in your overall sales pace as reported this quarter?
componenttext: And just -- is it -- it's fair to say that, that's really the, let's say, biggest driver of your improvement in your overall sales pace as reported this quarter?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say it is a major contributor. The other brands are doing well also. So -- but it's -- there's just a whole lot less competition at that entry level.
componenttext: I'd say it is a major contributor. The other brands are doing well also. So -- but it's -- there's just a whole lot less competition at that entry level.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And therefore, more pent-up demand, and it's easier to drive absorption.
componenttext: And therefore, more pent-up demand, and it's easier to drive absorption.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Right, no, certainly. I guess second question just on the improved SG&A guidance that you rolled out this quarter that helps your pretax by 20 bps, now you've expanded that guidance. Given that you still kind of have similar expectations on the uni
componenttext: Right. Right, no, certainly. I guess second question just on the improved SG&A guidance that you rolled out this quarter that helps your pretax by 20 bps, now you've expanded that guidance. Given that you still kind of have similar expectations on the units and it seems like the ASPs, it would kind of suggest that you're not necessarily expecting better -- that the improved leverage isn't coming off of improved volumes per se and it seems like Express and your overall, again, top line seems to be coming in as expected. So are there other things in the SG&A line item that's helping here in terms of kind of concrete items around, perhaps, advertising or other types of SG&A controllables that are coming in better than expected? Or is it just the overall model in effect, just the overall efficiency, just being that much better even with the same type of closings that you expected 3 months ago?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, it's really just a result of our overall focus on SG&A. It's not any one thing. It's always been a hallmark of our business and something we're very focused on. We set a 9.6% SG&A in fiscal 2015, which was the best SG&A we'd had other than 2 years i
componenttext: Mike, it's really just a result of our overall focus on SG&A. It's not any one thing. It's always been a hallmark of our business and something we're very focused on. We set a 9.6% SG&A in fiscal 2015, which was the best SG&A we'd had other than 2 years in the company's history when we had a 9 handle as well. And we've now guided to 9.0% to 9.2%. And I'd just say it is a focus and something that all of our guys in the field are looking at is how can we run the business more efficiently and leverage our overhead better than we have in the past.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is David. We get up every day and try to figure out how to make it a little bit easier to build a house, a little bit easier to sell a house and a little bit easier to get the house closed. And we work on that every single day because that i
componenttext: Michael, this is David. We get up every day and try to figure out how to make it a little bit easier to build a house, a little bit easier to sell a house and a little bit easier to get the house closed. And we work on that every single day because that is a sustainable competitive advantage. And that is -- that's what we try to be.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And obviously, it's great to see as the recovery continues. One last quick question, if I could. Community count, now flattish for about 4 quarters. Is that something that you would expect to reaccelerate at some point, maybe into the mid-si
componenttext: That's great. And obviously, it's great to see as the recovery continues. One last quick question, if I could. Community count, now flattish for about 4 quarters. Is that something that you would expect to reaccelerate at some point, maybe into the mid-single-digit or high single-digit growth into next year? Or should we just continue to expect sales pace over the next couple of years to drive the bus?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, for this year, we stated we expect our community count to be in kind of that low single-digit or relatively flat this year, with the improvement in sales coming from improved absorptions. And certainly, the Express rollout is a driver of that. I thi
componenttext: Mike, for this year, we stated we expect our community count to be in kind of that low single-digit or relatively flat this year, with the improvement in sales coming from improved absorptions. And certainly, the Express rollout is a driver of that. I think it will continue to be a driver next year. As Express matures, if you're looking over the next year or 2, you would naturally expect to grow at the double-digit pace. You would see a stronger community count growth over the longer term. We don't really have the visibility fully for '17 yet to make any specific comments on that, though.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, Michael, we're replacing communities every quarter, every month. And when you trade a community that's driving an absorption level of 2 or 3 for a new community that's an Express model that's driving 6 or 8, a flat community count, there's a lo
componenttext: Right now, Michael, we're replacing communities every quarter, every month. And when you trade a community that's driving an absorption level of 2 or 3 for a new community that's an Express model that's driving 6 or 8, a flat community count, there's a lot of efficiencies and absorption improvement in that. So yes, but over time, we will be expanding our community count to meet the market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Jack Micenko from SIG.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Jack Micenko from SIG.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question for Bill. You're generating a ton of cash. It sounds like that trend is going to continue in the next year and years beyond. Your leverage levels are getting to the lower end of, I think, probably optimal. Your land strategy has changed a b
componenttext: First question for Bill. You're generating a ton of cash. It sounds like that trend is going to continue in the next year and years beyond. Your leverage levels are getting to the lower end of, I think, probably optimal. Your land strategy has changed a bit, and it sounds like you're going to kind of keep it about the same point even if the mix is going to change from an absolute level. I guess the question is, what do you do with the cash? I know in the past, there've been share repurchase, there's been debt repurchase. What do we think about longer-term goals with the cash beyond sort of second half spend, that sort of thing, around capital management?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, this year, Jack, we're generating $300 million to $500 million, and we're paying off over $500 million of debt this year. So for fiscal '16, it's essentially debt retirement and continuing to invest in the business. We do continue to look at M&
componenttext: Certainly, this year, Jack, we're generating $300 million to $500 million, and we're paying off over $500 million of debt this year. So for fiscal '16, it's essentially debt retirement and continuing to invest in the business. We do continue to look at M&A opportunities. We've done several deals over the last several years, and to the extent that we see good deals that are a good fit for us, as we described earlier, that will be a priority as well. And then beyond that, we want to stay opportunistic. And so we're not going to tie ourselves down to anything specific beyond this year. But right now, we're focused on debt retirement, being opportunistic, investing in the business, and then we'll assess further as we get visibility into '17.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up question, through our travels, I think one of the things that we've seen is the Express-type product is appealing to a buyer group maybe beyond the entry or first-time buyer. And really, we're surprised at the trade-down empty
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up question, through our travels, I think one of the things that we've seen is the Express-type product is appealing to a buyer group maybe beyond the entry or first-time buyer. And really, we're surprised at the trade-down empty nester. Everybody thinks that the active adult is sort of a mid- to upper-end product, but we're seeing a lot in the lower price points as well. Are you seeing that in a meaningful way? Has it changed the trajectory or the direction of the rollout of the Express product or maybe even location? What can you share with us about that dynamic?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say that it's changed the direction. We have seen that take place, especially in Florida. It surprised me as well, where when we launched Express in Florida, 40%, 45% were actually people buying their last home, not their first home. And that's
componenttext: I wouldn't say that it's changed the direction. We have seen that take place, especially in Florida. It surprised me as well, where when we launched Express in Florida, 40%, 45% were actually people buying their last home, not their first home. And that's something we're taking note of and making sure that we're in a position to accommodate those buyers.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Susan Maklari from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Susan Maklari from UBS.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is just going back to your third quarter guidance, in terms of the conversion rate, I believe you said 76% to 80%. That just feels a little  light relative to where we were modeling our expectations. Would you say that you saw any pull f
componenttext: My first question is just going back to your third quarter guidance, in terms of the conversion rate, I believe you said 76% to 80%. That just feels a little  light relative to where we were modeling our expectations. Would you say that you saw any pull forward in demand in the second quarter, perhaps maybe due to the overall better weather that most of the country saw?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sue, not necessarily that we're attributing it to better weather, but our operators did convert their backlog at a higher rate than we anticipated and than what we told you for Q2. When we look at our business plan for Q3, which we're expecting to deliver
componenttext: Sue, not necessarily that we're attributing it to better weather, but our operators did convert their backlog at a higher rate than we anticipated and than what we told you for Q2. When we look at our business plan for Q3, which we're expecting to deliver on, it's right in the heart of that 76% to 80% range that we've guided to for Q3.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the timing of the deliveries through the year is a function of really the roll-up of all of our communities and the timing of when communities come online and when housing starts get started. And right now, the way it's rolling up, division by divisi
componenttext: Yes, the timing of the deliveries through the year is a function of really the roll-up of all of our communities and the timing of when communities come online and when housing starts get started. And right now, the way it's rolling up, division by division, points to that range. But still, for the year, points to the same range we gave at the start of the year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And historically, we typically do see a tick down in our conversion rate from Q2 to Q3. That's a normal seasonal trend for us.
componenttext: And historically, we typically do see a tick down in our conversion rate from Q2 to Q3. That's a normal seasonal trend for us.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then looking at your spec levels, it seems like those are continuing to sort of trend down over time. Can you just talk a little bit about what's contributing to that and should we think -- what should we make of that?
componenttext: Okay. And then looking at your spec levels, it seems like those are continuing to sort of trend down over time. Can you just talk a little bit about what's contributing to that and should we think -- what should we make of that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we can contribute that there's a very strong demand in the marketplace right now and that we are starting specs and getting them out there and getting them sold early in the construction process. And it's -- you got to start more houses. And then
componenttext: I think we can contribute that there's a very strong demand in the marketplace right now and that we are starting specs and getting them out there and getting them sold early in the construction process. And it's -- you got to start more houses. And then -- so you get those started and you get those sold. In addition, we're starting some houses to be build jobs as well. So our overall mix of build versus spec is staying the same. We're just seeing very strong demand in the marketplace, more efficient with our -- turning over our homes is one of the key drivers of our cash flow generation. Doing more revenue, more closings, with the same number of homes under construction at any point of time, key part of our focus.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Will Randow from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Will Randow from Citigroup.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to Susan's question, when you look at your current percentage of closings that are spec, could you talk about that and how you feel going into kind of peak construction period in regards to potential labor inflation and/or delays?
componenttext: Just going back to Susan's question, when you look at your current percentage of closings that are spec, could you talk about that and how you feel going into kind of peak construction period in regards to potential labor inflation and/or delays?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so in terms of our specs that we closed in the quarter, it was in our normal range, which is, every quarter, 70% to 80% of what we're closing is a spec. And so when you look at our reported gross margin, you're essentially seeing our spec gross margin
componenttext: And so in terms of our specs that we closed in the quarter, it was in our normal range, which is, every quarter, 70% to 80% of what we're closing is a spec. And so when you look at our reported gross margin, you're essentially seeing our spec gross margin in terms of labor.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not seeing a tremendous amount of labor inflation. In fact, we've been able to stay ahead of the cost increases we've seen on stick and brick, which any cost increases that have come through have been more labor oriented versus the materials and the
componenttext: We're not seeing a tremendous amount of labor inflation. In fact, we've been able to stay ahead of the cost increases we've seen on stick and brick, which any cost increases that have come through have been more labor oriented versus the materials and the commodities today. But we haven't seen a tremendous amount of pressure and in terms of shortages affecting delays, our cycle times have remained very consistent, and we've not had a -- as evidenced by our backlog conversion rate last quarter, we have not had a real labor constraint widespread that's affected closings.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, as you drive higher absorption in a community-by-community basis, you take a lot of pressure off the trade base, because it's -- a lot of their time is just going from community to community. And if we can get them into the community and keep them
componenttext: Again, as you drive higher absorption in a community-by-community basis, you take a lot of pressure off the trade base, because it's -- a lot of their time is just going from community to community. And if we can get them into the community and keep them there, they can make more money, a lot less pressure on pricing.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up, you mentioned your stick-and-brick costs are fairly stable. Is there any way to you could parse down on the categories in terms of the movements, for example, with lumber and how you think about that going through the year?
componenttext: And just as a follow-up, you mentioned your stick-and-brick costs are fairly stable. Is there any way to you could parse down on the categories in terms of the movements, for example, with lumber and how you think about that going through the year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of overall, our revenue per square foot year-over-year was up about 4%, and our stick and brick was up about 2.5%. Sequentially, it was closer to both being up about 1%. The majority of the cost inflation, as Mike mentioned, we continue to see is
componenttext: In terms of overall, our revenue per square foot year-over-year was up about 4%, and our stick and brick was up about 2.5%. Sequentially, it was closer to both being up about 1%. The majority of the cost inflation, as Mike mentioned, we continue to see is on the labor side, not the materials side. And so lumber specifically, I wouldn't say we've seen anything unusual in lumber prices. They tend to follow a seasonal trend, and we haven't seen anything unusual this year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really comes down to our overall revenue volume or our closings volume would be the -- is the main driver. We expect the predominance of that cash flow to come in our fourth quarter when we have our largest closings quarter. And it's essentially then t
componenttext: It really comes down to our overall revenue volume or our closings volume would be the -- is the main driver. We expect the predominance of that cash flow to come in our fourth quarter when we have our largest closings quarter. And it's essentially then that the wide range is attributable to a little bit unpredictability on the timing of when land purchases will close. And so as we get a little closer to end of the year, we might be able to tighten that a bit. But there is some unpredictability in the timing of when land deals will close.
