headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for D.R. Horton, America's Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to t
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for D.R. Horton, America's Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to turn the call over to Jessica Hansen, Vice President of Investor Relations for D.R. Horton. Please go ahead.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our results for the third quarter of fiscal 2016. Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our results for the third quarter of fiscal 2016. 
Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there is no assurance that actual outcomes will not be materially different. All forward-looking statements are based upon information available to D.R. Horton or the date of this conference call and D.R. Horton does not undertake any obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
Additional information about issues that can lead to material changes in performance is contained in D.R. Horton's annual report on Form 10-K and our most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q, both of which are filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. This morning's earnings release can be found on our website at investor.drhorton.com, and we plan to file our 10-Q next week. After the conclusion of the call, we will post updated supplementary data to our Investor Relations site on the Presentation section under News and Events for your reference. The supplementary information includes current and historical supporting data on our homebuilding return on inventory, gross margins, changes in active selling communities, product mix and our mortgage operations. 
Now I will turn the call over to David Auld, our President and CEO.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jessica and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I'm pleased to be joined on this call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. The D.
componenttext:
Thank you, Jessica and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I'm pleased to be joined on this call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
The D.R. Horton team delivered a strong third quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased to $379 million on $3.2 billion of revenue. And our pretax profit margin improved 40 basis points to 11.7%. Our homes sold increased 13% compared to third quarter of 2015 as we continue to see improvement in absorption per community. These results reflect the consistent, solid performance of our core D.R. Horton communities and our Emerald Homes and Express Homes brand as we strive to be the leading builder in each of our markets. 
Our focus is to produce double-digit annual growth in both our revenues and profits while generating positive cash flows and increasing returns. During the 9 months into June, we generated $89 million of cash from operations, on track for our second consecutive year of positive cash flows. For the trailing 12 months, our homebuilding return on inventory improved to 14.3%, up from 12.1% a year ago. 
With a sales backlog of 14,670 homes at the end of June and a well-stocked supply of land, lots and homes, we are well-positioned for the fourth quarter and next year. 
Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Net income for the third quarter increased 13% to $250 million or $0.66 per diluted share compared to $221 million or $0.60 per diluted share in the prior year quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 13% to $379 million in the third quarter vers
componenttext:
Net income for the third quarter increased 13% to $250 million or $0.66 per diluted share compared to $221 million or $0.60 per diluted share in the prior year quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 13% to $379 million in the third quarter versus $334 million a year ago. And homebuilding pretax income increased 16% to $349 million compared to $302 million. 
Our third quarter home sales revenues increased 9% to $3.1 billion on 10,739 homes closed, up from $2.9 billion on 9,856 homes closed in the prior year quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was $290,400, essentially flat both sequentially and compared to last year. 
This quarter, entry-level homes, marketed under our Express Homes brand, accounted for 28% of homes closed and 20% of home sales revenue. Our homes for higher end move up and luxury buyers, priced greater than $500,000, were 7% of our homes closed and 16% of our homes sales revenue. 
Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The value of our net sales orders in the third quarter increased 14% from the prior year quarter to $3.4 billion and homes sold increased 13% to 11,714 homes on a slight decrease on our average active selling communities. Our average sales price on net sa
componenttext:
The value of our net sales orders in the third quarter increased 14% from the prior year quarter to $3.4 billion and homes sold increased 13% to 11,714 homes on a slight decrease on our average active selling communities. Our average sales price on net sales orders in the third quarter was $293,300. The cancellation rate for the third quarter was 21%, consistent with the prior year quarter. 
The value of our backlog increased 17% from a year ago to $4.4 billion, with an average sales price per home of $298,600 and homes in backlog increased 15% to 14,670 homes. Our backlog conversion rate for the third quarter was 78%, at the midpoint of the range we guided to on our second quarter call. 
Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the third quarter was 20.3%, up 40 basis points from the second quarter. The improvement in our margin this quarter was primarily due to controlling cost increases while also reducing incentives or raising
componenttext:
Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the third quarter was 20.3%, up 40 basis points from the second quarter. The improvement in our margin this quarter was primarily due to controlling cost increases while also reducing incentives or raising prices in communities where we are achieving our targeted absorptions. 
Our general gross margin expectations remain unchanged. In the current housing market, we continue to expect our average home sale gross margin to be around 20% with quarterly fluctuations that may range from 19% to 21% due to product and geographic mix and the relative impact of warraty and interest cost. 
David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the third quarter, homebuilding SG&A expense was $280 million compared to $258 million in the prior year quarter. As a percentage of homebuilding revenue, SG&A improved 10 basis points to 8.9% compared to 9% in the prior-year quarter. Of the 9 months e
componenttext:
In the third quarter, homebuilding SG&A expense was $280 million compared to $258 million in the prior year quarter. As a percentage of homebuilding revenue, SG&A improved 10 basis points to 8.9% compared to 9% in the prior-year quarter. Of the 9 months ended June, our SG&A improved 40 basis points to 9.5% compared to 9.9% in the same period in the prior year. We remain focused on controlling our SG&A while ensuring our infrastructure adequately supports our current and expected growth. 
Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Financial services pretax income in the third quarter was $29.4 million compared to $31.7 million in the prior year quarter. 92% of our mortgage company's loan originations during the quarter related to homes closed by our homebuilding operations, and our
componenttext:
Financial services pretax income in the third quarter was $29.4 million compared to $31.7 million in the prior year quarter. 92% of our mortgage company's loan originations during the quarter related to homes closed by our homebuilding operations, and our mortgage company handled the financing for 56% of our home buyers. FHA and VA loans accounted for 50% of the mortgage company's volume compared to 49% in the prior-year quarter.
Borrowers originating loans with our mortgage company this quarter had an average FICA score of 716 and an average loan-to-value ratio of 89%. First-time homebuyers represented 45% of the closings handled by our mortgage company compared to 41% in the third quarter last year. 
Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At the end of June, we had 25,300 homes in inventory, of which 1,600 were models. 11,300 of our total homes were spec homes, with 8,200 in various stages of construction and 3,100 completed. Our construction in progress and finished homes inventory increa
componenttext:
At the end of June, we had 25,300 homes in inventory, of which 1,600 were models. 11,300 of our total homes were spec homes, with 8,200 in various stages of construction and 3,100 completed. Our construction in progress and finished homes inventory increased by $218 million during the quarter due to seasonal construction activity. 
Our third quarter investments in lots, land and development totaled $823 million, of which $586 million was to replenish finished lots and land and $237 million was for land development. 
For the 9 months ended June, our investments totaled $2 billion, an increase of 18% from the same period last year. We expect the continued increase in our investments in land and development in the fourth quarter as compared to the prior year. 
David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At June 30, 2016, our land and lot portfolio consisted of 202,000 total lots, which 112,000 or 55% are owned and 90,000 or 45% are controlled through auction contracts. 73,000 of our total lots are finished, of which 30,000 are owned and 43,000 are auctio
componenttext:
At June 30, 2016, our land and lot portfolio consisted of 202,000 total lots, which 112,000 or 55% are owned and 90,000 or 45% are controlled through auction contracts. 73,000 of our total lots are finished, of which 30,000 are owned and 43,000 are auction. Our 202,000 total lots owned and controlled provide us a strong competitive advantage with a sufficient lot [indiscernible] to support solid growth in sales and closings in future periods. 
Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: During the third quarter, we reported $2.9 million in land option charges for write-offs of earnest money deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded $5.2 million of inventory impairment charges primaril
componenttext:
During the third quarter, we reported $2.9 million in land option charges for write-offs of earnest money deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded $5.2 million of inventory impairment charges primarily due to an expected land sale in the East region. We will continue to evaluate our inventories for potential impairment, which may result in future charges, but the timing and magnitude of these charges will fluctuate. 
Our inactive land held for development of $156 million at the end of the quarter represents 9,100 lots, down 29% from a year ago. We continue to work through each of our remaining inactive land parcels to improve cash flows and returns and we expect that our land held for development will continue to decline. 
Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At June 30, our homebuilding liquidity included $863 million of unrestricted homebuilding cash and $882 million of available capacity on our revolving credit facility. Our homebuilding leverage ratio improved 730 basis points from a year ago to 30%. Dur
componenttext:
At June 30, our homebuilding liquidity included $863 million of unrestricted homebuilding cash and $882 million of available capacity on our revolving credit facility. Our homebuilding leverage ratio improved 730 basis points from a year ago to 30%. 
During the quarter, we repaid $373 million of senior notes at their maturity and the balance of our public notes outstanding at June 30 was $2.8 billion. We have $350 million of debt maturities in the next 12 months. 
At June 30, our shareholders equity was $6.5 billion and book value per share was $17.50, up 14% from a year-ago. 
Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking forward to the fourth quarter, we expect our homes closed to approximate the beginning backlog conversion rate in the range of 81% to 84% at an average sales price around $290,000. We anticipate our home sales gross margin in the fourth quarter wi
componenttext:
Looking forward to the fourth quarter, we expect our homes closed to approximate the beginning backlog conversion rate in the range of 81% to 84% at an average sales price around $290,000. We anticipate our home sales gross margin in the fourth quarter will be around 20% and we expect our fourth quarter homebuilding SG&A to be in the range of 8.4% to 8.7% of homebuilding revenues. 
We estimate that our fourth quarter financial services operating margin will be around 35%. We expect our tax rate in the fourth quarter to be around 35% and our fourth quarter diluted share count to be approximately 377 million shares. And we continue to expect $300 million to $500 million of positive cash flows from operations for the full year of fiscal 2016. 
Our expectations are based on today's housing market condition. Our current, preliminary expectations for fiscal 2017 are for our consolidated revenues to grow by approximately 10% to 15% and for our consolidated pretax margin to increase to a range of 11.2% to 11.5% for the full year. We also expect to generate positive cash flows from operations for the third consecutive year in a range of approximately $300 million to $500 million. We anticipate our tax rate for fiscal 2017 will be between 35% and 36% and that our diluted share count next year will increase by approximately 1.5%. 
David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In closing, our third quarter growth in sales, closings and profits and the improvement in our pretax profit margin are the result of the strength of our people and our operating platform. We are striving to be the leading builder in each of our markets a
componenttext:
In closing, our third quarter growth in sales, closings and profits and the improvement in our pretax profit margin are the result of the strength of our people and our operating platform. We are striving to be the leading builder in each of our markets and continue to expand our industry leading market share. 
D.R. Horton has been the largest builder in the United States for 14 consecutive years. And according to Builder Magazine's recent Local Leaders Issue, in 2015, we were the #1 builder in 13 of the top 50 U.S. housing markets and a top 5 builder in 30 of the largest markets. 
Since 2009, our market share has increased from 5% to 8%. We remain focused on growing both our revenue and profit at a double-digit annual pace while continuing to generate positive cash flows and improved returns. We are well-positioned to do so with our solid balance sheet, industry-leading market share, broad geographic footprint, diversified product offering across our D.R. Horton, Emerald and Express brands, attractive finished lot and land position and most importantly, our tremendous team across the country. 
We'd like to thank the entire D.R. Horton team for their continued focus and hard work and we are excited and looking forward to our opportunities ahead. 
This concludes the prepared remarks. We will now host questions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from the line of Steven East from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from the line of Steven East from Wells Fargo.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, maybe I'll ask you a little bit. Thanks for the guidance on all that, that's very helpful and if I look at the cash flow for 2017, another year that looks like a lot like this year, I guess a couple of things. What does that imply, again, going bac
componenttext: David, maybe I'll ask you a little bit. Thanks for the guidance on all that, that's very helpful and if I look at the cash flow for 2017, another year that looks like a lot like this year, I guess a couple of things. What does that imply, again, going back to your capital allocation that I always ask you. But what does that imply for being able to grow your community? Is it what growth rate are you expecting? Is in that 10% to 15% range that you have in your revenues? And then as you look out, what's your next use there? Is it -- are you seeing M&A out there? And do you have more debt paydown et cetera?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve, I think right now we're looking at every opportunity that's out there. As we've talked before, our goal is to be consistent and kind of take advantage of situations as they appear in our market. Community count growth, I would think we're prob
componenttext: Yes, Steve, I think right now we're looking at every opportunity that's out there. As we've talked before, our goal is to be consistent and kind of take advantage of situations as they appear in our market. Community count growth, I would think we're probably going to take community count up single digit, mid-single digit, maybe. Certainly, paying down debt to me is always a good thing. Deleveraging the balance sheet and creating opportunity -- or opportunities as they arise is something that we believe in. And as far as the guidance for next year, I think it's just -- we see a consistent, solid market out there. And we're well-positioned to take advantage of it. And just kind of continue to try to improve our execution and get better building and closing houses everyday.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just going back to the M&A. What are you seeing out there from the privates? And then switching gears. It sounds like so for next year, you've got your absorption rate continuing to improve. Is that really just being driven on the Express side o
componenttext: Okay. And just going back to the M&A. What are you seeing out there from the privates? And then switching gears. It sounds like so for next year, you've got your absorption rate continuing to improve. Is that really just being driven on the Express side of the world? Or what are you seeing anything else in the markets?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, from the absorption rate, yes, the Express definitely drives higher absorption rates than even the cohort [ph] brand. And as we continue to expand that brand, we are in 51 markets I think right now. We're going to continue to push that brand into ot
componenttext: Well, from the absorption rate, yes, the Express definitely drives higher absorption rates than even the cohort [ph] brand. And as we continue to expand that brand, we are in 51 markets I think right now. We're going to continue to push that brand into other markets. And I think we will see added absorption on a develop division standpoint, improved absorption  division by division which drives the overall. But I do think that we will see growth in communities next year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Steve, this is Mike. On your M&A question. We continue to see various private builders across the country testing the waters. We've been very fortunate with the acquisitions we made, we may have been very selective. We have a lot of good people, a lot
componenttext: And Steve, this is Mike. On your M&A question. We continue to see various private builders across the country testing the waters. We've been very fortunate with the acquisitions we made, we may have been very selective. We have a lot of good people, a lot of good teams. And we'll continue to be selective. We've set a high bar internally and we're looking for the best opportunities that either expand our geographic coverage or bring us new customers, new customer segments.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Alan Ratner from Zelman and Associates.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Alan Ratner from Zelman and Associates.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I think I might have asked you this last quarter too. But the option lot count, I mean, 90,000 now. You're up almost 70% from a year ago, 45% of your total loss control option. What are you seeing the landmark that you've been able to drive that su
componenttext: David, I think I might have asked you this last quarter too. But the option lot count, I mean, 90,000 now. You're up almost 70% from a year ago, 45% of your total loss control option. What are you seeing the landmark that you've been able to drive that success? Because obviously that's going to be a huge positive for returns. And it seems like you're not really anticipating those options having much of an impact on your margin because you're still keeping the same language for roughly 20% gross margin. So is it just that the landmark's opening up and developers have access to capital and they're more willing to flip you these lots at options? Or are you kind of going outside the box and doing something unusual? Because none of your competitors seem to have had much success as you have.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've got a huge advantage and we've got a great big footprint. And our absorption per community is something that developers that are putting lots on the ground look to. So good market, bad market, we're going to build houses. And I think our outre
componenttext: Well, we've got a huge advantage and we've got a great big footprint. And our absorption per community is something that developers that are putting lots on the ground look to. So good market, bad market, we're going to build houses. And I think our outreach to the development community, we are a much friendlier buyer. It's becoming -- our goal is to really partner with these guys and to put their capital at play and avoid some of the longer-term negatives of owning as a builder, as a public company. So it's just focus, be honest with you, focus and execution. Our guys out there had been asked to do it and they get it done.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And generally, you're able to underwrite these deals and keep a pretty similar gross margin as if you were to own that land outright? Or is there margin differential when you do this? And just as a final follow-up there is, is it widespread across the cou
componenttext: And generally, you're able to underwrite these deals and keep a pretty similar gross margin as if you were to own that land outright? Or is there margin differential when you do this? And just as a final follow-up there is, is it widespread across the country where you're having the success? Or are there certain geographies where the majority of those option lots are located? Thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been -- as far as across the country, we've got option. We've been able to create option lot situations in California. And I can tell you, the last market, there was never a chance of doing that. So it really is just focus. And as far as margin, yes
componenttext: We've been -- as far as across the country, we've got option. We've been able to create option lot situations in California. And I can tell you, the last market, there was never a chance of doing that. So it really is just focus. And as far as margin, yes, the margins maybe a little bit lower. But the returns are significantly higher. And that's, to me, we value capital. We want to maximize the return we get on capital. And so trading a nominal amount of margin for a significantly higher return is a good way of helping our shareholders. Maximizing the value of the shares.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Interested in Express from a competitive standpoint and also from a customer standpoint. What you're observing, evolving as this product is continuing to move forward?
componenttext: Interested in Express from a competitive standpoint and also from a customer standpoint. What you're observing, evolving as this product is continuing to move forward?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, this is Bill, certainly, from a competitive standpoint, we've been very pleased with what we're seeing in Express. We're offering a great value, an affordable value for buyers out there and there are still very limited inventory and very limited sup
componenttext: Eric, this is Bill, certainly, from a competitive standpoint, we've been very pleased with what we're seeing in Express. We're offering a great value, an affordable value for buyers out there and there are still very limited inventory and very limited supply of affordable product out there in the market. So we're still seeing what we've been seeing as we've rolled it from market to market. We've been introducing Express into some of our Western markets over the last couple of quarters and we're seeing very positive responses there as well. We've commented in prior quarters about in markets like Florida, where there are, perhaps, more retirees. We have seen more -- a larger mix of older buyers buying the Express Homes because they see the same value there. And so that's been a nice observation as well. And I think will serve us well going forward. It's just another element of demand that -- for that product line.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of the runway with this product, both from a competitive standpoint and your ability to source land where the economics work for this product? And then as well as a percentage of total business, what's -- where are we and what's the run rate from
componenttext: In terms of the runway with this product, both from a competitive standpoint and your ability to source land where the economics work for this product? And then as well as a percentage of total business, what's -- where are we and what's the run rate from here it look like moving forward?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We expect to continue that footprint. As David mentioned earlier, today, we are in 51 markets and 17 states. And 28% of our sales, it was also 28% of our closings and 20% of our revenues. If you recall, when we first introduced and got a question on when
componenttext: We expect to continue that footprint. As David mentioned earlier, today, we are in 51 markets and 17 states. And 28% of our sales, it was also 28% of our closings and 20% of our revenues. If you recall, when we first introduced and got a question on when this is rolled out, what does that look like, we generally talked about overtime about 60% of our revenues coming from our core D.R. Horton brand, 20% from Emerald, 20% from Express, which would infer probably closer to 30% in units on the Express side. I think at this point, we tell you that it looks like that we will overshoot that during this cycle because that's where the demand is right now. And we want to cater to that demand and what we believe is still being underserved. So we don't have any set targets on where it could go. We'll continue to adjust our business based on what we see in the market. And [indiscernible] market shares as we can.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are allocating capital based on the highest returning projects. And right now, we have been pleasantly surprised with the demand for Express and have actually seen higher margins than we originally underwrote and higher absorption levels than we origin
componenttext: We are allocating capital based on the highest returning projects. And right now, we have been pleasantly surprised with the demand for Express and have actually seen higher margins than we originally underwrote and higher absorption levels than we originally underwrote. And so it is a great way to improve returns for the shareholders.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Ken Zener from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Ken Zener from KeyBanc.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So David, if you -- I mean, we talked a long time ago about the housing market prices. Your Express Homes, obviously it's differentiated, it's only 20% of revenue, but it's obviously contributing to your volume. So if you do that, 28% of closings, 20% of
componenttext: So David, if you -- I mean, we talked a long time ago about the housing market prices. Your Express Homes, obviously it's differentiated, it's only 20% of revenue, but it's obviously contributing to your volume. So if you do that, 28% of closings, 20% of revenue, you're at a house of about 2 10 in terms of price point. So what does it mean. I mean, thanks for giving FY '17 guidance. Many other builders wouldn't do that, what gives you the confidence? I know you have the visibility on 1Q based on your units under construction. But what really gives you the confidence to be making these statements about the back half of '17, A. And then B, it seems as though you get this growth. Should we be seeing flat to down pricing on your average sales realizing turns that are offsetting that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the pricing front, right now, we anticipate that it's going to stay essentially flat. But yes, it could trend down with Express continuing to become a bigger mix. What we are seeing though is the markets we are rolling Express out in today are the high
componenttext: On the pricing front, right now, we anticipate that it's going to stay essentially flat. But yes, it could trend down with Express continuing to become a bigger mix. What we are seeing though is the markets we are rolling Express out in today are the higher priced markets. So it's not as much of an incremental drag on our ASP as the initial rollout was.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, Ken, California is probably going to be, we think, going to be very successful Express market for us. We are early in the process of rolling out there. That's typical Express only California is going to be our average sales price right now so..
componenttext: Right now, Ken, California is probably going to be, we think, going to be very successful Express market for us. We are early in the process of rolling out there. That's typical Express only California is going to be our average sales price right now so...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Ken, when we look at our fiscal visibility and our confidence level, it's simply a reflection, number 1, that we do see a good market right now. It's a good, stable, healthy market, certain [ph] variability market, market certainly. But it's a relati
componenttext: And, Ken, when we look at our fiscal visibility and our confidence level, it's simply a reflection, number 1, that we do see a good market right now. It's a good, stable, healthy market, certain [ph] variability market, market certainly. But it's a relatively stable market. But what we see the most is our positioning across our divisions, our division operators are doing a tremendous job of positioning communities, positioning lots in front of those communities and really executing well on our product offerings today. And so as we begin to look forward the next several quarters, next 18 months or so, we would really do have good visibility and confidence level to be able to deliver consistently at a double-digit pace on the revenue line, continue to drive some additional SG&A leverage to improve our operating margin and improve our returns. And so we felt like it was appropriate to start to get some preliminary guidance for next year as we did last year at this time, for fiscal '16. And certainly, we've been pleased that we've essentially delivered on that preliminary guidance thus far this year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, I think it's obviously it is nice to have that early communication. If I could go back to the gross margin still on these, on your guidance. We -- Bill reported today modestly trimmed your guidance, another public builder talked about gross mar
componenttext: Right now, I think it's obviously it is nice to have that early communication. If I could go back to the gross margin still on these, on your guidance. We -- Bill reported today modestly trimmed your guidance, another public builder talked about gross margin pressure. So it seems as though the either construction costs or land inflation, given your roughly 20% gross margin, you feel that is defensible. Is that because you're getting better pricing on these perhaps on these Express than you are on the other pieces? Or is it just that you bought the land at a lower targeted gross margin? I mean, what's -- you can't comment on other builders. But it seems as though you're not concerned about gross margin degradation next year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are always very focused on gross margin, Ken. But what we've seen is that we have taken some lot cost as a percentage of revenue, taken some of those increases and be able to offset them with reduced incentives and controlling some cost increases on th
componenttext: We are always very focused on gross margin, Ken. But what we've seen is that we have taken some lot cost as a percentage of revenue, taken some of those increases and be able to offset them with reduced incentives and controlling some cost increases on the stick and brick side. When we get our community to the targeted absorption levels, at those points, we're able to bring incentives down or take pricing up and protect the margin. And overall, on the balance, the team has done a great job of enhancing the margin on a consolidated basis this quarter. And we feel good about -- with the range of the guidance we're giving on the margins, that's a defensible position for us going forward as we continue to drive absorptions community by community. Part of that's been Express and simplifying some of our operations behind [indiscernible] and delivering a house with fewer labor hours in it to get it built. And part of it has been some of the great land positioning we have been doing over the past few years.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, we feel very good about next year. I mean, what we're seeing in the markets, there's not a lot of lots being put on the ground that were going to have to compete against. There is still pent-up demand at the entry level and first move up price points
componenttext: Ken, we feel very good about next year. I mean, what we're seeing in the markets, there's not a lot of lots being put on the ground that were going to have to compete against. There is still pent-up demand at the entry level and first move up price points. It just feels good right now.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Bob Wetenhall from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys are crushing it and I love the fact that you have that crystal ball somewhere in the office in Fort Worth into '17. I wanted to ask you, when we're thinking about comments around 2017, it's kind of like flat ASP performance looking out. How shoul
componenttext: You guys are crushing it and I love the fact that you have that crystal ball somewhere in the office in Fort Worth into '17. I wanted to ask you, when we're thinking about comments around 2017, it's kind of like flat ASP performance looking out. How should we be thinking about the interplay between kind of like community absorption rates versus new community growth? Because I think to get to your kind of range of 10% to 15% to get flat pricing, you can either deliver faster or you can open new communities? What's the right way to think about that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, we think in '17, it will be a combination of driving further improvement in our absorption, coupled with, at some point, as we move throughout '17, an increase in our community count. Our community count on a year-over-year basis was down, which was
componenttext: Bob, we think in '17, it will be a combination of driving further improvement in our absorption, coupled with, at some point, as we move throughout '17, an increase in our community count. Our community count on a year-over-year basis was down, which was not a surprise to us. And we would expect, over the next couple of quarters, it's move up or down no more than a low to mid single-digit range. But at some point, as we move throughout the year, we would expect an increase in that community count to help drive that 10% to 15% consolidated topline growth.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, we don't have a crystal ball. But Don Horton does tells us what it's going to be and we go do it.
componenttext: Bob, we don't have a crystal ball. But Don Horton does tells us what it's going to be and we go do it.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's quite helpful. And you guys are speaking a lot about California. And I was hoping you could kind of -- I always think that as a cash market, not an option market. And I was hoping it sounds like the torch is going to be passed kind of really good g
componenttext: That's quite helpful. And you guys are speaking a lot about California. And I was hoping you could kind of -- I always think that as a cash market, not an option market. And I was hoping it sounds like the torch is going to be passed kind of really good growth in the Southeast to a very optimistic view of West Coast markets. Could you just give us some flavor of what you're seeing in terms of land buying opportunity and your expectations for growth in both Northern California, Southern California and the Phoenix market? Thanks a lot.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, the growth we're looking at there is at a new price point that hasn't existed out there. And we feel very optimistic based upon the land that we've been able to put in front of that program. So do we feel more optimistic about California than the bal
componenttext: Bob, the growth we're looking at there is at a new price point that hasn't existed out there. And we feel very optimistic based upon the land that we've been able to put in front of that program. So do we feel more optimistic about California than the balance of the country? Absolutely not. I think Texas continues to be strong and our Southeast area just continues to outperform.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we're introducing Express in Phoenix and certainly expected to do very well there and expect to see some growth there in Phoenix as well. But really, the key is the affordable product offering.
componenttext: And we're introducing Express in Phoenix and certainly expected to do very well there and expect to see some growth there in Phoenix as well. But really, the key is the affordable product offering.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It just runs at a much higher absorption. And developers typically, when they see that, they feel more comfortable putting less on the ground for us. So...
componenttext: It just runs at a much higher absorption. And developers typically, when they see that, they feel more comfortable putting less on the ground for us. So...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to understand. Are you seeing the price point for what you're bringing to the California markets is just going to be way below competing entry level and first-time homebuyer product in the market?
componenttext: Just to understand. Are you seeing the price point for what you're bringing to the California markets is just going to be way below competing entry level and first-time homebuyer product in the market?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not saying label. I'm saying that the value combination is going to be superior. And we've been able to capture market share with that product offering.
componenttext: I'm not saying label. I'm saying that the value combination is going to be superior. And we've been able to capture market share with that product offering.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the double-digit and I appreciate the guidance there and obviously, the confidence that that shows. So far in the Q&A, you've touched on obviously, some low single-digit rate of community count growth. ASPs, selling prices, continuing
componenttext: Just following up on the double-digit and I appreciate the guidance there and obviously, the confidence that that shows. So far in the Q&A, you've touched on obviously, some low single-digit rate of community count growth. ASPs, selling prices, continuing this kind of flattish trend that they've had this year, putting the burden, if you will, on absorptions. And just, I think you just mentioned that in the prior question. How should we think about that? Is that absorptions across the portfolio? So on a same-store D.R. Horton brand basis, we would see strong absorption growth there? Or is this, with that, it's obviously a lot of community rotation is this Express, something in for other brands as if percentage grows and actually that's higher absorption. So that would drive the absorption. How should we think about it? And how are you thinking about for next year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, there's several pieces of it and I think you touched on a lot of them. It's some of the Express communities rotating in, also just within the D.R. Horton communities, some of the communities that we are closing out may have been smaller communities
componenttext: Sure, there's several pieces of it and I think you touched on a lot of them. It's some of the Express communities rotating in, also just within the D.R. Horton communities, some of the communities that we are closing out may have been smaller communities and what's been opening are communities with larger lot positions in front of them that are going to be running at higher absorption paces that are coming online, have been coming online over the past few quarters and will be coming online into the future. So that's where we're seeing our double-digit growth within the existing community count. And we do expect, as David mentioned, that we're probably be growing average selling community count slightly into '17. But the nature of the communities, each one producing a few more sales than the ones that they are replacing.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. That's really helpful. And then also, consolidated pretax, I believe, that you've kind of guided to high tens, 10.7% to 11.2%, I think, you said last quarter, specifically you laid out this quarter. But I'm thinking about '17 and Jessica,
componenttext: Got it, got it. That's really helpful. And then also, consolidated pretax, I believe, that you've kind of guided to high tens, 10.7% to 11.2%, I think, you said last quarter, specifically you laid out this quarter. But I'm thinking about '17 and Jessica, I think you mentioned the low levels for next year. A lot of that, I imagine, is coming from continued SG&A leverage. I was wondering if you could just provide some general color around that? Or also, the financial services profitability is part of the mix there as well. That's been pretty strong, consistent. So I was just wondering if you could give us your thoughts on trends in both of those.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're correct, Nishu, that we do expect the majority of our operating margin improvement next year to come from SG&A leverage again like it did this year. And so we guided specifically to 11.2% to 11.5% and we would expect our gross margin to be right ar
componenttext: You're correct, Nishu, that we do expect the majority of our operating margin improvement next year to come from SG&A leverage again like it did this year. And so we guided specifically to 11.2% to 11.5% and we would expect our gross margin to be right around 20% and to drive that better bottom line by further stretching our overhead structure, leveraging our overhead structure. SG&A or in terms of the financial services business, they did see a step down in our margin this year which we've been expecting. They've had outsized gross margins from last year or 2. They're still operating at a very good level. We guided to Q4 for that to be around 35%. They followed the homebuilder business seasonally so in fiscal '17, we would expect them to have low operating margins in the first 6 months of the year and then to pick up in the back half of the year like we saw in '16. We'd expect a similar trend in '17.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I have was on the East region. I believe you highlighted that the impairment in the quarter, was largely driven by a parcel sale or expected land sale there. I was curious if that was the same parcel that you took the impairment on in the s
componenttext: First question I have was on the East region. I believe you highlighted that the impairment in the quarter, was largely driven by a parcel sale or expected land sale there. I was curious if that was the same parcel that you took the impairment on in the second quarter. And just more broadly, regarding the East, I think when we marketed a couple -- did our NDR a couple of months ago, kind of talk to the East as an area of opportunity, maybe do a little bit better, gaining some share there, an area that maybe relative to some of your other regions, there's still some share to be gained there. So any, just thoughts, specifically on the impairment there? And secondly, on the opportunity you see on the region over the next year or 2?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Mike. That is not the same project that we impaired. We sold that project that we impaired in the second quarter, that's no longer with us. This project is a different project. It has been an older project in land held for development. We
componenttext: Michael, this is Mike. That is not the same project that we impaired. We sold that project that we impaired in the second quarter, that's no longer with us. This project is a different project. It has been an older project in land held for development. We evaluated it. In terms of the best course of action for us was to pull the capital out of it and move forward, redeploy that capital. And we do see opportunity for growth and improving our position in our East market. And -- but that's not going to happen overnight. We're going to hard work on it everyday. We've had some changes in the teams up there and we're very excited about the direction they're taking us and the opportunities there putting in front of us. As with everything, nothing ever happens fast enough or quick enough for us but we're working very hard to get more lots on the ground in front of us and get those communities opened and drive more growth out of those.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our [indiscernible] East region, Mike, just for clarification, includes our Northeast market which are the ones Mike was referring to, our Capital division and our New Jersey division. But the East publicly reported region also does include the Carolinas
componenttext: Our [indiscernible] East region, Mike, just for clarification, includes our Northeast market which are the ones Mike was referring to, our Capital division and our New Jersey division. But the East publicly reported region also does include the Carolinas which, those are firing on all cylinders and very strong markets for us today.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I appreciate that clarification. I guess again a question on the gross margin. Obviously you're very clear in your guidance. But you did have a nice, a little better than expected result this quarter and you highlighted a couple of the drivers. I w
componenttext: Great. I appreciate that clarification. I guess again a question on the gross margin. Obviously you're very clear in your guidance. But you did have a nice, a little better than expected result this quarter and you highlighted a couple of the drivers. I was wondering if there was some particular elements of mix that also helped this quarter? And I guess looking forward, you still expect the gross margin to be in and around 20% and I was curious on that. You talked about Express coming in a little better than expected. And obviously, as you do more Express and more Emerald, I would expect the efficiencies and experience to maybe result in a little bit better amount of profitability. So again, sorry for the two parter for my second question again. But mix on the quarter and then some of those improved operational efficiencies or experience set benefiting the margin into next year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. This is Bill. Nothing unusual on the margin this quarter other than just continued focus on execution and controlling our costs. We've been absorbing labor cost increases, some material cost increases over time and we've been working to offs
componenttext: Thanks, Mike. This is Bill. Nothing unusual on the margin this quarter other than just continued focus on execution and controlling our costs. We've been absorbing labor cost increases, some material cost increases over time and we've been working to offset those and we're making some progress there, getting some traction on that while we're still absorbing increasing land cost that are coming in. So -- but -- yes, we've done, I think, an improving job on controlling those cost and continuing to push price and then reduce incentives wherever we can. So we did see a nice low pick up this quarter and there's nothing unusual in that number. And it's really just in that normal range of around 20% we would expect to see. A move of 30, 40 basis points is not really unusual in and around 20%. But certainly, pleased to post a quarter a little bit about 20%. And hopefully, we can -- we are always focused on doing everything we can to maintain and improve on that while driving better returns.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just thoughts around some of the better efficiencies as you gain experience in  Express and Emerald? Could that be ultimately showing up as a potential positive lift? Or is it just another element that allows you to combat, let's say, rising land cost
componenttext: And just thoughts around some of the better efficiencies as you gain experience in  Express and Emerald? Could that be ultimately showing up as a potential positive lift? Or is it just another element that allows you to combat, let's say, rising land cost and labor cost?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, part of our strategy is to get better everyday in what we do. The margins that we see across the three brands are actually pretty closely clustered together around the company average. And we do expect to get better in every community everyday
componenttext: Certainly, part of our strategy is to get better everyday in what we do. The margins that we see across the three brands are actually pretty closely clustered together around the company average. And we do expect to get better in every community everyday at what we do. And we have seen that. We have seen our margins moving up. And were held through pretty high standard to expect to continue to see those margins, making progress on them everyday. And in a market, Michael, it does continue to improve and grow, there will be cost increases that come along the way and these additional efficiencies that we are able to glean out of the business do help offset those other cost increases.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from the line of Jack Micenko from SAG.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from the line of Jack Micenko from SAG.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to understand the message on backlog conversion a little bit better. So 81% to 84% for the fourth quarter. You did the midpoint of the range this quarter. If I get, if I go 84%, I get to the midpoint of the range, which I guess would mean, if you
componenttext: I wanted to understand the message on backlog conversion a little bit better. So 81% to 84% for the fourth quarter. You did the midpoint of the range this quarter. If I get, if I go 84%, I get to the midpoint of the range, which I guess would mean, if you had a sort of similar result this quarter and the last, you'll be in the sort of, albeit, mentally, it's a narrow range on your deliveries but you'll be at the bottom half. Is that the message? Or is it conservatism on the guidance range? How do we think about that? And then on a broader base, is [indiscernible] handle on the backlog conversion, is that the new Horton norm given the mix, the product mix, is that number sort of stepped up the last couple of years?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jack, there's a lot of fluctuation in our backlog conversion rate and there's a lot of things that can impact that each quarter. But if you look at the last 4 to 5 years on average, our Q3 to Q4 change in our backlog conversion had typically been about fl
componenttext: Jack, there's a lot of fluctuation in our backlog conversion rate and there's a lot of things that can impact that each quarter. But if you look at the last 4 to 5 years on average, our Q3 to Q4 change in our backlog conversion had typically been about flat. So we are saying that it's going to go up a little bit to that 81% to 84% compared to what we did this quarter. I would not tell you that there is a bunch of conservatism baked into that. As you saw this quarter, we delivered at the midpoint of our range. And some of the headlines out there is being called amiss. And that's even though we're right in the dead center of the guidance we provided. So no conservatism on that. We feel good about delivering 81% to 84% and it's a little bit better and we are focused everyday on delivering the best we can and we would like to continue to see a backlog conversion rate in the 80% range. But there will be some quarters that are in the 70s.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: From an operational efficiency and getting better, that's something we look at and strive to improve because that helps with the SG&A leverage, it helps with the inventory turn. Conversion rate is a great metric that determine whether you're actually gett
componenttext: From an operational efficiency and getting better, that's something we look at and strive to improve because that helps with the SG&A leverage, it helps with the inventory turn. Conversion rate is a great metric that determine whether you're actually getting better or not. So we're not going to guide optimistically. We've got a consistent market. We've got a consistent, solid performance. And expect to continue that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. And then your FHA mix from the mortgage company was up a bit year-over-year. The rhetoric from some of the larger banks seems to suggest that they're moving away from that product somewhat with some of the inherent, sort of legacy, legal
componenttext: Okay, thank you. And then your FHA mix from the mortgage company was up a bit year-over-year. The rhetoric from some of the larger banks seems to suggest that they're moving away from that product somewhat with some of the inherent, sort of legacy, legal risks or tail risk to that program. Are you seeing any shift from FHA to private mortgage insurance in your borrower base more granulary? Or is it still pretty stable?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say it's pretty stable. The difference for us is with Express becoming a bigger piece of our mix. Their percentage usage for those buyers of FHA loans is higher than our company average, it's closer to the mid-40s. So that's really the function there.
componenttext: I'd say it's pretty stable. The difference for us is with Express becoming a bigger piece of our mix. Their percentage usage for those buyers of FHA loans is higher than our company average, it's closer to the mid-40s. So that's really the function there.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Susan Maklari from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Susan Maklari from UBS.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've mentioned the fact that you are seeing some more older buyers coming into your Express communities. And as you think about the evolution of Express and maybe some of the demographic trends that we expect to come through, is that something that we c
componenttext: You've mentioned the fact that you are seeing some more older buyers coming into your Express communities. And as you think about the evolution of Express and maybe some of the demographic trends that we expect to come through, is that something that we could see sort of further come long and perhaps maybe even evolved from a marketing or branding perspective down the line?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're certainly focused on all the buyers that are responding to Express. And we are seeing great acceptance of Express in Florida, as Jessica mentioned before, some of the retiree buyers. And we're going to look to meet those buyers and needs to und
componenttext: Yes. We're certainly focused on all the buyers that are responding to Express. And we are seeing great acceptance of Express in Florida, as Jessica mentioned before, some of the retiree buyers. And we're going to look to meet those buyers and needs to understand what exactly what it is they want and put a house on the ground for them at a great value. People that are retiring on fixed income are looking for value in a high-quality, well-built home. That's exactly in the wheelhouse of what we do. And so I think you can expect to see that we're trying to take advantage of every opportunity in front of us, including that buyer demographic.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as we think about some of the labor issues that remain out there and the experience that builders in general are facing, do expect any change outside of the normal seasonality in terms of your spec pace or or your start pace as we go throug
componenttext: Okay. And then as we think about some of the labor issues that remain out there and the experience that builders in general are facing, do expect any change outside of the normal seasonality in terms of your spec pace or or your start pace as we go through in the next few quarters?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are looking at our start pace to just kind of continue as we go seasonally to build some inventory for the spring and to be prepared for a spring selling season next year, hopefully it's good or better than when we just came out of. And we're seeing ce
componenttext: We are looking at our start pace to just kind of continue as we go seasonally to build some inventory for the spring and to be prepared for a spring selling season next year, hopefully it's good or better than when we just came out of. And we're seeing certainly, labor is always a challenging component. Our market positioning, the scale we have in so many of our markets gives us a great advantage in the labor availability front and we watch very closely our build times and our cycle times and we're not seeing an elongation of that. We're feeling our team is doing a great job of managing their trade base.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The absorption per community is a great deal to expand our option lot program. But it is also a great deal to secure and keep the labor force. Because they come in, they start and we build through the communities instead of start, stop, start, stop. And t
componenttext: The absorption per community is a great deal to expand our option lot program. But it is also a great deal to secure and keep the labor force. Because they come in, they start and we build through the communities instead of start, stop, start, stop. And they're always out chasing new job sites. So there is a lot of benefits to what we're doing and that's one of them.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Jon Lovallo from Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Jon Lovallo from Merrill Lynch.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on Southeast conversions, they've been a little bit light year-over-year in the first three quarters. Was there anything in 2015 that made those exceptionally, maybe conversion, exceptionally strong or is there something, something going
componenttext: First question is on Southeast conversions, they've been a little bit light year-over-year in the first three quarters. Was there anything in 2015 that made those exceptionally, maybe conversion, exceptionally strong or is there something, something going on this year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say if there's anything unusual, John, we think we would certainly see very strong absorptions last year that's moderated a little bit this year. But we're still seeing very strong growth and expect very strong growth going forward in the Southeast. T
componenttext: I'd say if there's anything unusual, John, we think we would certainly see very strong absorptions last year that's moderated a little bit this year. But we're still seeing very strong growth and expect very strong growth going forward in the Southeast. They're delivering right in line with our expectations.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, moving on. The valuations across the group have risen in the past couple of weeks in particular. In your conversations with the private builders, are you hearing a general expectation for higher prices on the private side as well on the M&A front?
componenttext: Okay, moving on. The valuations across the group have risen in the past couple of weeks in particular. In your conversations with the private builders, are you hearing a general expectation for higher prices on the private side as well on the M&A front?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We always probably have a bit of the valuation gap at the initial conversations. It takes time. And that's why our bar is pretty high and we're very selective in what we're doing and we're going to look to make the right acquisitions where it makes sense
componenttext: We always probably have a bit of the valuation gap at the initial conversations. It takes time. And that's why our bar is pretty high and we're very selective in what we're doing and we're going to look to make the right acquisitions where it makes sense for us and the numbers work. We're not going to push, fortunately we're in a position. Teams have done a great job in lots and product positioning that we don't feel the need we had to push and drive on them, on making a deal work that otherwise might not. But we haven't seen any specific rise in the past couple of weeks. I mean, that private builder market is not quite as liquid as the public side.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And one last one if I may. The 11.2% to 11.5% gross -- sorry, margin for 2017, is that a homebuilding margin or consolidated pretax?
componenttext: Great. And one last one if I may. The 11.2% to 11.5% gross -- sorry, margin for 2017, is that a homebuilding margin or consolidated pretax?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's consolidated pretax.
componenttext: That's consolidated pretax.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask first about longer term dots on SG&A. So it sounds like based on the preliminary guide for fiscal '17, you'll dip below 9% historically kind of a little bit watermark. So clearly, success at driving absorptions and some of the efficiencies
componenttext: I wanted to ask first about longer term dots on SG&A. So it sounds like based on the preliminary guide for fiscal '17, you'll dip below 9% historically kind of a little bit watermark. So clearly, success at driving absorptions and some of the efficiencies have done wonders for that. If you think about other structural ways to reduce SG&A beyond those levels, we've heard some other builders talk about a couple of different things. Just curious to get your thoughts on, if there's anything else you're exploring outside of just continuing to drive absorptions?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The main driver, Mike, is absorption. So community by community, that's really where our expense structure resides. And as we continue to work to improve our absorptions, then we're able to drive better leverage in our SG&A structure, both in the communit
componenttext: The main driver, Mike, is absorption. So community by community, that's really where our expense structure resides. And as we continue to work to improve our absorptions, then we're able to drive better leverage in our SG&A structure, both in the community and then all throughout our organization. So that -- in each year, we look at what our expectations are to improve on the top line and then we assess how much we can leverage SG&A. But as we expect to grow top line double digit, we should expect to lever SG&A further as well. So yes, that does imply we will get down below 9% and there's not a magic floor there. Each year, if we expect to grow, we would expect to continue to push some more SG&A leverage. Certainly, some of the other things that have been talked about among other builders we're doing a lot of those things as well. We're certainly taking advantage of technology wherever we can. We're looking to be -- to drive ways to be more efficient in all areas of our business. But there's not one magic bullet. There is -- we're looking to do, to get more efficient in every line of our financials. And certainly, those things are part of it as well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then second question, just going back to some of the Express discussion. And so certainly appreciate that kind of first mover advantage has been pretty powerful in terms of even out through next year, you don't have a lot of competition as far as thin
componenttext: And then second question, just going back to some of the Express discussion. And so certainly appreciate that kind of first mover advantage has been pretty powerful in terms of even out through next year, you don't have a lot of competition as far as things that are coming to market. What about, if we look at the land deals that you're looking at today, that would be 2018 or 2019, obviously, people have taken notice of your success at the Express part of the market. So are you showing up and seeing significantly more competition for those types of deals as you look out the next couple of years?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have competition in every factor of everything we do. And I believe ultimately, it just comes down to execution. And right now, our people are out there executing. We are the group that -- or the builder, that, I think, makes the most sense to align wi
componenttext: We have competition in every factor of everything we do. And I believe ultimately, it just comes down to execution. And right now, our people are out there executing. We are the group that -- or the builder, that, I think, makes the most sense to align with. And so we're finding the land deals we need to support the growth that we're seeking. So do I think it's going to become more competitive? Maybe, but it's pretty competitive out there right now. We just got great people doing a great job.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Alex Barron from Housing Research Center.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: I was hoping maybe, I don't know if I missed this, if you mentioned the stats for Emerald Homes, like the ones you mentioned for Express on closings, orders, revenues?

componenttext: Sure. That will be on our supplementary data that we'll post at the end of the call. What we did say during our scripted comments were our homes priced greater than $500,000 were 7% of our homes closed and 16% of our homes sold revenue. If you look at homes just marketed as Emerald, it stayed constant at about 4% of our homes closed. But if you look at that in terms of units, on a trailing 12 month basis, year-over-year, Emerald is actually grown by over 50% for us.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the orders for that same home group?
componenttext: Okay. And the orders for that same home group?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The orders for Emerald were right at 4% as well.
componenttext: The orders for Emerald were right at 4% as well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, I guess as far as your outlook for what you guys are calling affordable homes, or Express, I'm kind of curious to see what your outlook is going forward in terms of community count growth, in terms of just -- do you feel that that's wher
componenttext: Got it. And then, I guess as far as your outlook for what you guys are calling affordable homes, or Express, I'm kind of curious to see what your outlook is going forward in terms of community count growth, in terms of just -- do you feel that that's where the biggest opportunity is at? And I guess the second follow-up question, where are you guys generically think we are in the cycle at this point?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know where we are in the cycle. I can tell you, it feels very good right now. And if you look at the number of people it in the country, look at the housing information, you look at job growth, all of those things are positive. So we feel very goo
componenttext: I don't know where we are in the cycle. I can tell you, it feels very good right now. And if you look at the number of people it in the country, look at the housing information, you look at job growth, all of those things are positive. So we feel very good. And as far as -- you had asked about the Emerald brand, I can tell you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Express, the one where I was interested in, what [indiscernible] is for that going forward.
componenttext: The Express, the one where I was interested in, what [indiscernible] is for that going forward.
