componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Jade Rahmani from KBW.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about M&A and if you could share your thoughts on a potential for larger-sized transaction than recent deals. We noticed your leverage levels are extremely low, which creates some optionality. And regarding leverage, is that based on
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about M&A and if you could share your thoughts on a potential for larger-sized transaction than recent deals. We noticed your leverage levels are extremely low, which creates some optionality. And regarding leverage, is that based on conservatism on the cycle or a change in longer-term view about optimal leverage? Or is it to create this optionality around M&A?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's to create optionality around a lot of things: investing in the business, reducing debt. Having a lot of flexibility in the business is good. With specific regards to M&A, we continue to look at a lot of potential transactions. And we pu
componenttext: Well, I think it's to create optionality around a lot of things: investing in the business, reducing debt. Having a lot of flexibility in the business is good. With specific regards to M&A, we continue to look at a lot of potential transactions. And we pursue those that make the most sense for us, whether they're larger or smaller. It's -- we're kind of neutral to the size of the transaction. If it makes sense at a small transaction, good team, good people, good positioning, we'll be interested. If it's a larger transaction that fits well with us and there's alignment in what makes sense with the other side, we would look at that as well. We're not shedding either off at any point in time.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on your guidance, in terms of the underlying economic expectations, are you assuming sort of a low to mid-single-digit growth rate in existing and new home sales?
componenttext: And just on your guidance, in terms of the underlying economic expectations, are you assuming sort of a low to mid-single-digit growth rate in existing and new home sales?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're assuming kind of more of the same in '17 as what we saw in '16. So when we say our expectations are based on today's housing market conditions, really just more of the same.
componenttext: We're assuming kind of more of the same in '17 as what we saw in '16. So when we say our expectations are based on today's housing market conditions, really just more of the same.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Will Randow from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Will Randow from Citigroup.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know that you guys didn't want to comment on necessarily where you think we are in the cycle, which is definitely fair. But how do you believe you're positioning D.R. Horton within the cycle, given you've been generating free cash for this year and the
componenttext: I know that you guys didn't want to comment on necessarily where you think we are in the cycle, which is definitely fair. But how do you believe you're positioning D.R. Horton within the cycle, given you've been generating free cash for this year and the prior year? And also, how does that influence your view on potential incremental M&A or returning share -- or cash to shareholders, if you will?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Will, I think we're working to stay in a very balanced, flexible position. We're putting ourselves in position to continue to grow while we continue to see the good, stable, healthy market conditions we see today. But as we're utilizing our cash to furthe
componenttext: Will, I think we're working to stay in a very balanced, flexible position. We're putting ourselves in position to continue to grow while we continue to see the good, stable, healthy market conditions we see today. But as we're utilizing our cash to further strengthen our balance sheet, that's giving us even more flexibility to be opportunistic when we see opportunities to invest in whatever form that may be. And then, certainly, if things were not to continue as strong, we're in a very strong position there as well, whether -- and so really, great position to take advantage of M&A opportunities, to invest further in our business. Really, we're in a very good, flexible position at the moment.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one follow-up that's unrelated. In terms of demand pacing through the quarter, did you see any influence from a relatively hot June's inclement weather and a seasonally -- a relatively warm spring, if you will?
componenttext: And just one follow-up that's unrelated. In terms of demand pacing through the quarter, did you see any influence from a relatively hot June's inclement weather and a seasonally -- a relatively warm spring, if you will?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the sales demand side, no, not necessarily. Certainly, on the construction side, when you have dry weather there's no disruptions there. So from that standpoint, that's always positive. But the summer is always hot.
componenttext: On the sales demand side, no, not necessarily. Certainly, on the construction side, when you have dry weather there's no disruptions there. So from that standpoint, that's always positive. But the summer is always hot.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year-End [ph] 2016 Earnings Conference Call of D.R. Horton, America's Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year-End [ph] 2016 Earnings Conference Call of D.R. Horton, America's Builder, the largest builder in the United States. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now turn the call over to Jessica Hansen, Vice President of Investor Relations for D.R. Horton. Please go ahead.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2016 Financial Results.Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securit
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. Welcome to our call to discuss our Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2016 Financial Results.
Before we get started, today's call may include comments that constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes that any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there is no assurance that actual outcomes will not be materially different. All forward-looking statements are based upon information available to D.R. Horton on the date of this conference call, and D.R. Horton does not undertake any obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. Additional information about issues that could lead to material changes in performance is contained in D.R. Horton's annual report on Form 10-K and our most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q, both of which are filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
This morning's earnings release can be found on our website at investor.drhorton.com, and we plan to file our 10-K next week. After the conclusion of the call, we will post updated supplementary historical data to our Investor Relations site on the Presentations section under News and Events for your reference. The supplementary information includes current and historical data on our homebuilding return on inventory, gross margins, changes in active selling communities, product mix and our mortgage operations.
Now I will turn the call over to David Auld, our President and CEO.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jessica, and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I'm pleased to be joined on the call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat, our Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Our D.R. Horton
componenttext:
Thank you, Jessica, and good morning. In addition to Jessica, I'm pleased to be joined on the call by Mike Murray, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and Bill Wheat, our Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Our D.R. Horton team finished strong in 2016. Pretax income for the fourth quarter increased 28% to $433 million on $3.7 billion of revenue. And our pretax operating margin improved 90 basis points to 11.6%. For the year, we delivered results in line with our original guidance we shared last summer, with consolidated pretax income increasing 20% to $1.4 billion on $12.2 billion of revenue. We closed 40,309 homes this year, which is an increase of 3,661 homes or 10% over last year. Our consolidated pretax margin for the full year of 2016 improved 70 basis points to 11.1%. Our return on inventory improved 260 basis points in 2016 to 15.4%. During the fourth quarter, we generated $529 million of cash from operations, bringing our total cash generated from operations to $618 million for the year and to $1.3 billion over the past 2 years. These results reflect consistent strong performance across our broad geographic footprint and diverse product offerings. Our continued strategic focus is to [ph] this double-digit annual growth in both our revenue and pretax profits while generating positive cash flows and improved returns. With a sales backlog of 11,475 homes at the end of September; positive sales trends in October and well-stocked supply of land, lots and homes; and the launch of our Freedom Homes brand, we are well positioned and looking forward to 2017. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Net income for the fourth quarter increased 19% to $284 million or $0.75 per diluted share compared to $239 million or $0.64 per diluted share in the year ago quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 28% to $433 million in the fourth quarter comp
componenttext:
Net income for the fourth quarter increased 19% to $284 million or $0.75 per diluted share compared to $239 million or $0.64 per diluted share in the year ago quarter. Our consolidated pretax income increased 28% to $433 million in the fourth quarter compared to $339 million in the year ago quarter. And homebuilding pretax income increased 34% to $405 million compared to $302 million in the prior year quarter. 
Our backlog conversion rate for the fourth quarter was 83%, near the high end of the range we guided to on our third quarter call. As a result, our fourth quarter home sales revenues increased 19% to $3.6 billion on 12,247 homes closed, up from $3.1 billion on 10,576 homes closed in the year ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was $297,000, up 3% compared to the prior year due to an increase in our average sales price per square foot. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the fourth quarter, our homes sold increased 3% to 8,744 homes. On a 5% decline in our average active selling communities, our sales absorptions strongly improved by 8% over last year. Absorptions were up in 5 of our 6 regions. The value of our net sal
componenttext:
In the fourth quarter, our homes sold increased 3% to 8,744 homes. On a 5% decline in our average active selling communities, our sales absorptions strongly improved by 8% over last year. Absorptions were up in 5 of our 6 regions. The value of our net sales orders in the fourth quarter increased 7% from the year ago quarter to $2.6 billion. Our average sales price on net sales orders increased 4% to $299,800. Our fourth quarter cancellation rate was 28%, in line with the year ago quarter. The value of our backlog increased 9% from a year ago to $3.4 billion, with an average sales price per home of $299,600 and homes in backlog increased 8% to 11,475 homes. 
We are very pleased with our current sales pace and October sales were in line with our fiscal 2017 business plan, supporting our expectations for the year. Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: As announced during the fourth quarter, we are adding another brand to our product line-up, Freedom Homes, offering a low-maintenance lifestyle at an affordable price for active adult buyers who want to live in an age-restricted or age-targeted community.
componenttext:
As announced during the fourth quarter, we are adding another brand to our product line-up, Freedom Homes, offering a low-maintenance lifestyle at an affordable price for active adult buyers who want to live in an age-restricted or age-targeted community. Early customer response to Freedom Homes has been positive. 
We are currently operating Freedom Homes in 8 markets and 7 states and expect to have Freedom communities opened in at least 1/3 of our 78 operating markets by the end of fiscal 2017. 
As we work towards completion of our Express Homes rollout in fiscal 2017, we are excited about the expansion of Express into our Western markets, where customer response has been just as strong as in our early markets. In the fourth quarter, entry-level homes marketed under our Express Homes brand accounted for 28% of our homes sold, 29% of homes closed and 20% of home sales sold revenue. And for the year, they accounted for 27% of homes sold, 26% of homes closed and 18% of home sales revenue. 
We also remain dedicated to offering homes for higher-end move-up and luxury buyers under both our D.R. Horton and Emerald Homes brands. In the fourth quarter, homes priced greater than $500,000 were 7% of our homes closed and 19% of our home sales revenue. And for the year, they accounted for 7% of homes closed and 17% of home sales revenue. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the fourth quarter was 20.5%, up 20 basis points sequentially from the third quarter and up 60 basis points from the prior year quarter. The sequential improvement in our gross margin was primarily due to c
componenttext: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the fourth quarter was 20.5%, up 20 basis points sequentially from the third quarter and up 60 basis points from the prior year quarter. The sequential improvement in our gross margin was primarily due to controlling cost increases while also reducing incentives or raising prices in communities where we are achieving our targeted absorptions. In the current housing environment, we expect our gross margins to continue to remain in a relatively consistent range of 19% to 21%. While balancing pace and price in each of our communities to optimize returns on our inventory investments, we have been able to achieve a gross margin slightly higher than 20% over the last few [ph] quarters. We may still experience quarterly fluctuations ranging from 19% to 21% due to product and geographic mix, purchase accounting and the relative impact of warranty, litigation and interest cost. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the fourth quarter, SG&A expense as a percentage of homebuilding revenues was 8.8%, flat with the prior year quarter. SG&A expense for the quarter included $15.5 million to write-off an acquired tradename that we are no longer using and to increase our
componenttext: In the fourth quarter, SG&A expense as a percentage of homebuilding revenues was 8.8%, flat with the prior year quarter. SG&A expense for the quarter included $15.5 million to write-off an acquired tradename that we are no longer using and to increase our legal reserves for a recent court [ph] decision, which we plan to appeal. Homebuilding SG&A for the full year improved 20 basis points to 9.3% compared to 9.5% in 2015 as our increased revenues improved the leverage of our fixed overhead cost. We remain focused on controlling our SG&A while ensuring that infrastructure adequately supports our growth and we expect to further leverage our SG&A in 2017. Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Financial services pretax income in the fourth quarter was $28 million. For the year, financial services pretax income was $89.1 million on $296 million of revenues, representing a 30% pretax operating margin. Our financial services profits for the fourth
componenttext:
Financial services pretax income in the fourth quarter was $28 million. For the year, financial services pretax income was $89.1 million on $296 million of revenues, representing a 30% pretax operating margin. Our financial services profits for the fourth quarter and fiscal year decreased from the prior year, primarily due to an increase in our estimated loan loss reserves in the fourth quarter and increased overhead cost to comply with additional regulations. 
94% of our mortgage company's loan originations during the fourth quarter related to homes closed by our homebuilding operations and our mortgage company handled the financing for 57% of our home buyers. FHA and VA loans accounted for 48% of the mortgage company's volume compared to 50% in the year ago quarter. Borrowers [ph] originating loans with our mortgage company this quarter had an average FICO score of 718 and an average loan-to-value ratio of 89%. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: During the quarter, our total number of homes in inventory decreased by 9%, a normal seasonal trend after our strongest home closing quarter of the year. We finished the year with 23,100 homes in inventory, of which, 1,600 were models, 11,800 of our total
componenttext:
During the quarter, our total number of homes in inventory decreased by 9%, a normal seasonal trend after our strongest home closing quarter of the year. We finished the year with 23,100 homes in inventory, of which, 1,600 were models, 11,800 of our total homes were spec homes, with 8,300 in various stages of construction and 3,500 completed. Compared to a year ago, we have 17% more homes in inventory, which places us in a strong position at the start of the year to achieve double-digit growth in revenues in 2017. 
Our fourth quarter investment in lots, land and development totaled $747 million, of which, $467 million was to replenish finished lots and land and $280 million was for land development. For the year, our total investment totaled $2.7 billion, an increase of 23% from 2015. We plan to increase our investments to replenish our land and lot supply in 2017 at a rate to support our expected growth in revenues. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: At September 30, 2016, our land and lot portfolio consisted of 205,000 lots, of which 113,000 or 55% are owned and 92,000 or 45% are controlled through option contracts. 75,000 of our total lots controlled are finished, of which 30,000 are owned and 45,00
componenttext: At September 30, 2016, our land and lot portfolio consisted of 205,000 lots, of which 113,000 or 55% are owned and 92,000 or 45% are controlled through option contracts. 75,000 of our total lots controlled are finished, of which 30,000 are owned and 45,000 are optioned. Consistent with our focus on building strong relationships with land developers, our optioned lot position has increased 65% from a year ago while our overall lot position increased 18%. Our 205,000 lot portfolio is a strong competitive advantage in the current housing market and a sufficient lot supply to support solid growth in both sales and closings. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our inactive land held for development of $138 million at the end of the year represents 7,300 lots, down 20% from June and down 34% from a year ago. We continue to work through each of our remaining inactive land parcels to improve cash flows and returns
componenttext:
Our inactive land held for development of $138 million at the end of the year represents 7,300 lots, down 20% from June and down 34% from a year ago. We continue to work through each of our remaining inactive land parcels to improve cash flows and returns and we expect that our land held for development will continue to decline. 
During the fourth quarter, we recorded $4 million in land option charges for write-offs of earnest money deposits and due diligence costs for projects that we do not intend to pursue. We also recorded $11.4 million of inventory impairment charges, the majority of which were in our Southwest and East regions. This charge is primarily related to strategic decisions to sell land. We will continue to evaluate our inventories for potential impairment, which may result in future impairment charges, but the timing and magnitude of these charges will fluctuate. 
During the fourth quarter, we also recorded a goodwill impairment charge of $7.2 million related to one of our operating divisions in our Southeast region. Our total goodwill balance after this impairment is $80 million. Mike?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: In September, we acquired the homebuilding operations of Wilson Parker Homes for $91.9 million of cash, which includes a holdback payment and an estimated postclosing adjustment. Wilson Parker primarily operates in Atlanta and Augusta, Georgia and Raleigh
componenttext: In September, we acquired the homebuilding operations of Wilson Parker Homes for $91.9 million of cash, which includes a holdback payment and an estimated postclosing adjustment. Wilson Parker primarily operates in Atlanta and Augusta, Georgia and Raleigh, North Carolina. The assets acquired included approximately 380 homes in inventory, 490 lots and control of approximately 1,850 additional lots through option contracts. We also acquired a sales order backlog of 308 homes valued at $74.1 million. Our fourth quarter results include 66 net sales orders and 81 homes closed from Wilson Parker, subsequent to the acquisition date. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: During the fourth quarter, we generated $529 million of cash flow from operations. For the full year, we generated $618 million, above the high end of our guidance range. At September 30, our homebuilding liquidity included $1.3 billion of unrestricted ho
componenttext:
During the fourth quarter, we generated $529 million of cash flow from operations. For the full year, we generated $618 million, above the high end of our guidance range. At September 30, our homebuilding liquidity included $1.3 billion of unrestricted homebuilding cash and $882 million available capacity on our revolving credit facility. Our homebuilding leverage improved 690 basis points from a year ago to 29.2%. The balance of our public notes outstanding at September 30 was $2.8 billion, and we have a total of 350 million of senior notes that will mature in fiscal 2017. We finished the year with a shareholder's equity balance of $6.8 billion and book value per common share of $18.21, up 14% from a year ago. 
Our priorities for cash flow utilization center around being opportunistic while remaining disciplined. Our top priorities for fiscal 2017 include: investing in our homebuilding business where opportunities to generate acceptable returns exist; business acquisitions to further consolidate market share; paying off debt at maturity; and consistent dividends to shareholders. 
Based on our solid balance sheet, liquidity, profitability and cash flows, our Board of Directors increased our quarterly cash dividend by 25% to $0.10 per share. We currently expect to distribute approximately $150 million in dividends to our shareholders during fiscal 2017. Jessica?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking forward, our expectations for next year are consistent with what we shared on our July call and are based on today's housing market conditions. In fiscal 2017, we still expect to generate a consolidated pretax margin of 11.2% to 11.5%. We also exp
componenttext:
Looking forward, our expectations for next year are consistent with what we shared on our July call and are based on today's housing market conditions. In fiscal 2017, we still expect to generate a consolidated pretax margin of 11.2% to 11.5%. We also expect to generate consolidated revenues of between $13.4 billion and $13.8 million and to close between 43,500 and 45,500 homes. We anticipate our home sales gross margin for the full year of fiscal 2017 will be around 20%, with potential quarterly fluctuations that may range from 19% to 21%. We estimate that our annual homebuilding SG&A expense will be approximately 9.0%, with the first 2 quarters of the year higher than 9% and the third and fourth quarters lower than 9%. We expect our annual financial services operating margin to be around 30%, with the first 2 quarters of the year lower than 30% and the third and fourth quarters higher than 30%. We are forecasting a fiscal 2017 income tax rate of approximately 35% and an annual average diluted share count of approximately 380 million shares. We also continue to expect to generate positive cash flow from operations for the third consecutive year in a range of approximately $300 million to $500 million. 
Our fiscal 2017 results will be significantly impacted by the spring selling season and we plan to update our expectations as necessary each quarter as visibility to the spring and the full year becomes clearer. 
For the first fiscal quarter of 2017, we expect that our number of homes closed will approximate a beginning backlog conversion rate in the range of 76% to 80%. We anticipate our first quarter home sales gross margin will be around 20%, and we expect our homebuilding SG&A in the first quarter to be in the range of 10% to 10.2% of homebuilding revenues. David?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: In closing, the strength of our team and operating platform across the country allowed us to deliver full year 2016 results in line with the guidance we provided at the start of last year. While growing our revenue and pretax profit at a double-digit pace
componenttext:
In closing, the strength of our team and operating platform across the country allowed us to deliver full year 2016 results in line with the guidance we provided at the start of last year. While growing our revenue and pretax profit at a double-digit pace again this year, we generated $618 million of positive cash flow from operations and improved our annual return on inventory by 260 basis points to 15.4%. We remain focused on growing both our revenue and pretax profits at a double-digit annual pace while continuing to generate positive cash flows and improved returns. We are well positioned to do so with our solid balance sheet, industry leading market share, broad geographic footprint, diversified product offerings across our D.R. Horton, Emerald, Express and Freedom brands, attractive finished lot and land position and most importantly, our outstanding team across the country. We'd like to thank all of our employees for their hard work and remarkable accomplishments this year. And we look forward to working together to continue growing and improving our operations in 2017. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. We will now host questions. Thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question today is coming from -- our first question today is coming from Alan Ratner from Zelman and Associates.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question today is coming from -- our first question today is coming from Alan Ratner from Zelman and Associates.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my first question, just thinking about the job you guys have done on the entry level and you guys have had a tremendous first mover advantage there over the last year or 2. And as I listen to all the other builders on their conference calls this q
componenttext: I guess my first question, just thinking about the job you guys have done on the entry level and you guys have had a tremendous first mover advantage there over the last year or 2. And as I listen to all the other builders on their conference calls this quarter, almost everybody is talking about entry level, increasing their exposure there, opening new communities. And when I look at your order numbers this quarter, which came in lower than where you've been trending in recent quarters, curious if you're seeing any increased competition there that might have affected that sales pace? May be some more incentives, as calendar reporting quarter builders kind of gear up for some closings there? With your guidance staying unchanged, it sounds like October bounced back. So any more color you can give on the sales pace and the competition you're seeing on entry level would be great. Thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alan, this is David Auld. From a competitive standpoint, I feel like we're as well or better positioned today as we were starting last year. So I think it's -- fourth quarter sales number, we just had a lot going on. And the tough comp here before and it
componenttext: Alan, this is David Auld. From a competitive standpoint, I feel like we're as well or better positioned today as we were starting last year. So I think it's -- fourth quarter sales number, we just had a lot going on. And the tough comp here before and it was right in the -- it put us right in where we felt we'd be for the year. So I think if we look at is October, October looks good. So...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I appreciate that, David. And I think you mentioned, I might have misheard this, but your community count was down about 5% year-over-year, if I was correct? I know you've been talking about that growth resuming there to something more in the low
componenttext: Got it. I appreciate that, David. And I think you mentioned, I might have misheard this, but your community count was down about 5% year-over-year, if I was correct? I know you've been talking about that growth resuming there to something more in the low to mid-single-digit range. So just curious if that came in below your expectations in the quarter and when you would expect to see that inflect positively?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alan, you're correct. It was down -- our community count was down 5% year-over-year and it was down 2% sequentially. It's one of the hardest things for us to predict, so we don't give formal guidance on community count. As we continue to get more informat
componenttext: Alan, you're correct. It was down -- our community count was down 5% year-over-year and it was down 2% sequentially. It's one of the hardest things for us to predict, so we don't give formal guidance on community count. As we continue to get more information and we are into November of the year right now, we expect our community count to be relatively stable versus the current levels which would infer that it would continue to be down on a year-over-year basis and somewhere below the mid-single-digit range like we experienced this quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Alan, this is David. Our expectation is double-digit growth. And I can tell you that the operating plan going forward supports the guidance we've given you. So -- and the expectation again into next year. So ...
componenttext: And Alan, this is David. Our expectation is double-digit growth. And I can tell you that the operating plan going forward supports the guidance we've given you. So -- and the expectation again into next year. So ...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our targets are all based on an annual basis. So we're really focused on that double-digit growth and revenues and pretax profits annually. Quarter-to-quarter, you have some variation.
componenttext: And our targets are all based on an annual basis. So we're really focused on that double-digit growth and revenues and pretax profits annually. Quarter-to-quarter, you have some variation.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Ken Zener from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Ken Zener from KeyBanc.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: So can you -- the [indiscernible] rate normally kind of creeps up in the fourth quarter consistent with what we saw last year. But your -- I'm just trying to tease out labor constraints and all these types of things because it seems like while your [indis
componenttext: So can you -- the [indiscernible] rate normally kind of creeps up in the fourth quarter consistent with what we saw last year. But your -- I'm just trying to tease out labor constraints and all these types of things because it seems like while your [indiscernible] backlog conversion, if your user units is under construction [indiscernible], you're actually coming in a bit lower closing these as a percent of units under construction than you normally do. Is there something that's impacting that trend? Seems like you would've had perhaps more units? I'm not sure. Please comment on that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We hit the high end of our guidance range. So I would say we delivered on what we anticipated and we are excited about the fact we have 17% more homes under construction today going into the year to position us very well to deliver on the targets for 2017
componenttext: We hit the high end of our guidance range. So I would say we delivered on what we anticipated and we are excited about the fact we have 17% more homes under construction today going into the year to position us very well to deliver on the targets for 2017. But Q4 was right in line with the guidance we gave.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm saying for 1Q.
componenttext: I'm saying for 1Q.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016

componenttext: There is 76% to 80% backlog conversion. It's about [indiscernible] we experienced last year. And what we expect to do it in Q1 which is a nice increase on a year-over-year basis in terms of absolute units.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016

componenttext: Last year was [indiscernible] -- last year Q1 in fiscal 2016 Q1, was a 76% backlog conversion rate. And with this implied conversion rate, that would imply high single digit to low double-digit growth in Q1 versus last year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, well, I'll follow-up on that. But then I guess, again for the order pace as we look at seasonally for [indiscernible] seems like it came in just a little lighter than your normal seasonality and I need to see your supplemental today. But certainly c
componenttext: Okay, well, I'll follow-up on that. But then I guess, again for the order pace as we look at seasonally for [indiscernible] seems like it came in just a little lighter than your normal seasonality and I need to see your supplemental today. But certainly compared to '15, '14, and '13, it was a little lower. Was there anything -- was there any one region that was kind of driving that? And I know a new supplemental, you have that. I'm just wondering if can publicly comment on that before the supplemental comes out.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we commented that 5 of our 6 of our regions were up in terms of those absorptions. And so really, no, there wasn't really one region that sticks out at all. We're making sure that this time of the year we are positioning ourselves with our inventory
componenttext: Well, we commented that 5 of our 6 of our regions were up in terms of those absorptions. And so really, no, there wasn't really one region that sticks out at all. We're making sure that this time of the year we are positioning ourselves with our inventory levels and community. By community, to be prepared to deliver on what we're going to do next year. And in each community, they deliver the closings that we expected in the quarter and we are in the position we expected to be to deliver fiscal '17.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only reason we were down in our Southwest region, which is our smallest operating region, is only a couple of markets, the biggest one being Phoenix, which we talked about the last couple of quarters we're repositioning and excited about introduci
componenttext: And the only reason we were down in our Southwest region, which is our smallest operating region, is only a couple of markets, the biggest one being Phoenix, which we talked about the last couple of quarters we're repositioning and excited about introducing Express into that market. So we do expect our absorptions to start to pick up. But this quarter, that was the only region that we saw a decline in our absorption. So very excited with what we continue to see across the country.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our question is coming today from Stephen East from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our question is coming today from Stephen East from Wells Fargo.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one last question on the orders trend or a couple of questions on the orders front. Could you give us some -- could you quantify to some degree what October looks like, maybe either in that, in percentage terms or versus the fiscal fourth quarter? An
componenttext: Just one last question on the orders trend or a couple of questions on the orders front. Could you give us some -- could you quantify to some degree what October looks like, maybe either in that, in percentage terms or versus the fiscal fourth quarter? And then when you look at the fiscal fourth quarter, it was the easiest comp that you had in the year and you had some pretty good growth rates the prior quarters. As you look at the market, what do you think was changing versus may be the last 2 or 3 quarters, the growth rates that you posted?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, with regard to our October sales, we feel very good about our October sales. We were up over the prior year and in line with where we thought we'd be and that's definitely supporting the outlook we have for the year. In terms of underlying market
componenttext: Stephen, with regard to our October sales, we feel very good about our October sales. We were up over the prior year and in line with where we thought we'd be and that's definitely supporting the outlook we have for the year. In terms of underlying market factors, we're not seeing significant changes. We continue to see both, in looking at the numbers as well as talking with field, visiting the field operations, continued strong demand across the brands. And we are not, in any way, alarmed. We are, in fact, very encouraged and positive about the way '17 looks and our positioning for '17.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question I had for you, your lot option strategy, you put a lot more under option. As you look at moving forward, I assume you prefer to continue to do that. But as you look at the market in actuality, what's that market giving y
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question I had for you, your lot option strategy, you put a lot more under option. As you look at moving forward, I assume you prefer to continue to do that. But as you look at the market in actuality, what's that market giving you? Do you -- can you grow that as a percentage of options meaningfully in 2017? Or was this something that was just opportunistic that came through? And then could you just talk a little bit about what the trademark was and why that transpired?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen with regard to the option contracts. We did have a tremendous progress we've been making in that program. It's not any one opportunistic situation. It's been market by market, operating division by operating division, working with local developers
componenttext: Stephen with regard to the option contracts. We did have a tremendous progress we've been making in that program. It's not any one opportunistic situation. It's been market by market, operating division by operating division, working with local developers to improve our option lot portfolio. We made a 65% increase this year over last year. I don't think we'll see that kind of growth going forward in the option position. But I do think we're going to get closer to a 50-50 balance from our 55-45 balance option today. I'll let Bill talk to that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Stephen with respect to the tradename, this is related to one of the acquisitions that we did 2 or 3 years ago. We have recently changed over all of those communities to our core brands, to our Horton Express brands and so we're no longer using that n
componenttext: And Stephen with respect to the tradename, this is related to one of the acquisitions that we did 2 or 3 years ago. We have recently changed over all of those communities to our core brands, to our Horton Express brands and so we're no longer using that name so we wrote off the remaining balance that we had not yet been amortized. So pretty ordinary course of business as we integrate acquisitions over the years following the acquisition date.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Stephen, on this -- we're just being good partners for the people that have the ability to put lots on the ground. And when we look at our kind of our driving philosophy on flag by flag [indiscernible] absorptions, I mean, that makes underwriting land
componenttext: And Stephen, on this -- we're just being good partners for the people that have the ability to put lots on the ground. And when we look at our kind of our driving philosophy on flag by flag [indiscernible] absorptions, I mean, that makes underwriting land and lot option contracts a much easier program for the people that are borrowing money to put the lot [indiscernible]. So we're just being nice with them. And we're going to continue to be nice.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Tim for Nishu. Thanks for taking my question. My first question is regarding the backlog conversion ratio. So it seems to be up year-over-year in the fourth quarter and you're guiding for it to be up in the first quarter of '17 as well. S
componenttext: This is actually Tim for Nishu. Thanks for taking my question. My first question is regarding the backlog conversion ratio. So it seems to be up year-over-year in the fourth quarter and you're guiding for it to be up in the first quarter of '17 as well. So some of your peers have been mentioning labor shortages being a tailwind or a headwind to this metric rather. But it doesn't seem to be the case for you in 4Q and apparently not in 1Q. I just wanted to dig a little bit into this and mainly regarding the Express versus the D.R. Horton brand communities, just because assuming that the Horton -- sorry, the Express communities have a bit quicker cycle times, could you just explain a bit of this mix to us and what do you expect trending into '17? Thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a lot in that question and I'll take some parts of it. Looking at labor, certainly labor is tight across the markets. We feel that our market positioning, the leading market positions that we have give us access to great labor partners. And we are able
componenttext: So a lot in that question and I'll take some parts of it. Looking at labor, certainly labor is tight across the markets. We feel that our market positioning, the leading market positions that we have give us access to great labor partners. And we are able to provide a lot of work for those. As David mentioned before, running a consistent absorption space, community by community helps us in negotiating and giving that labor a secured place to go to work everyday. But we do hear that our guys are working very hard everyday to secure adequate labor, provide quality homes. And we monitor our build times brand by brand. And we -- and that would be the best way we will have to see if we were having a global impact on labor shortages in our deliveries and we're not seeing our build times really lengthen our cycle times extended for how long it takes us to build the house. So we're very pleased. Our guys are doing a great job and gals are doing a great job performing in that regard.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Tim, in addition to being very focused on building that option lot position, we have a focus on improving our backlog conversion and that's what you're starting to see come through. And a big part of that is our Express brand. But we're doing better i
componenttext: And Tim, in addition to being very focused on building that option lot position, we have a focus on improving our backlog conversion and that's what you're starting to see come through. And a big part of that is our Express brand. But we're doing better in Horton as well and we're going to continue to try to drive a better backlog conversion as we move forward, although there can be some choppiness to that from quarter-to-quarter as well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quickly just to clarify. Was both Express and Horton up year-over-year on the backlog conversion by brand percentage in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Just quickly just to clarify. Was both Express and Horton up year-over-year on the backlog conversion by brand percentage in the fourth quarter?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't -- we don't have that in front of us, right now Tim, but I'll happy to take a look at it and get back to you.
componenttext: We haven't -- we don't have that in front of us, right now Tim, but I'll happy to take a look at it and get back to you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, no problem, thank you though. and then my second question, just digging a bit into the margin guidance for financial services revenue. It seems to be -- it's down year-over-year from '16 to '15 and you essentially are expecting it to be flat in
componenttext: All right, no problem, thank you though. and then my second question, just digging a bit into the margin guidance for financial services revenue. It seems to be -- it's down year-over-year from '16 to '15 and you essentially are expecting it to be flat in '17. What was the main factor that influenced the reduction year-over-year into '16 and what gives you the confidence that these margins will stabilize into '17?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really, 2 primary things, Tim. Last year, we saw abnormally high margins in the financial services business as the industry started to price in a lot of the extra cost that were coming related to regulations. And this year, those costs came in. So we saw
componenttext: Really, 2 primary things, Tim. Last year, we saw abnormally high margins in the financial services business as the industry started to price in a lot of the extra cost that were coming related to regulations. And this year, those costs came in. So we saw a significant increase in compliance cost and our business there as we implemented all the new rules and regulations and that certainly impacted our overhead costs there as well. And then one another big factor for us, more specifically, we did have an incremental increase in our reserves for our loan portfolio fiscal '16. And in fiscal '15 we actually have reductions in those reserves. So you had an opposite effect in our overall margins in the business versus -- '15 versus '16. But really, the run rate of around 30% has been historically a very normal operating range for financial services. So we feel like in fiscal '17, we shall be back to a normal level.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Stephen Kim from Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Stephen Kim from Evercore.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes, you reiterated your outlook for double-digit growth and I guess I just wanted to make sure, does that include an assumption for ASP growth? And in that vein, I was wondering if you can give us a little more clarity as to whether the community coun
componenttext: So yes, you reiterated your outlook for double-digit growth and I guess I just wanted to make sure, does that include an assumption for ASP growth? And in that vein, I was wondering if you can give us a little more clarity as to whether the community count growth in the quarter was more hampered at high end communities or lower end communities or were there any particular regions that sort of stand on in terms of where you're having a little bit more harder time than others in growing the community count. Thanks.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, as you look at our guidance for next year, our unit growth for the range there is an 8% [ph] to 13% growth and the revenue number is a 10% to 14% growth. So there will be very slight assumption of price appreciation which is about what we've seen
componenttext: Stephen, as you look at our guidance for next year, our unit growth for the range there is an 8% [ph] to 13% growth and the revenue number is a 10% to 14% growth. So there will be very slight assumption of price appreciation which is about what we've seen very low single-digit at best. So not much but a little bit. And then the second part we...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of our community count, we've seen that decline pretty much across the board which is what caused our 5% decline on a year-over-year basis on an average basis. It's in line with what our business plan looks like and we continue to drive bett
componenttext: Yes, in terms of our community count, we've seen that decline pretty much across the board which is what caused our 5% decline on a year-over-year basis on an average basis. It's in line with what our business plan looks like and we continue to drive better absorptions out of the vast majority of our communities which is why we continue to see our sales improvement. And the majority of our business plan in fiscal '17 is just like '16, we do expect to continue to drive better absorption out of the majority of our flags. Express will continue to help us with doing that and the launch and the beginning roll out of Freedom Homes, which is a very similar business model to Express, is going to help as well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, it's David Auld. Our long-term goal is double-digit growth. So we are going to be positioning to maximize our returns and generating double-digit growth. So the community count is going to balance out as our absorptions has picked up, it's coming
componenttext: Stephen, it's David Auld. Our long-term goal is double-digit growth. So we are going to be positioning to maximize our returns and generating double-digit growth. So the community count is going to balance out as our absorptions has picked up, it's coming down. But as a cycle in the market, we will be adding communities to support that growth.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's encouraging. With respect to the cycle, I was wondering if you can comment on one other issue which relates to a build-to-order versus more of a spec model approach to the production. We've heard some people say that a build-to-order model h
componenttext: Great, that's encouraging. With respect to the cycle, I was wondering if you can comment on one other issue which relates to a build-to-order versus more of a spec model approach to the production. We've heard some people say that a build-to-order model has certain advantages. And I was curious if you could comment on your opinion, generally, as to the advantages of a spec model versus a build-to-order. And if there's any sort of perspective on where we are in the cycle that might inform your buyers [ph] one way or the other?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, to me, build-to-order spec depends on where you are in a cycle and what is the biggest constraint in the market. If selling the house is the biggest constraint, then you're going to do whatever the buyers want you to do, and it pushes you into that
componenttext: Well, to me, build-to-order spec depends on where you are in a cycle and what is the biggest constraint in the market. If selling the house is the biggest constraint, then you're going to do whatever the buyers want you to do, and it pushes you into that build-to-order model. But if labor is the biggest constraint, location and land position is the biggest constraint, then you're trying to create the most efficiency you can and best value you can for the buyer and that is a production start and spec model. But if you look at our margins over the last 2 years, 3 years, I mean, we're most stable in the industry and it's because we're very disciplined and when we start, when we sell and when we close these homes. And create the most efficient, maximize the labor trade that we have. And it's why we are doing a better job than our competitors out there. So ...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jason in for Mike. I was hoping you can give a little more color on the pricing incentive trends that you saw there occur through the quarter across different product lines. How much is your pricing up [ph] versus your Atlantic construction cost and
componenttext: It's Jason in for Mike. I was hoping you can give a little more color on the pricing incentive trends that you saw there occur through the quarter across different product lines. How much is your pricing up [ph] versus your Atlantic construction cost and which market do you currently have the most pricing power in it right now as you're looking across your footprint?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've continued to see a nice increase in our revenues per square foot, Jason. They were up about 4%, both year-over-year and sequentially and our cost, both year-over-year and sequentially, were only up about 2%. So that is part of the gross margin pick
componenttext: We've continued to see a nice increase in our revenues per square foot, Jason. They were up about 4%, both year-over-year and sequentially and our cost, both year-over-year and sequentially, were only up about 2%. So that is part of the gross margin pick up you seeing, being offset by slightly higher land costs flowing through. But really, it's across the board. You continue to see our Express price point move up, primarily driven by a change in the mix as we roll in some of those Western markets, as I mentioned in the scripted comments. But we do have pricing power out there today because there's a lack of inventory, particularly at the entry-level price points.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: And right now, Jason, we continue to see very consistent margins across all of our brands. They're all in a very tight range around our company average. So no major differential in margins, cost or pricing dynamics, really in any of our brands right now.
componenttext: And right now, Jason, we continue to see very consistent margins across all of our brands. They're all in a very tight range around our company average. So no major differential in margins, cost or pricing dynamics, really in any of our brands right now.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just in terms of the gross margin, obviously, a nice improvement from last year. I want to see a much of that was driven by mix from a geographic or product standpoint? And then as you have been underwriting new land deals, have you
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just in terms of the gross margin, obviously, a nice improvement from last year. I want to see a much of that was driven by mix from a geographic or product standpoint? And then as you have been underwriting new land deals, have you been able to maintain a consistent underwriting standard or have there been any adjustments as you look across the platform?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really haven't seen a big differentiator in the driver of margins. We've seen kind of general improvement across the platform. As David mentioned before, our brands have produced very consistent margins close to the company average. With regard to our
componenttext: We really haven't seen a big differentiator in the driver of margins. We've seen kind of general improvement across the platform. As David mentioned before, our brands have produced very consistent margins close to the company average. With regard to our underwriting hurdles, we've maintained the same underwriting hurdles we've had and our primary focus is to return on the inventory investment that we'll have in the community and a return of the initial community capital in 24 months that we've been talking about for a few years now. So we've been able to maintain those disciplines and still invest significantly in replenishing our land and lot supply.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from John Lovallo from Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from John Lovallo from Merrill Lynch.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first question I had was just on south-central orders being down slightly year-over-year. I was wondering if you could just give a little more color by major city in Texas?
componenttext: The first question I had was just on south-central orders being down slightly year-over-year. I was wondering if you could just give a little more color by major city in Texas?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Overall, Texas has been strong for several years now. And especially the Dallas-Fort Worth area, certainly stands out, continues to be at very strong level. Certainly, the growth rate has moderated versus where we were but still in a very -- maintaining a
componenttext: Overall, Texas has been strong for several years now. And especially the Dallas-Fort Worth area, certainly stands out, continues to be at very strong level. Certainly, the growth rate has moderated versus where we were but still in a very -- maintaining at a very strong level. Our sales in Houston, the second largest in Texas, it was up year-over-year. So we've continued to see that at a very strong level as we continue to move back down the price curve and making sure that we are saying at an affordable level in the Houston market. Austin and San Antonio, the other 2 major markets, also just very solid, consistent results and when you're comparing versus where those cities and where the state of Texas was last year, that's at a very strong level of performance.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then if we think about the gross margin, just curious what you're expecting in terms of purchase accounting impact from Wilson?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then if we think about the gross margin, just curious what you're expecting in terms of purchase accounting impact from Wilson?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very minimal. If you look at our supplemental information, we've got really no quarters more than about a 10 to 20 basis point impact and certainly don't expect any more than that going forward as well.
componenttext: Very minimal. If you look at our supplemental information, we've got really no quarters more than about a 10 to 20 basis point impact and certainly don't expect any more than that going forward as well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016

componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Jack Micenko from AIG.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the mortgage side. I think it's 57 capture and a 48 FHA, VA for the company overall, right? Wondering if you could break that out a little bit more on Express? Are you capturing more on the Express buyer? And I know there's been obviously some loan lim
componenttext: On the mortgage side. I think it's 57 capture and a 48 FHA, VA for the company overall, right? Wondering if you could break that out a little bit more on Express? Are you capturing more on the Express buyer? And I know there's been obviously some loan limit issues across the country. But is your FHA percentage higher at Express or lower than the company average?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jack. The FHA percentage is higher. I don't have the specific number in front of me and I don't have the capture rate for Express in front of me. But I do believe that it's higher than the company average as well. I'll be happy to take a look at tha
componenttext: Sure, Jack. The FHA percentage is higher. I don't have the specific number in front of me and I don't have the capture rate for Express in front of me. But I do believe that it's higher than the company average as well. I'll be happy to take a look at that and get back to you after the call.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then switching over to Freedom. I'd imagine that's a different, obviously, a different buyer profile. So how are they financing? Is it heavier cash? Is it too soon to tell? Or is there anything -- is there anything noteworthy out of sort of the
componenttext: Okay, and then switching over to Freedom. I'd imagine that's a different, obviously, a different buyer profile. So how are they financing? Is it heavier cash? Is it too soon to tell? Or is there anything -- is there anything noteworthy out of sort of the Freedom buyer in terms of how they're paying for their homes?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think generally, we're pretty early with that launch to have any kind of generalization to say what that buyer's been doing. We did seen a lot of our Express communities in Florida, a lot of that buyer profile coming in with out of very significant down
componenttext: I think generally, we're pretty early with that launch to have any kind of generalization to say what that buyer's been doing. We did seen a lot of our Express communities in Florida, a lot of that buyer profile coming in with out of very significant down payments, low mortgages or even cash buyers. So we're excited to see how that unfolds. But we'll get [indiscernible] to see if that happens.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Susan Maklari from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Susan Maklari from UBS.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just further on the mortgage markets. We saw from the Fed yesterday, their loan officer survey that perhaps there's been some modest or moderate loosening in terms of mortgage lending. Is that something that you would say that you've seen, especially mayb
componenttext: Just further on the mortgage markets. We saw from the Fed yesterday, their loan officer survey that perhaps there's been some modest or moderate loosening in terms of mortgage lending. Is that something that you would say that you've seen, especially maybe among that Express buyer?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: To the extent there's been a bit loosening, it was been very modest. Really, similar to what we said the last couple of years. Any loosening has been very modest, nothing has moved the needle significantly in the market. But we would certainly expect that
componenttext: To the extent there's been a bit loosening, it was been very modest. Really, similar to what we said the last couple of years. Any loosening has been very modest, nothing has moved the needle significantly in the market. But we would certainly expect that over time, probably we continue to see a little bit more loosening as we -- as the economy improves as the mortgage market continues to improve.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of thinking about geographic footprint and sort of maybe expanding in certain markets on the back of the Wilson acquisition. Just are there any areas that you'd feel like maybe you're perhaps relatively underrepresented in and woul
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of thinking about geographic footprint and sort of maybe expanding in certain markets on the back of the Wilson acquisition. Just are there any areas that you'd feel like maybe you're perhaps relatively underrepresented in and would be interested in sort of further expanding?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's something we look at regularly. We have talked a bit internally that we've been working to improve our operations in the Northeast and feel like we're making good progress there and over the next couple of years, we think we're going to see some go
componenttext: That's something we look at regularly. We have talked a bit internally that we've been working to improve our operations in the Northeast and feel like we're making good progress there and over the next couple of years, we think we're going to see some good results there. As well in our Southwest, Phoenix markets, starting to come back a little bit. So we've been making some more investments there and increasing our community counts there. So we expect to see some pickup in our Southwest as well. And beyond that, we look at potential business acquisitions, we look at potential market startups. But we don't have anything new to announce there at the moment.

componenttext: Just 2 things. Curious, first of all, on where we are in the cycle, how you're thinking about managing your land investment. Obviously, I heard comments about optional land. But curious how you're thinking about managing through that at this point? And then secondly, you talked about Freedom becoming 1/3 of the market -- in 1/3 of your markets by the end of the year. Curious how if that is incremental to what you've done with Express and if that's going to take lots from Express or if we should expect for that price point or that piece of your business to grow even incrementally from where you are with Express?

componenttext: Well, from the Express Freedom standpoint, we're not thinking this is just going to replace the Express positions. We do believe this Freedom brand is a great vehicle to drive growth and support our double-digit growth across the company. And the rollout, the flag count, obviously -- sorry, what was the other question?

componenttext: Cycle. Well, I think we got a good 2017 position for it. headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016

componenttext: Yell, it's not just the Express market that feels good right now. It's in the Horton brand feels good. We've got a lot better in executing our Emerald offering, product offering and I guess I spent the month of September driving the Carolinas and looking at our flags, talking to our people. We've got a business plan for the Carolinas. I'll be very surprised if they don't exceed that plan significantly. So it's just a -- we say it frankly all the time. It's just good to be us. I don't have -- obviously, we can't operate in a vacuum [ph]. So the overall market is strong. But we're so well-positioned today that it really is just good to D.R. Horton.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016

componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Megan McGrath from MKM partners.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up a little bit on the cost side. You mentioned controlling our cost better and that was part of your outperformance in the gross margin. So just curious if you could give any more color on that? Is it pushing back against this pri
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up a little bit on the cost side. You mentioned controlling our cost better and that was part of your outperformance in the gross margin. So just curious if you could give any more color on that? Is it pushing back against this prior more in terms of price increases or is it more sort of operational in nature? Would love some more color on the detail on how you're controlling your cost in this environment.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Megan, what we've been doing is we've been working with national trade accounts, we've been working with suppliers in that regard to optimize our buying efficiencies. We've been with large market shares in many of our markets, most of our markets, we're a
componenttext: Megan, what we've been doing is we've been working with national trade accounts, we've been working with suppliers in that regard to optimize our buying efficiencies. We've been with large market shares in many of our markets, most of our markets, we're able to work with labor and get very competitive pricing there. So we're also looking at ways to be more efficient, executing a business plan in a neighborhood that drives an absorption rate that allows for the suppliers and the labor partners to be efficient with their business. And give us pricing that is reflective of that efficiencies. At the same time, we've been able to reduce incentives or raise prices once we achieve those absorption paces. And I think those two factors have been very helpful to our margins over the past few quarters. And they were very, very, very flat for several quarters in a row and we're starting to see some of the benefit of that execution and that discipline we've had in the field.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a couple of follow-ups from prior questions. I guess first from a seasonality perspective, gross margin was actually up sequentially in this fourth quarter. And that's not the historical trend where you're typically down 50 bps. So I guess can
componenttext: I just had a couple of follow-ups from prior questions. I guess first from a seasonality perspective, gross margin was actually up sequentially in this fourth quarter. And that's not the historical trend where you're typically down 50 bps. So I guess can you talk about what type of price increases you're able to implement over the past quarter or so to drive that? You mentioned in the prior question, mix, if you could talk a little bit more about that? And what read is there for 2017 guidance for gross margins. Stated differently, is 20 flat kind of a, I'll call it, a lowball number? How do you think about that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've been very pleased. As we said in our scripted comments, what we've been able to do in the last couple of quarters. It's really been a cumulative effect of our efforts and really just driving that consistent absorption to be able to increase our m
componenttext: So we've been very pleased. As we said in our scripted comments, what we've been able to do in the last couple of quarters. It's really been a cumulative effect of our efforts and really just driving that consistent absorption to be able to increase our margins. So when we look at '17, we still do expect the biggest driver of our bottom line to be incremental SG&A leverage due to the higher volumes. But if this brings good and we continue to meet and or exceed our business plans, then there could be some upside to our gross margin. Where we sit today, we feel comfortable saying it would be right around that 20% with some quarterly fluctuations that could be in the 19% to 21% range because there are some things outside of just price and land, lot and labor or materials that can impact our gross margin which is why we do continue to give you that slightly broader range and stick with around 20% for the full fiscal year. But we'll update that as we continue to move throughout the year and have better visibility in the spring.

componenttext: Will, we really don't have information as far as percentage where we raise price. That is managed at a local level. But overall, our revenue per square foot did go up 4.4% on a year-over-year basis and 3.7% on a sequential basis. So we are clearly seeing a fair amount of price appreciation and a fair sample of our communities across our business today and to the extent that it's there and we've got the opportunity to continue to do that, we reduce incentives, we'll continue to do that.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016

componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Buck Horne from Raymond James.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to the spec home versus to be built sale question just a little bit. I mean, just on absolute count, it looks like your unsold units are up a little north of 20% year-on-year and on a per community basis, you're probably up maybe close
componenttext: I wanted to go back to the spec home versus to be built sale question just a little bit. I mean, just on absolute count, it looks like your unsold units are up a little north of 20% year-on-year and on a per community basis, you're probably up maybe closer to 25%. Are you seeing a narrowing of the margin differential between specs and the contract sales to the point where it's -- that's what's giving you a lot more comfort to raise your unsold unit counts? Or is this more of a means to keep your labor more occupied and keep the trade base busy with the tightness in the labor market?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's more of the latter. Community by community, we manage our inventory levels, manage our production in order to hit the production schedules in the sales pace that we are expecting going forward and we feel very good about our positioning right now. Wh
componenttext: It's more of the latter. Community by community, we manage our inventory levels, manage our production in order to hit the production schedules in the sales pace that we are expecting going forward and we feel very good about our positioning right now. When we look at our overall units and our completed units, they are right in line with our business plans. In fact, when you look at our aging on those, which some of that information will be in our filings later on, our aging is actually improving. So that's something we monitor very closely as well. So overall, we feel good about our positioning.

componenttext: Okay, thanks. componenttext: We have not been in any kind of formal or broad agreement or discussions with anybody about that.
